div.p: PROCEEDINGS OF A GENERAL COURT MARTIAL, HELD AT MAJOR GENERAL LINCOLN'S QUARTERS, NEAR QUAKER-HILL, IN THE STATE OF NEW-YORK, BY ORDER OF HIS EXCELLENCY GENERAL WASHINGTON, COMMANDER IN CHIEF OF THE ARMY OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA, FOR THE TRIAL OF MAJOR GENERAL SCHUYLER, OCTOBER 1, 1778. Major General LINCOLN, Pre≈øident.
PHILADELPHIA: PRINTED BY HALL AND SELLERS, IN MARKET-STREET. MDCCLXXVIII.

div.head:
PROCEEDINGS OF A GENERAL COURT MARTIAL, &c.
Major General LINCOLN, PRESIDENT.
MEMBERS.
Brigadier General NIXON,
Brigadier General CLINTON,
Brigadier General WAYNE,
Brigadier General MUHLENBURGH,
Colonel GREATON,
Colonel JOHNSON,
Colonel PUTNAM,
Colonel M. GIST,
Colonel RUSSEL,
Colonel GRAYSON,
Colonel STEWART,
Colonel MEIGGS.
JOHN LAURANCE, JUDGE ADVOCATE.
div.p: THE Judge Advocate produces His Excellency the Commander in Chief's Order for the Court to ≈øit, which, being read, is as follows:

THE General Court Martial, whereof Major General Lincoln is Pre≈øident, will a≈ø≈øemble to-morrow morning, nine o'clock, at the Pre≈øident's quarters, and ≈øit at ≈øuch place as he ≈øhall appoint, for the trial of Major General Schuyler. Colonel John≈øon is appointed a member of the Court, vice Colonel Willis, who is ≈øick.

div.head: OCTOBER 1≈øt.
div.p: THE Pre≈øident, Members, and Judge Advocate being duly ≈øworn, the Court proceed to the trial of Major General Schuyler, who appears, and the following charge (contained in a report of a Committee of Congre≈øs, appointed to examine the evidence collected, and ≈øtate charges, again≈øt the General Officers, who were in the Northern Department when Ticonderoga and Mount Independence were evacuated) is exhibited again≈øt him.

Neglect of Duty, in not being pre≈øent at Ticonderoga to di≈øcharge the functions of his command, from the middle of June, 1777, until it was no longer po≈ø≈øible to maintain Ticonderoga and Mount Independence, con≈øi≈øtent with the ≈øafety of the troops and ≈øtores, when he ≈øhould have cau≈øed a retreat to be made for the pre≈øervation of both,‚Äîunder the 5th article of the 18th ≈øection of the Rules and Articles of War.

Major General Schuyler, being de≈øired to plead, ≈øays, I admit that I was ab≈øent from Ticonderoga from the 24th of June to the conclu≈øion of the ≈øiege, but I beg leave to in≈øi≈øt, and doubt not ≈øhall be able to prove, that I was guilty of no neglect of duty in not being there.

The Judge Advocate ob≈øerves, That Major General Schuyler having been appointed to command the Northern Department (including Albany, Ticonderoga, Fort Stanwix, and their dependencies) he was, by Congre≈øs, on the 22d of May, 1777, relea≈øed from all re≈øtraint re≈øpecting the e≈øtabli≈øhment of his Head-Quarters.

That, by letters to him from General St. Clair, Commanding Officer at Ticonderoga, dated the 13th, 18th, 24th, 25th, 26th, 28th and 30th of June, and 1≈øt of July, 1777, he was informed of the de≈øigns, ≈øtrength and advance of the enemy again≈øt Ticonderoga, and of the great danger in which that po≈øt and Mount Independence would be, in ca≈øe of an attack.

That it appears, in con≈øequence of the letters of the 13th and 18th of June, he went to Ticonderoga; for on the 20th he there held a Council of War. That, although in this Council of War it was determined that the effective rank and file were greatly inadequate to the defence of Ticonderoga and Mount Independence, but that neverthele≈øs both po≈øts ought to be maintained as long as po≈ø≈øible, con≈øi≈øtent with the ≈øafety of the troops and ≈øtores, and that the fortifications and lines on Mount Independence were very deficient, and that the repairs and additions to them ought to claim immediate attention, yet General Schuyler made no ≈øtay at Ticonderoga, to expedite the works on Mount Independence, and to cau≈øe a retreat to be made, when it became no longer po≈ø≈øible to maintain the po≈øts, con≈øi≈øtent with the ≈øafety of the troops and ≈øtores; for his ab≈øence appears from General St. Clair's letter to him on the 24th of June, and tho≈øe that followed.

That, Ticonderoga and Mount Independence being the po≈øts of greate≈øt defence to the United States again≈øt the advance of the Briti≈øh forces from Canada, and the main army of the Northern Department being ≈øtationed at tho≈øe po≈øts, it was General Schuyler's duty to have been at the head of that army, and to have remained there, when he knew the enemy were actually advanced again≈øt it. That his forces were greatly inadequate to the defence of the po≈øts, and that they were to be abandoned in the moment when it ≈øhould become no longer po≈ø≈øible to maintain them, con≈øi≈øtent with the ≈øafety of the troops and ≈øtores, a moment, of which it was nece≈ø≈øary the fir≈øt-officer in the department ≈øhould judge.

That, in the ab≈øence of General Schuyler, this critical and important moment pa≈ø≈øed unob≈øerved or unimproved; for on the 6th day of July the po≈øts were abandoned, with the lo≈øs of the ≈øick, ammunition, cannon, provi≈øion and cloathing of the army, and the lo≈øs of many lives in the retreat.

The Judge Advocate produces a copy of a re≈øolution of Congre≈øs, dated March 6, 1776; a copy of a re≈øolution of Congre≈øs, dated May ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , 1777; copies of letters from Major General St Clair to Major General
Schuyler, dated the 13th, 18th, 24th, 25th, 26th, 28th and 30th of June, and 1≈øt of July, 1777; al≈øo a copy of the proceedings of a Council of General Officers, held at Ticonderoga the 20th of June, 1777; which, being read, are as follow:

div.head: IN CONGRESS, March 6, 1776.
div.p: Re≈øolved, That the Pre≈øident acquaint General Schuyler, the Congre≈øs judge it nece≈ø≈øary that he ≈øhould remain at Albany, to make the proper arrangements re≈øpecting the army de≈øtined for Canada, and, therefore, that he e≈øtabli≈øh his Head-Quarters at Albany until farther orders.

div.head: May 22, 1777.
div.p: Re≈øolved, That Albany, Ticonderoga, Fort Stanwix, and their dependencies, be henceforward con≈øidered as forming the Northern Department.
That Major General Schuyler be directed forthwith to proceed to the Northern Department, and take upon him the command there.
Re≈øolved, That the re≈øolution pa≈ø≈øed the 6th of March, 1776, directing General Schuyler to e≈øtabli≈øh his Head-Quarters at Albany, be repealed.

closer.signed: Extract from the Minutes, CHARLES THOMSON, Secretary.

div.p: HERE follows the ≈øub≈øtance of the information given by two men from Canada, taken pri≈øoners by one of our parties on Onion River.

That General Burgoyne is arrived in Canada, but has brought no troops with him; that the Briti≈øh army is a≈ø≈øembling as fa≈øt as po≈ø≈øible at St. John's; that the light infantry, which they call the flying army, commanded by General Frazer, is already advanced to Point-au-Fer; that the whole army is ≈øaid to con≈øi≈øt of about ten thou≈øand men, a part of which, with Indians under the command of Sir John John≈øon, and Canadians under Captain Mackay, are to penetrate the country by the Mohawk River, whil≈øt the re≈øt of the army under General Burgoyne cro≈ø≈øes the Lake to attack this place; that their fleet (a particular account of which is in the inclo≈øed letter to General Sullivan) is all on the Lake, and we may depend on their being here in a fortnight at farthe≈øt.

From the nature and circum≈øtance of the pa≈øs granted to one of the two, which I here inclo≈øe, and his own account of the manner in which he was ≈øent from Montreal, viz. to ≈øearch plans of the country which he pretended to know were hid at Metcalf's, and his being po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of a con≈øiderable ≈øum of continental money, and ≈øome gold and ≈øilver, I have the ≈øtronge≈øt ≈øu≈øpicion of his being a ≈øpy, and have ≈øecured him as ≈øuch, and ≈øent him down to you, both that you might have an opportunity to examine him your≈øelf, and that, if you ≈øhould think of him as I do, he might be tried at Albany, where, ≈øhould he be found guilty, the ≈øentence will probably be more adequate to the crime than here; for I find the officer who lately ≈øuffered a ≈øpy he had in charge to e≈øcape, through the gro≈ø≈øe≈øt mi≈øconduct, has been honourably acquitted by a Court Martial.

You will likewi≈øe find a letter from Col. Bailey, containing the intelligence brought by two Frenchmen ≈øent down by General Gates. Though their intelligence differs very materially, they agree in the circum≈øtance of General Burgoyne's arrival; and if the≈øe fellows have really been ≈øent by him to ≈øee what we were about, there was no method more likely to procure them an ea≈øy reception than that of giving an account of the preparations in Canada, and carrying, or pretending to carry, letters from our friends. The letter to General Sullivan may notwith≈øtanding be genuine, and Am≈øbury ≈øays it was written by one Michael Shannon. This name was found upon him on a ≈øeparate piece of paper, in a fair hand, which he ≈øeemed unwilling to part with, and which I ≈øuppo≈øe to have been a private ≈øignal by which he was to be known upon his return.

If the enemy intend to attack us, I a≈ø≈øure you, Sir, we are very ill prepared to receive them. The whole amount of the continental troops, fit for duty, is 1576 rank and file, exclu≈øive of Baldwin's artificers 140, and Whitcomb's 52 rangers. Be≈øides the≈øe there are three regiment of Hamp≈øhire militia, engaged for no particular time, and who go off whenever they plea≈øe, 150 are gone ≈øince la≈øt return; two regiments of Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts militia of 252 rank and file fit for duty, engaged for two months from their arrival, three weeks of which with ≈øome of them is already expired. Among≈øt the number returned ≈øick there is no doubt but many would be u≈øeful in ca≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity, but at any rate we cannot reckon upon more than 2200 men. I am very much concerned to give you this di≈øagreeable detail, but I have ≈øomething wor≈øe to add to it.‚ÄîWe cannot increa≈øe our numbers by calling in the militia without ruin; for by the Commi≈ø≈øary's return, and the account of his weekly expenditure, there is meat for ≈øeven weeks only on the ground, and he has no pro≈øpect of any ≈øupply of ≈øalt-meat, but from ≈øome place near Still-Water, nor of fre≈øh, but by ≈øending to New-England for it.‚ÄîThis I have de≈øired him to do, but mu≈øt own I have little pro≈øpect of advantage from it; for be a≈ø≈øured that, and indeed every other communication, may and will very ea≈øily be cut off.‚ÄîI have heard of ≈øome cattle below Crown-Point, which I ≈øhall ≈øend for to-morrow.

The bridge goes on tolerably well, but is indeed a very heavy trouble≈øome job.‚ÄîThe ca≈ø≈øoons, Colonel Baldwin ≈øays, will be ≈øunk by the end of next week; in the mean time I have ordered the floating bridge to be removed to the lower ≈øide of them, which will ≈øerve as a kind of ≈øecond boom, and retard at lea≈øt, if not prevent, the enemy's ve≈ø≈øels from pa≈ø≈øing, ≈øhould they attempt it.

A magazine of wood ≈øhould be laid in immediately, but how to effect it I know not, as there are no teams here of any kind, and not a ≈øtick upon the Mount.‚ÄîAll the timber for the bridge is hauled out of the woods by hand, and employs a much greater number of men than would otherwi≈øe be nece≈ø≈øary, and might be employed, and are wanted for other purpo≈øes.‚ÄîWhat can the Quarter-Ma≈øter mean by leaving this place, where ≈øo many works are to be carried on, without ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary an article as draught cattle?
The tents here are in general very bad. I mu≈øt beg you, my dear General, to ha≈øten up the new tents, for I ≈øhall get no good of the troops here in any way, whil≈øt they remain in barracks.

Our powder magazines are in ≈øo wretched a ≈øtate, that I am told near fifty pounds of powder a week is damaged. In ≈øhort, every thing is ≈øo much out of order, that I will add no more to this li≈øt of grievances, than to tell you we have no cartridge paper.
When I write again, I hope to have ≈øomething more agreeable to entertain you with, and am, with much e≈øteem.

closer.signed: Your mo≈øt obedient humble Servant, A. ST. CLAIR.

postscript.p: I forgot to mention a paper in which Am≈øbury's money was wrapped, and is al≈øo inclo≈øed; it is blurred and blotted, but you will ob≈øerve it contains a letter from Eph. Jones to his brother, dated June 2d, about the time Am≈øbury left Montreal, and is a corroborating circum≈øtance of the fellow's ill de≈øign.

I ≈øhould have called upon the militia but for the ≈øtate of our magazine‚ÄîShould they come in fa≈øt, which I believe they would, they might eat us out before the arrival of either the enemy or a ≈øupply.‚Äî Plea≈øe to give your directions on this head as ≈øoon ‚Ä¢ s po≈ø≈øible.
The batteaus are in ruin for want of pitch and ta ‚Ä¢ , which Colonel Hay ≈øays he has often wrote for.
Adams, the other of the pri≈øoners, ≈øeems to be an innocent fellow, and whom Am≈øbury brought off with him without knowing his errand; he was taken by Mackay at Sabbath Day Point.

div.p: INCLOSED you have the returns of the troops and ≈øtores at this place, all except the cloathier's, which is ≈øo drained I thought it needle≈øs to a≈øk for any from him, as he has almo≈øt literally nothing.

Since my la≈øt I have had con≈øtant ≈øcouts out, but have made no di≈øcovery of the enemy, ≈øave that four of their ve≈ø≈øels are lying about a mile on the hither ≈øide of the Split Rock; they con≈øi≈øt of two ≈øhips, and two gondolas; and on Friday la≈øt a ≈øchooner beat up within four miles of Crown Point, but, without landing any of her people, or coming to anchor, returned down the lake.

Ye≈øterday about noon we had two men, who had ≈øtrolled out of camp without arms, taken by a party of ≈øavages, who had ≈øtole down to the road ≈øide betwixt M'Into≈øh's and the bridge, and concealed them≈øelves in the bu≈øhes; they were immediately pur≈øued as far as Putnam's Creek, but could not be overtaken; unluckily, however, they fell in with a ≈øcouting party I had ≈øent down to di≈øcover the motions of the enemy, that were upon their return, and fired upon them unexpectedly; the officer is wounded, one man killed and ≈øcalped, and one mi≈ø≈øing, but whether taken or not is as yet uncertain.

Another party that I had ordered to proceed to Point-au-Fer, or wherever the enemy might be, returned la≈øt night on di≈øcovering a large party of Indians on the ea≈øt ≈øide of the lake about four miles above Crown Point. I think of ≈øending to feel their pul≈øe to-night, as I am ≈øure it would be of con≈øequence to give the≈øe fellows a drubbing.

I am at a lo≈øs to form a judgment of the de≈øigns of the enemy. If they mean to attack us, one would think it indi≈øcreet to put us on our guard by ≈øuch a trifling affair, and yet I cannot think they could prevail with any number of the ≈øavages to come on, unle≈øs they had an army not far off to ≈øupport them. Be that as it will, I ≈øhall u≈øe every precaution po≈ø≈øible again≈øt ≈øurprize, and will endeavour to penetrate their de≈øigns. The ≈øame rea≈øon, notwith≈øtanding our weakne≈øs, ≈øtill prevails again≈øt calling for the militia as when I wrote la≈øt, having as yet received no ≈øupply of meat either fre≈øh or ≈øalt.

Do you know, Sir, any thing about the terms upon which Capt. Whitcomb's corps was rai≈øed. He informs me, that by General Gates's orders he promi≈øed his people that they ≈øhould have the ≈øame bounty as the troops of the State in which they were rai≈øed, notwith≈øtanding they were not part of their quota. This promi≈øe has not ‚Ä¢ een complied with, and they are held by a conditional agreement only, which expires this day. I ≈øhall be able to retain them, however, until you favour me with your an≈øwer.

I am making ≈øome improvement upon the Mount, but that and the Ticonderoga ≈øide have ≈øuch dependence upon, and connection with, each other, that in my opinion it will be very dangerous to give up either, and yet it is certain we cannot with our pre≈øent numbers hold both. I de≈øign, however, to make the appearance of doing it, and, after defending Ticonderoga as long as po≈ø≈øible, retreat to Mount Independence.
Our guards are crouded with tories; they are dangerous here, and cannot properly be tried. I have ordered them to Albany. I am, &c.

closer.signed: A. ST. CLAIR.

postscript.p: The bridge goes on heavily, the ca≈ø≈øoons not all ≈øunk yet, but the timber is almo≈øt all cut, and in the water.
The officers of the fleet have not received commi≈ø≈øions, and are very unea≈øy about it.

div.p:
SERJEANT HEATH, who I ≈øent down the lake to make di≈øcoveries, returned la≈øt night, and informs me, that on Tue≈øday la≈øt he ≈øaw two birch canoes going down the lake with ≈øixteen Indians and three white men in them, and ≈øuppo≈øes it was the party that had done the mi≈øchief near the lines the day before‚Äî that from a place near the mouth of Otter Creek, he ≈øaw three ve≈ø≈øels under ≈øail beating up, one at anchor about one mile above ‚Ä¢ plit Rock, and the Thunderer behind it‚Äîfrom this place he likewi≈øe de≈øcried an encampment of the enemy on both ≈øides of Gilliland's Creek‚Äîthat from the appearance of it, and the extent, he thinks it mu≈øt contain a great body of men, and that a number of ≈ømoaks aro≈øe at a di≈øtance back, which he ≈øuppo≈øes was from the encampment of the Indian‚Äîthat on Friday la≈øt, from Pointon, he ≈øaw twenty batteaus come out of Gilliland's Creek, and ≈øail up the lake pa≈øt the Split Rock towards Ticonderoga‚Äîthat one of the inhabitants, in whom he could place confidence, informed him the Indians were very numerous‚Äî that they frequently cro≈øs to the ea≈øt ≈øide of the lake, and that a party of them had been at his hou≈øe a few minutes before his arrival‚Äîthat he then returned to Otter Creek, where he propo≈øed to have halted to refre≈øh his party, but, on being informed that a large party of Indians were at one Briton's, he made the be≈øt of his way here‚Äîone of his party this day fell behind a little, and was either taken or de≈øerted; he ≈øu≈øpects the latter, becau≈øe he both waited for him, and ≈øent back to look for him‚Äîthat one Webb, another inhabitant, informed him that the enemy had been four or five days at Gilliland's‚Äîthat they came up with a va≈øt number
of batteaus and ≈øome gondolas‚Äîthat ≈øome of the troops come over frequently, and ≈øay their whole army is there, and that they are only waiting the arrival of the re≈øt of their ve≈ø≈øels and ≈øtores, when they are to attack this place.

I have no doubt that a party of the enemy are at Gilliland's, nor that their de≈øign is to come here, but not in my opinion to attack, but to harra≈øs us, and give confidence to their ≈øavages, who, it is more than probable, would not have been prevailed upon to undertake it without being joined by ≈øome regular troops. Were they in force, it is improbable they would wa≈øte their time at ≈øuch a di≈øtance, in a part of the country where they can find nothing to refre≈øh them≈øelves; and I do not find that they have made any depredations on the ea≈øt ≈øide.

It is not ea≈øy to judge of the force at a di≈øtant view of an encampment, and Heath mu≈øt have been „Äà‚óä„Äâ miles or more di≈øtant from that on Gilliland's Point, a di≈øtance too great to determine any thing with preci≈øion, although he had a gla≈øs to a≈ø≈øi≈øt his eye; be≈øides, I think the ground is not capable of encamping a great number (for he in≈øi≈øts on it they are not on the high ground, but upon the beach only) but of this you are a much better judge than me, as I never ≈øaw it but once: Be the matter as it will, I ≈øhall endeavour to guard again≈øt ≈øurprize, and to di≈øcover both them and their de≈øigns; and, if opportunity offers, feel their pul≈øes a little.

I had all the ground between this and Crown Point, from the lake ≈øome di≈øtance over the mountains, well examined ye≈øterday with a heavy ≈øcout, but they di≈øcovered no enemy, nor appearance of any. Whitcomb ≈øays he is certain there has not been an Indiain but three in that quarter ≈øince the pri≈øoners were taken, and that it was three or four days ≈øince the≈øe three had been there; ≈øo that the Indians ≈øaid to have been about us, and fired at, were, I believe, the children of a di≈øturbed imagination.

You had an exceeding bad time to cro≈øs the lake, but I hope you got well over, and without any injury to your health, though it mu≈øt have been expo≈øed, as I doubt if you was not obliged to be out a ≈øecond night. I ≈øhall write again to you by expre≈øs the moment I make any farther di≈øcoveries; and am, with much re≈øpect and e≈øteem,

closer.signed: Your mo≈øt obedient humble Servant, A. ST. CLAIR.

div.p: I INFORMED you ye≈øterday that an encampment of the enemy had been di≈øcovered at Gilliland's Creek. La≈øt night two of their ve≈ø≈øels came up to Crown Point, and this morning there are ≈øeven lying at that place; the re≈øt of their fleet is probably but a little lower down, as we heard their morning guns di≈øtinctly at different places. They have al≈øo debarked ≈øome troops, and encamped upon Chimney Point. div.p: THIS moment I have received information from Hoite, of Otter Creek, that a large party of Indians and Tories are gone up that creek, ≈øuppo≈øed to be five hundred, and are de≈øigned to cut off the communication by Skeen≈øborough. div.p:
MY ≈øcout, on which I depended much for intelligence, is not yet returned, nor I fear ever will now. We are going on with the nece≈ø≈øary works on the Mount as fa≈øt as po≈ø≈øible, and have removed the mo≈øt valuable of the ≈øtores and provi≈øion to that ≈øide. I could wi≈øh the batteaus were all over ≈øoon, or that you would not ≈øend them. I beg leave to refer you for further particulars to Colonel Varrick, who takes the charge of this, and am,

closer.signed: A. ST. CLAIR.

div.p: THIS morning ≈øome of the enemy's gun-boats appeared at the Three Mile Point, when the alarm was given. div.p: NOT finding a convenient opportunity to ≈øend off my letter, I have the plea≈øure to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 28th. Major General Schuyler proceeds in his Defence, as follows:

p.hi: Mr. Pre≈øident, and Gentlemen of the Court Martial,

div.p: AS Courts Martial may, with propriety, be con≈øidered not only as Courts of Ju≈øtice, but al≈øo as Courts of Honour, I am happy that my conduct is to be examined, and its merits a≈øcertained by this. The charge again≈øt me is ≈øimple, and confined to one point, and the evidence adduced to ≈øupport it is comprized in very little compa≈øs. Tho≈øe ≈øorts were inve≈øted on or about the fir≈øt day of July, and evacuated on the ≈øixth day of July, 1777. During the whole time of the ≈øiege, I am charged with having been ab≈øent, and therein of having neglected my duty. To this charge I am now to an≈øwer. body.p: IF va≈øt ≈øuperiority in numbers, great good health and ≈øpirits, can in≈øure ≈øucce≈øs, our troops will be crowned with it in this department, and very ≈øoon, immediately after which I intend to ha≈øten to Head Quarters; and as I wi≈øh not to be long ab≈øent from my family, I mu≈øt entreat the favour of Congre≈øs that I may be furni≈øhed with the charges upon which the enquiry into my conduct is to be made, that I may be enabled to carry with me the nece≈ø≈øary witne≈ø≈øes and papers.

IN le≈øs than twenty days I ≈øhall nearly compleat a comfor ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ le hou≈øe for the reception of my family, happy if by that time I ≈øhall be ordered to attend at Head Quarters for my trial; and as ≈øoon as that is over. I propo≈øe doing my≈øelf the honour to return you in per≈øon my warme≈øt acknowledgments for your polite and friendly attention, and carry with me to my retirement a heart full of gratitude and e≈øteem.

I HAVE not a doubt but that the gentlemen of the Committee, appointed to enquire into the cau≈øes of the lo≈øs of Ticonderoga and Mount Independence, judging of my feelings by what their own would be in a ≈øimilar
≈øituation, will pay ≈øuch attention to the object of their appointment, as that the enquiry into my conduct may take place as early as po≈ø≈øible. Confident I am it cannot be either their wi≈øh, or that of Congre≈øs, that I ≈øhould remain in my pre≈øent di≈øagreeable ≈øituation any longer than ab≈øolute nece≈ø≈øity requires.

WHEN a man of ≈øentiment, labouring under odious and injurious ≈øu≈øpicions, has in pro≈øpect a period which promi≈øes to afford him relief, and re≈øtore quiet to his mind, it is natural that he ≈øhould anxiou≈øly wi≈øh for its arrival. I HAVE already tre≈øpa≈ø≈øed on the patience of Congre≈øs, but I feel my≈øelf obliged to intreat their attention a moment longer. div.p: THE various bu≈øine≈øs of your department, in making the nece≈ø≈øary preparations for the next campaign, will require your clo≈øe≈øt and immediate attention. I ≈øhall therefore point out part of what is to be done, and which you are to execute without the lea≈øt delay.

Timber, plank, boards, nails, pitch, oakum and cordage, mu≈øt be provided in time, and ≈øuch a number of oars, ≈øetting-poles, paddles and ≈øcoops, as you ≈øhall find, upon enquiry, are wanted.

I wi≈øh you continually to reflect on the difficulties attending a long land tran≈øportation, e≈øpecially in the ≈øpring of the year, when the roads are almo≈øt impa≈ø≈øable, working cattle weak, and forage extremely ≈øcarce. I have ordered ≈øleds to be con≈øtructed at Saratoga, for tran≈øporting what cannon may be procured this winter. You will immediately ≈øend two black≈ømiths, with bellows and every other nece≈ø≈øary, to that place, to do the iron-work, and ≈øuch other as may be wanted.

I fore≈øee that the barracks and ho≈øpital will very ≈øoon be de≈øtitute of fire-wood. You will therefore take timely care to procure a ≈øupply, not only for daily u≈øe, but for the ≈øpring, as then it is not to be had, unle≈øs at an immoderate price, and with great difficulty. I am, &c.

div.head: Copy of a letter to Governor Trumbull, dated Albany, December 29, 1776.
div.p: AS I have not been honoured with a line from Congre≈øs, on the ≈øubject of the preparations nece≈ø≈øary for the next campaign in the Northern Quarter, altho' I tran≈ømitted my opinion on the ≈øubject in the beginning of November, I conclude that the enemy's manoeuvres in Jer≈øey have ≈øo entirely engro≈ø≈øed their attention, that they have not been able to attend to what I ≈øugge≈øted. I have therefore re≈øolved, without waiting any longer for their directions, as the winter is ≈ølipping away, to carry into execution whatever I deem e≈ø≈øential to the ≈øervice, and which does not admit of further delay, of which, among≈øt other things, that of procuring a ≈øufficiency of cannon for the defence of Ticonderega, &c. is a capital article. I ≈øhould therefore be glad to know what cannon you can furni≈øh me with, and where I may ≈øend for them, as I wi≈øh that an article, ≈øo extremely difficult to move in the ≈øpring of the year, ≈øhould be carried to the places for which they are de≈øigned whil≈øt we are favoured with good ≈øledding. A very con≈øiderable quantity of ≈øhot is al≈øo wanted; and as Mr. Living≈øton's furnace is out of bla≈øt, I cannot procure them there. Can the≈øe be got at Sali≈øbury, and when? Be≈øides the cannon for the forts, a number will be wanted for five or ≈øix ≈øtout gallies which I propo≈øe to build in Lake George, to prevent the enemy's penetrating by that Lake, if they ≈øhould be able to di≈ølodge us from the Ticonderoga ≈øide of Lake Champlain, and draw their boats by land into Lake George, which it would be po≈ø≈øible for them to do, altho' we keep po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Mount Independence. By the way of Skeen≈øborough, I am morally ≈øure they will not be able to penetrate; as I hope, in the cour≈øe of the winter, ≈øo effectually to ob≈øtruct the Lake, between Ticonderoga and the Mount, as that no kind of ve≈ø≈øels will be able to pa≈øs, unle≈øs they fir≈øt make them≈øelves ma≈øters of Mount Independence, which I think will be impo≈ø≈øible, if we can procure men, cannon and ammunition. A ≈øtock of provi≈øion I ≈øhall take care to lay in this winter.

Colonel Simmonds, with part of his regiment, from the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts-Bay, is on his way from hence to Ticonderoga. I ≈øhall be extremely happy to ≈øee a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of troops coming on, for I very much fear that the garri≈øon will not be detained after the term of their enli≈øtment expires.

I ≈øhall want two companies of carpenters, to con≈øtruct the ve≈ø≈øels intended for Lake George. Captain Le≈øter and Captain Win≈ølow gave good ≈øatisfaction la≈øt campaign, and I wi≈øh them to be employed in that bu≈øine≈øs. Permit me to beg the favour of you to enquire of them, if they will each rai≈øe a company, ≈øo as to leave Connecticut about the fir≈øt day of April. I have the plea≈øure to inform you that I have received friendly me≈ø≈øages from the Indians, who ≈øeem determined to ob≈øerve a ≈øtrict neutrality.

div.head: Extract of a letter to Thomas C ‚Ä¢ ≈øhing, E≈øq Speaker of the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives of the State of Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts-Bay, dated Albany, December 30, 1776.
div.p: SHOULD the enemy leave us unmole≈øted this winter, I ≈øhall hope that they will not be able to penetrate from the northward in ≈øpring or ≈øummer, provided troops, cannon and ammunition, are furni≈øhed me.

By a letter from the Honourable General Ward, of the 16th in≈øtant, which I al≈øo received la≈øt night, I find that I am to expect no cannon from your State. There are none in this, nor can I procure any from Penn≈øylvania or Jer≈øey. I am not yet advi≈øed what Connecticut can afford me, but I am confident it will be greatly ≈øhort of our wants. I therefore wi≈øh the Legi≈ølature of your State would recon≈øider the matter, and ≈øupply me with all the cannon you po≈ø≈øibly can. I mu≈øt al≈øo entreat that as much powder, lead and cartridge paper may be ≈øent, as can be collected in your State; and as the≈øe articles are much ea≈øier and cheaper moved in winter than they can be at any other time, I ≈øhall hope that they will be forwarded without delay.

The cannon, if any are furni≈øhed, might be carried directly to Ticonderoga, where the A≈ø≈øi≈øtant Deputy Quarter-Ma≈øter General will pay the expence of tran≈øportation. The powder, lead and cartridge paper to this place.

postscript.p: P. S. The Indians appear to continue friendly to us, and I have rea≈øon to believe they will adhere to the promi≈øes of neutrality which they have made. I ≈øoon expect a vi≈øit from them. They are in great want of cloathing; blankets e≈øpecially. If 4 or 500 can be procured, I wi≈øh them to be ≈øent the very ≈øoone≈øt po≈ø≈øible.

I have been di≈øappointed in procuring two tons of ≈øteel from New-Jer≈øey, and it is an article ≈øo e≈ø≈øentially nece≈ø≈øary that it cannot be di≈øpen≈øed with. Pray be ≈øo good as to ≈øend me that quantity, or rather three tons, if it is to be had.

div.head: Extract of a letter to Congre≈øs, dated Albany, December 30, 1776.
div.p: THAT I have not been honoured with the commands of Congre≈øs, on the various matters mentioned in my former letters, and in a paper which I delivered Me≈ø≈ørs. Stockton and Clymer on the 11th ult. is mo≈øt probably to be imputed to the nece≈ø≈øity it has been under, of giving the clo≈øe≈øt attention to the manoeuvres of the enemy in Jer≈øey. This con≈øideration, and that of the winter's being con≈øiderably advanced, has induced me to proceed in making ≈øuch preparations for the next campaign as I deem e≈ø≈øentially nece≈ø≈øary, without waiting the determination of Congre≈øs, tru≈øting that Congre≈øs will readily pardon any ≈øaux pas I may commit from erring in judgment.

On the 3d in≈øtant I addre≈ø≈øed my≈øelf to General Ward, on the ≈øubject of cannon and military ≈øtores. From the copy of his letter, which is inclo≈øed, Congre≈øs will perceive that I am not likely to receive any aid from the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts-Bay. I have, however, ≈øince the receipt of his letter, which was received on the 29th in≈øt. written by expre≈øs to the Honourable Thomas Cu≈øhing, entreating that the Legi≈ølature of that State would recon≈øider the matter, and furni≈øh what cannon, &c. they can, and urged the nece≈ø≈øity of their being ≈øent whil≈øt the earth is covered with ≈ønow, as a great expence in the tran≈øportation will be ≈øaved by the≈øe articles being carried to Ticonderoga in winter. I have made ≈øimilar applications to Governor Trumbull, and the Pre≈øident of New-Hamp≈øhire, and I propo≈øe in a few days to vi≈øit the Convention of this State on the ≈øame ≈øubject; for indeed, unle≈øs a ≈øufficient number of cannon and ammunition can be procured, we mu≈øt inevitably lo≈øe Ticonderoga, and what the con≈øequences of ≈øuch a di≈øa≈øter will be are too evident to dwell upon.

I have cau≈øed ten black≈ømiths ≈øhops to be erected in this city, and have engaged workmen to be employed in making intrenching tools, axes, nails, &c. and hope, with the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the ≈ømiths in the vicinity, to get a ≈øufficient ≈øtock of tho≈øe nece≈ø≈øary articles, provided I can any how procure a quantity of ≈øteel, for which I have applied to the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts-Bay; but left none ≈øhould be ≈øent from thence, I mu≈øt again entreat Congre≈øs to order three tons from Penn≈øylvania or Jer≈øey, with all the di≈øpatch po≈ø≈øible.

I have ordered all the provi≈øions that can be procured to be ≈øent to Fort George, Che≈øhire's and Ticonderoga. I fear a deficiency of ≈øalted meat, of which a ≈øufficient ≈øtock ≈øhould be laid in, as it would be ri≈øking too much to depend on the precarious ≈øupply of fre≈øh beef, at a time when the fortre≈ø≈øes may be inve≈øted by the enemy.

Directions are given for repairing the batteaus on Lake Champlain and Lake George, and for building one hundred and fifty, adapted to the navigation of Hud≈øon's and the Mohawk rivers and Wood creek. Should the enemy be able to force us from Ticonderoga, it will be po≈ø≈øible for them, although we keep po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Mount Independence, to get into Lake George, by drawing their batteaus over land from below Ticonderoga; for although the ta≈øk would be arduous, yet it is fea≈øable, and ought to be guarded again≈øt. I therefore propo≈øe to build five or ≈øix flat bottomed ve≈ø≈øels, of con≈øiderable force, on Lake George, and ≈øhall begin to prepare the nece≈ø≈øary articles in the beginning of February, unle≈øs Congre≈øs ≈øhould plea≈øe to direct otherwi≈øe; and about the ≈øame time I propo≈øe to begin the nece≈ø≈øary work of ob≈øtructing the navigation of Lake Champlain, between Ticonderoga and Mount Independence, which I hope to execute ≈øo effectually, as not to leave a po≈ø≈øibility for any kind of craft to pa≈øs whil≈øt we keep po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the latter place, and which I think we can do again≈øt any force whatever, provided we have a ≈øufficient garri≈øon, properly ≈øupplied with cannon, ammunition and provi≈øion.

A con≈øiderable quantity of cordage and oakum is wanted. If it cannot be ≈øupplied in this State, I ≈øhall ≈øend to Ea≈øtern ones, and ≈øo indeed I mu≈øt for many articles that will be wanted. I wi≈øh therefore a re≈øolution of Congre≈øs, directing every State to comply with my applications in whatever they can.

The Indians have ≈øent me a friendly me≈ø≈øage, and I have great hopes that they will abide by the neutrality they have promi≈øed to ob≈øerve. A report prevails that the enemy have reque≈øted the Mohawks to remove into the country, beyond our ≈øettlements, but I have rea≈øon to believe that it is void of foundation. I ≈øoon expect a vi≈øit from a con≈øiderable number of Chiefs and Warriors. They are in great di≈øtre≈øs for blankets. Unfortunately we have none here. If Convention ≈øhould think proper to inve≈øt the officers I have mentioned with ≈øuch a power, I wi≈øh it to be done the ≈øoone≈øt po≈ø≈øible, as the ≈øea≈øon in which the articles wanted can be mo≈øt ea≈øily conveyed will ≈øoon be pa≈øt.

div.head: Extract of a letter to General Wa≈øhington, dated Albany, January 30, 1777.
div.p: YOUR Excellency's favour of the 18th in≈øtant I had the honour to receive on the 28th. I cannot plead that bu≈øine≈øs, altho' I am clo≈øely employed, has been the only motive that I have not latterly done my≈øelf the plea≈øure to write you. I well know that every moment of your time mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily be engro≈ø≈øed in tho≈øe affairs, which, from your immediate ≈øituation, mu≈øt claim the earlie≈øt attention. I therefore contented my≈øelf with writing to Mr. Harri≈øon; but I fear either his or mine have mi≈øcarried, as I have not been favoured with an an≈øwer to mine of the 3d and 21≈øt ult. I hope your Excellency has received mine of the 15th and 25th, each inclo≈øing one to Congre≈øs.

Your ≈øucce≈øs in the Jer≈øeys has greatly in≈øpirited the people in this quarter, and the ≈øituation to which you have driven the enemy, affords us the plea≈øing hope that we ≈øhall ≈øoon hear you have reaped fre≈øh laurels.

I have not the lea≈øt doubt, ≈øhould General Carleton leave us unmole≈øted this winter, which I really do not believe he will, that he will pu≈øh very early in the ≈øpring, and he may come in the latter end of April. Before that time, therefore, the army ought to be at Ticonderoga. I do not think it ≈øhould con≈øi≈øt of le≈øs than 10,000 men, be≈øides 1000 for the ≈øeveral pa≈øts on the communication, and as many for Fort Schuyler and the other po≈øts on the Mohawk river. With the≈øe I think we ≈øhall have nothing to fear, provided we are ≈øufficiently ≈øupplied with cannon, ammunition and provi≈øion.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Colonel Baldwin, dated Head-Quarters, Albany, February 1, 1777.
div.p: GENERAL SCHUYLER has enjoined me to urge you to the mo≈øt ≈øpeedy compliance with his orders of the 21≈øt ult. and not to delay a moment to repair to this place, with the articles provided by you for this department. I am, &c.

closer.signed: J. LANSING, junior.

postscript.p: I inclo≈øe copy of the letter above alluded to.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Major Stevens of the Artillery, dated Head-Quarters, Albany, February 1, 1777.
div.p: THE proceding is a copy of General Schuyler's letter of the 21≈øt ult. I have it in command from the General to urge you to the mo≈øt ≈øpeedy compliance with it, as the ≈øervice will ≈øuffer greatly unle≈øs you come in≈øtantly to this place. I am, &c.

closer.signed: J. LANSING, junior.

div.head: Extract of a letter to Congre≈øs, dated Albany, February 4, 1777.
div.p: THE di≈øtre≈øs I labour under, from the want of a ≈øupply of Indian goods, is inconceivably great. I can, with great truth, ≈øay, that not above one day in ten pa≈ø≈øes but that I have more or le≈øs of the Indians with me. At this moment I have twenty-five Mohawks, Oneidas and Onondagoes in my hou≈øe, de≈øtitute of cloathing, and pre≈ø≈øing me to be relieved, and to continue the trade I opened la≈øt fall. It will be ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary that a treaty ≈øhould be held with them, previous to the opening of the campaign. The enemy will, early in the ≈øpring, hold one with them at O≈øwego, and we mu≈øt guard again≈øt, and try to counteract the ideas they will try to „Äà‚óä„Äâ them with.

Mr. McCarty, who was ≈øe ‚Ä¢ t to the Ea≈øtern States to purcha≈øe ≈øundry articles greatly needed in this department, has in part ≈øucceeded. Among≈øt other articles, he has procured between four and five tons of ≈øteel, which may ≈øuf ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ce. He could not „Äà‚óä„Äâ any camp kettles, or tin to make them of, but inform me that
forty or fifty tons of tin is in the continental ≈øtores at Bo≈øton, together with a number of blankets, cloathing, &c. but that the ≈øtore-keepers advi≈øed him that none could be i≈ø≈øued without the immediate order of Congre≈øs. I wi≈øh therefore to have ≈øuch order expedited. I ≈øhall, however, that we may not ≈øuffer by the delay that mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily take place before ≈øuch order can reach Bo≈øton, immediately apply to General Ward, entreating him to prevail on the ≈øtore-keepers to ≈øend part of the tin, cloathing and blankets, of which we ≈øtand in immediate need.

I have borrowed fifty thou≈øand dollars from this State, and con≈øiderable ≈øums from individuals, for the public ≈øervice, all of which is already expended, and ≈øtill every department is deeply indebted. I wi≈øh, therefore, that mea≈øures may be taken to ha≈øten a ≈øupply to the military che≈øt here.

Neither Colonel Baldwin, the Chief Engineer in this department, nor any of the artificers rai≈øing in the Ea≈øtern States, are as yet arrived, ≈øo that I cannot begin the nece≈ø≈øary works at Ticonderoga, Fort George, &c. as early as I intended, and as they ought to be begun.

As the garri≈øon of Ticonderoga is daily weakening, and that I have no pro≈øpect of a ≈øpeedy reinforcement, I ≈øhall not dare to ≈øend the cannon to that place, which are expected from Sali≈øbury with the fir≈øt ≈øledding, but order them to be left at Fort George and Che≈øhire's.

No ammunition of any kind is yet arrived here, nor do I know where to procure it. His Excellency General Wa≈øhington cannot furni≈øh me with any from Jer≈øey. Perhaps it might be well if I was informed where the continental magazines are, and to which of them to apply.

div.head: Copy of a letter to Mr. James Deane, Indian Interpreter, at Fort Schuyler, dated Albany, February 6, 1777.
div.p: THE bearers of this carry a belt from the Commi≈ø≈øioners of Indian Affairs, which is to go by them to the Caghnawagas of Canada. I have written to Colonel Elmore to furni≈øh you with-≈ønow ≈øhoes, provi≈øions and ≈øuch other articles as you may need, to equip the party for Canada.
I have al≈øo ordered Colonel Elmore to furni≈øh Mr. Spencer with one ration and a half of provi≈øions until his wife comes up, and thence forward with three. Plea≈øe to advi≈øe Mr. Spencer of this.

Be≈øides what the Indians have in charge from the Commi≈ø≈øioners, you will pre≈øs them warmly to try to di≈øcover the enemy's force in Canada, di≈øtingui≈øhing what Briti≈øh and what foreign troops may be there, and what number of Canadians may be engaged to ≈øerve with them. Al≈øo what Indians, and the numbers they may expect will join them. How they are ≈øupplied with provi≈øions. Whether they mean to attack Ticonderoga in the cour≈øe of the winter. If a treaty with the Six Nations is to be held, and when and where. At what place the Briti≈øh troops are quartered. Whether an attack by the way of the Mohawk river is intended. Whether great quantities of provi≈øions are ≈øent to Ot≈øwegatchie. If Quebec, or any other places in Canada, are fortifying. If any troops left Canada la≈øt fall, and how many, and at what time. Whether any forage is collecting at St. John's, or any batteaus building there or el≈øewhere. What price flour is now ≈øold at in Canada. You will al≈øo reque≈øt the Indians to try to prevail on ≈øome of the Caghnawagas to give intelligence of the movements of the enemy, and to a≈ø≈øure them that every important piece of intelligence which they convey to me will be rewarded.

div.head: Copy of a letter to Mr. James Deane, dated Albany, February 7, 1777.
div.p: I WROTE you ye≈øterday, but forgot to mention to you to give the Indians intended for Canada an account of the ≈øucce≈øs of our arms; for altho' I have done it here, yet I wi≈øh you to repeat to them, that after the enemy had obliged our people to leave Long-I≈øland and New-York, they attempted to get us between them and the ≈øea, in order to cut off our ≈øupplies, but although they tried all ≈øummer to do this, they were not able to effect it. They then took a fort of ours, ≈øituate upon York I≈øland, where we could not come to its relief, becau≈øe their ≈øhips of war prevented us. As ≈øoon as they had taken this fort they marched into New-Jer≈øey, and as mo≈øt of General Wa≈øhington's army was gone home, the ≈øoldiers term of enli≈øtment being expired, he was obliged to retreat before them to Trenton; but, having collected ≈øome troops there, he fought them on the 26th of December, as is already related. On the 3d of January he pur≈øued them, and fought them at Princeton, twelve miles on this ≈øide of Trenton. There he killed near three hundred, and took upwards of two hundred pri≈øoners. He has ≈øince that taken ninety-five loaded waggons, and five empty ones, al≈øo eighty-four war hor≈øes, and upwards of two hundred pri≈øoners. The enemy are now at Brun≈øwick, and they cannot get away, except by flying to their ve≈ø≈øels, becau≈øe General Wa≈øhington and Mon≈øieur Fermoy, a General from Old France, and General Putnam, each with a body of troops, ≈øurround them.

That France has ≈øent us 200,000 l. worth of artillery and warlike ≈øtores. Many French officers and Engineers, among≈øt others, Mon≈øieur Laboniere, the Engineer who built Ticonderoga la≈øt war. Write upon a bit of paper Laboniere Engineer, and let them take it with them, as he is well known by the Caghnawagas.
Reque≈øt of Colonel Elmore as much powder and ball as the party may want.

div.head: Extract of a letter to Major General Ward, dated Albany, February 7, 1777.
div.p: A VARIETY of articles are wanted in this department for the public ≈øervice, for which I have written to Mr. Abraham Living≈øton, one of the Agents of Congre≈øs, now at Bo≈øton; but if he ≈øhould not be able to procure all the articles, I have directed him to call on you, and permit me to entreat your aid on the occa≈øion.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Colonel Lewis, D. Q. M. G. dated Albany, February 7, 1777.
div.p: BESIDES the logs drawing to the mill at Che≈øhire's, it will be nece≈ø≈øary to order three hundred oak logs, from twenty feet and upwards, to be drawn to Mr. Wyng's mills, and to be ≈øawed into oak plank for the bottoms of ve≈ø≈øels. You will therefore take mea≈øures to have them brought there without delay.

It is of much importance that I ≈øhould be fully informed of every article in your department at Ticonderoga, and at every other po≈øt, place, mill or landing in this department. You will therefore furni≈øh me with a compleat return, with all po≈ø≈øible di≈øpatch. I am, &c.

div.head: Extract of Orders to Colonel Elmore, commanding at Fort Schuyler, dated Albany, February 7, 1777.
div.p: YOU will be plea≈øed to furni≈øh Mr. Deane with ≈ønow-≈øhoes, provi≈øion, and ≈øuch other articles as he may require for four or five Indians, who are going on a particular ≈øervice.

You will al≈øo order the Commi≈ø≈øary at your po≈øt to deliver one ration and an half of provi≈øion to Mr. Spencer at Oneida; and when his wife arrives there, you will order three rations per day to be delivered to him. I am, &c.

div.head: Extract of a letter to Congre≈øs, dated Albany, February 8, 1777.
div.p: FOUR or five tru≈øty Oneida Indians are ≈øent into Canada. They will give the Caghnawagas of Canada ≈øuch accounts, as I am in hopes will, in a great mea≈øure, prevent them from taking a very active part again≈øt us in the en≈øuing campaign.

I wi≈øh we could have po≈øitively a≈ø≈øured them that peace had been concluded between us and the Cherokees, &c. but we had only news-paper information. If it is really ≈øo, I wi≈øh to be advi≈øed of it the ≈øoone≈øt po≈ø≈øible.

Captain Marqui≈øie has delivered me a plan for a fort on Mount Independence, which I have given Colonel Wood to deliver to you; to whom I have al≈øo delivered a box, containing your mu≈øical in≈øtruments, which I wi≈øh ≈øafe to hand.

I very much fear that the ≈øtock of provi≈øions Congre≈øs has ordered to be laid in in this department, will not be procured in time to be conveyed to Fort George and Fort Ann in the cour≈øe of the winter, and if it is not, I am almo≈øt certain that we ≈øhall not be able to ≈øend on any con≈øiderable quantity until towards the latter end of May.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Colonel Lewis, D. Q. M. G. dated Albany, February 12, 1777.
div.p: A SNOW has happily fallen, which will greatly facilitate the tran≈øportation of the various articles that ought to be ≈øent to Fort George and Che≈øhire's, for the rea≈øons mentioned in my former orders; but as the winter ≈øea≈øon is ≈øo far advanced, that we have no rea≈øon to expect the ≈øledding will la≈øt much longer, I mu≈øt again entreat you to lo≈øe no time. The cannon from Sali≈øbury mu≈øt claim your fir≈øt attention. All the entrenching tools already made ≈øhould be forwarded without delay. Whatever provi≈øions the Deputy Commi≈ø≈øary General may have in ≈øtore here, or el≈øewhere, ≈øhould be immediately ≈øent on, as al≈øo the oars, ≈øcoops, and other uten≈øils for the batteaus on the Lakes. The forage which will be wanted ≈øhould be ≈øtored as I have directed. Carpenters mu≈øt, without delay, be ≈øent up to repair the batteaus on both Lakes and at Skeen≈øborough, together with pitch, oakum, and every nece≈ø≈øary for the purpo≈øe. The cordage for the ve≈ø≈øels to be built at Fort George ≈øhould al≈øo be there. In ≈øhort, every article in your department, that can be procured, ≈øhould be ≈øent up without the lea≈øt delay; for be≈øides the extra expence of tran≈øporting the≈øe articles in ≈øpring, when the roads are bad, you will, I fear, not be able to accompli≈øh it with all the wheel carriages you will then be able to procure, and the probable con≈øequences will be, that our army at Ticonderoga will be obliged to leave it, for want of the nece≈ø≈øary ≈øupplies. You are therefore bound, by every con≈øideration, to leave nothing undone a moment, which it is po≈ø≈øible for you to do, that we may not experience all the evils which would con≈øequently en≈øue from an evacuation of Ticonderoga.

Va≈øt quantities of boards and timber will, in all probability, be wanted, as well for the army in this quarter, as for that which may be ≈øtationed in the ≈øouthern parts of this State. Provi≈øion ≈øhould therefore be made to procure them. And as the proprietors of mills find it impo≈ø≈øible to procure workmen to cut and draw logs, ≈øuch of the fifteen companies of batteaumen and labourers now rai≈øing, and that can be fir≈øt got ready, ≈øhould be employed in cutting timber, and ≈øleds procured to draw it to the mills.

The roads between this and Fort Edward, and from thence to Fort George and Che≈øhire's, al≈øo claim your early and ≈øerious attention, and timber ≈øhould be drawn for cau≈øewaying where it is nece≈ø≈øary, and for erecting bridges where they may be wanted. To depend upon cro≈ø≈øing Hud≈øon's river at the two ferries, McNeal's and Jones's, with what ≈øcows are now there, is too precarious. At each place two good ≈øcows mu≈øt therefore be immediately con≈øtructed.

In ≈øhort, all that I have at any time ordered that you ≈øhould ≈øend up, purcha≈øe or cau≈øe to be made, ought to be done with the utmo≈øt di≈øpatch; for, if it is not, the bu≈øine≈øs that will croud upon you ≈øo va≈øtly when the campaign opens will involve you in inextricable difficulties.
A quantity of rum ≈øhould be purcha≈øed by you for the artificers employed in your department, that you may not labour under difficulties on that account.
I entreat you to pay the clo≈øe≈øt attention to every part of your department, that the public may reap the advantage of your exertions, and you the honour thereof.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Eli≈øha Avery, E≈øq Deputy Commi≈ø≈øary General, dated Albany, February 12, 1777.
div.p: AS no time is to be lo≈øt in forwarding the provi≈øions that are ordered to be laid in at Fort George, Che≈øhire's, Skeen≈øborough and Ticonderoga, you will from time to time advi≈øe the Deputy Quarter Ma≈øter General of the quantities you have on hand, that he may procure carriages to forward it.

I was in hopes to have had a return of what is laid in at Bennington, and other places to the ea≈øtward. Pray let me have it without delay, and make me a weekly return of whatever you have in hand, and where, that I may know what pro≈øpect there is of ≈øupplying the army in the next campaign. I am, &c.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Colonel Baldwin, Chief Engineer, dated Albany, February 13, 1777.
div.p:
THE Honourable Continental Congre≈øs, by a re≈øolution of the 28th December la≈øt, have ordered, That a fort be con≈øtructed on Mount Independence; that the navigation of the Lake, near that place, be ob≈øtructed by ca≈ø≈øoons, to be ≈øunk in the water at ≈ømall di≈øtances from one another, and joined together by ≈øtring pieces, ≈øo as at the ≈øame time to ≈øerve for a bridge between the fortifications on the ea≈øt and we≈øt
≈øides; that to prevent the enemy from drawing their ≈ømall craft over land beyond Three Mile Point into Lake George, the pa≈ø≈øage of that Lake be al≈øo ob≈øtructed in like manner by ca≈ø≈øoons, from i≈øland to i≈øland, in the Narrows, if practicable, or by floating batteries; that Fort Stanwix be ≈øtrengthened, and other fortifications be made, at proper places, near the Mohawk River; and that General Schuyler, the commanding officer of the Northern Department, execute the≈øe works this winter, and that the commanding officer of artillery, Chief Engineer, Quarter Ma≈øter General and Commi≈ø≈øary General, provide and perform whatever things in their re≈øpective departments are nece≈ø≈øary, or may contribute to the accompli≈øhment thereof; that there be a general ho≈øpital erected at Mount Independence.

In order, therefore, to fulfil the intentions of Congre≈øs, you are immediately to proceed to Lake George, to examine if it is practicable to ≈øunk ca≈ø≈øoons in the Narrows in the manner directed; and if you find it ≈øo, to report the ≈øame to me, and immediately to order one or more of your Sub-Engineers to execute the work. If it is not practicable, you will report to me, by letter, the rea≈øons why, together with the depth of the water, and the di≈øtance from ≈øhore to ≈øhore, and from i≈øland to i≈øland. The report to be accompanied with a ≈øketch of the i≈ølands.

You are then to proceed to Ticonderoga, and, as I conceive the ob≈øtructions of the Lake will be much ea≈øier and cheaper executed while the Lake continues frozen than at any other time, you will fir≈øt execute that work. The ca≈ø≈øoons ≈øhould be ≈øo far above water, as that the bridge may not be under water when the Lake is at the highe≈øt, and to prevent batteaus from pa≈ø≈øing underneath, when the Lake is at the lowe≈øt, a boom ought to be laid on the water on each ≈øide of the bridge.

It will be nece≈ø≈øary, the ≈øoone≈øt you po≈ø≈øibly can, to prepare what timber and other materials may be wanting for the con≈øtruction of the fort on Mount Independence, and to furni≈øh me with an actual and accurate ≈øurvey of Mount Independence, and a plan of the fort you may judge ≈øhould be built on it.

You are al≈øo to lo≈øe no time in preparing and collecting the materials for a ho≈øpital, ≈øufficiently large to contain ≈øix hundred ≈øick, be≈øides the nece≈ø≈øary apartments for the Director, and the other officers of the ho≈øpital.

You will al≈øo immediately ≈øend an engineer to examine and report the ≈øtate of Fort Stanwix, and what works ought to be con≈øtructed there, and on his return to ≈øix on one or more proper places on this ≈øide Fort Stanwix, to erect fortifications, to prevent the enemy from coming down the river in batteaus, in ca≈øe they ≈øhould be able to po≈ø≈øe≈øs them≈øelves of Fort Stanwix, or leave it in their rear.

Whatever carriages you may want for drawing timber for the works on Lake George, and at Ticonderoga and Mount Independence, you are to apply to Colonel Lewis, Deputy Quarter-Ma≈øter General, for, who will have my orders to furni≈øh you therewith.

The armourers tools, that are now at Ticonderoga, you will immediately ≈øend to Colonel Lewis, to be delivered to ≈øuch per≈øon as you may direct to ≈øuperintend the armoury here, and leave orders for the armourers to repair all the arms in this place, before they proceed to Ticonderoga.

Early provi≈øion is to be made, to have a ≈øufficiency of battery carriages for the cannon that may be ≈øent up, and for ≈øuch as may be wanted on board any ve≈ø≈øels to be con≈øtructed. In ≈øhort, you will u≈øe your be≈øt endeavours to have every thing put in the be≈øt order, and what is to be executed done with the utmo≈øt expedition.
Carpenters always require clo≈øe attention, and to be pu≈øhed to their duty; you will therefore give ≈øtrict orders to all your officers to keep them clo≈øely to work.

You will probably be able to procure ≈øoldiers, who can work with the whip-≈øaw. You ≈øhould therefore procure as many as you po≈ø≈øibly can, and immediately on your arrival at Ticonderoga apply for all the ≈øawyers in any of the corps there, and ≈øet them to work. It will be be≈øt to agree by the foot, becau≈øe it will be cheape≈øt, and that you will get more work done.

A hou≈øe to boil ≈øoap and make candles in is much wanted at Mount Independence. You will therefore con≈øtruct one, and al≈øo a bake-hou≈øe, as ≈øoon as you can, and repair the provi≈øion ≈øtores, that the public may not ≈øu≈øtain ≈øo great a lo≈øs as formerly by damaged provi≈øions.

div.head: Extract of Orders to Colonel Lewis, dated Albany, February 13, 1777.
div.p: THE blocks for the ve≈ø≈øels to be con≈øtructed on Lake Champlain you will give immediate orders for making. They may probably be procured here; if not, write to the ≈øuperintendants for building the frigates at Poukeep≈øie to get them ready again≈øt the river opens.

Pray do not fail to furni≈øh me with the return I have ≈øo long ago reque≈øted, of whatever articles, ve≈ø≈øels, carriages, &c. are now in your department, and the condition they are in, that we may know what is to be done. If your Deputies neglect giving you the nece≈ø≈øary information, di≈ømi≈øs them, and appoint others that will do their duty.

Colonel Baldwin, the Chief Engineer, is directed to carry on very con≈øiderable works on Lake George and at Ticonderoga. You are to furni≈øh him with as many carriages as he may want, which I believe will be con≈øiderable. Each carriage ≈øhould carry twenty days provi≈øions. Among≈øt the carriages ≈øhould be ten ≈øleds, drawn by oxen.

The Deputy Commi≈ø≈øary General has returned three hundred barrels of flour at Skeen≈øborough; the≈øe mu≈øt be immediately forwarded to Ticonderoga; al≈øo one hundred and eighty barrels of beef, which are at Fort George, as ≈øoon as Lake George is pa≈ø≈øable, if it is not ≈øo already.

He al≈øo informs me that there are about one thou≈øand barrels of beef and pork at Bennington and Lane≈øborough. This mu≈øt al≈øo be immediately forwarded to either Che≈øhire's or Skeen≈øborough, which ever may be mo≈øt convenient.

div.head: Copy of a letter to Governor Trumbull, dated Albany, February 14, 1777.
div.p:
I FIND my≈øelf under the nece≈ø≈øity of again troubling your Honour on the ≈øubject of the carpenters. Such a variety of work is to be done in this department, that I fear, if we do not begin upon the ve≈ø≈øels to be con≈øtructed on Lake George ≈øooner than I at fir≈øt intended, that the ≈øervice will probably ≈øuffer. Permit me therefore to entreat you to reque≈øt Captain Woolcot, and the per≈øons to whom you have given the other warrant,
to ha≈øten the rai≈øing of their companies, and to march them to this place the ≈øoone≈øt po≈ø≈øible. They will have very comfortable quarters at Fort George.

div.head: Extract of a letter to Congre≈øs, dated Albany, February 24, 1777.
div.p: I HAVE ordered ≈øuch of the batteaumen as are already rai≈øed and mu≈øtered to cut timber for the different public works. Some thou≈øands of logs are already brought to the public's mills at Che≈øhire's. Parties are gone and going to bring timber to the mill at Skeen≈øborough, and to the other mills in the vicinity of Fort George, to mine and others on Hud≈øon's river. The expence of procuring this article in ≈øummer, on account of the difficulty of drawing the timber out of the ≈øwamp, is ≈øo exceedingly great, that I hope a very con≈øiderable ≈øaving will ari≈øe to the public.

div.head: Copy of a letter to Brigadier General Bailey, dated Albany, March 4, 1777.
div.p: YOUR favour of the 27th ult. by Captain Young, was delivered me la≈øt evening.

From information which Colonel Bedel has tran≈ømitted me, it appears prudent that none of the militia from Glouce≈øter and Cumberland ≈øhould be called out of that county. You will therefore plea≈øe to countermand your orders to ≈øuch as are directed to march, and I ≈øhall immediately give orders that ≈øuch as are or may arrive at Ticonderoga be immediately di≈ømi≈ø≈øed.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Colonel Lewis, dated Albany, March 8, 1777.

I mu≈øt therefore again entreat you to attend to this very important matter. I am, &c.

div.head: Copy of a letter to Brigadier General Knox, dated Albany, March 10, 1777.
div.p: MAJOR Stevens delivered me, in the beginning of December, an e≈øtimate of what would be wanted in the artillery department. Part of the articles he has procured, and I have now ≈øent him to wait on you for what is ≈øtill deficient, his Excellency General Wa≈øhington having directed that my application for ordnance and ordnance ≈øtores ≈øhould be made to you. I ≈øhall, be≈øides the articles the Major may mentions, ≈øtand in need of forty ≈øhip-guns, ten of which to carry nine pound ball, fifteen carrying ≈øix pound ball, and as many carrying four pound ball, with carriages, cartridges, ≈øhot, and every nece≈ø≈øary belonging to them. The≈øe to be ≈øent to this place or Fort George, where I wi≈øh to have them by the la≈øt of April at farthe≈øt.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Colonel Baldwin, dated Albany, March 10, 1777.
div.p: NOT a ≈øingle armourer is yet arrived at this place; and as all our dependence was placed on tho≈øe you were to procure, I am greatly apprehen≈øive of the con≈øequence, if they ≈øhould not ≈øoon arrive. Pray inform me immediately of the names of the over≈øeers, and their places of abode, that I may di≈øpatch an expre≈øs for them. I hope the works you have in hand are in good forwardne≈øs. Much is to be done, and exertions required.
