For which purpo≈øe you mu≈øt appoint an able clerk of the checque, who is to keep regular accounts of every per≈øon's name, and of every day they are employed.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Major Stevens of the Artillery, dated Albany, March 10, 1777.
div.p: YOU will immediately proceed to Brigadier General Knox, and apply to him for whatever may be ≈øtill deficient of the articles mentioned in the e≈øtimate you delivered me. You will al≈øo make him a return of ≈øuch other nece≈ø≈øaries as the Artillery Department may ≈øtand in need of, and entreat that they may be forwarded without delay, by the mo≈øt convenient route, to Ticonderoga.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Colonel Lewis, dated Albany, March 17, 1777.
div.p:
AS the ice has now left Hud≈øon's river, you will forward the cannon, and whatever military ≈øtores are now here, as fa≈øt as po≈ø≈øible to Fort George, to be conveyed to Ticonderoga as ≈øoon as Lake George ≈øhall be navigable.
If the batteaus at that place are not already repaired, no time ≈øhould be lo≈øt in doing it. The ≈øchooner there ≈øhould al≈øo be overhauled, and put into repair, without delay.

The ≈øhip carpenters now moving up to Fort George will require a number of carriages, to draw in the timber for the ve≈ø≈øels they are to build. The≈øe carriages you will furni≈øh immediately, and ≈øend one of your a≈ø≈øi≈øtants to ≈øuperintend the works at that place. The ho≈øpital there will al≈øo require repairs, and ≈øhould be done immediately. Two black≈ømiths mu≈øt be kept at work there, and a quantity of iron ≈øent up. If the ≈øhip nails are not already forwarded, ≈øend them on without lo≈øs of time. A company of carpenters, to con≈øi≈øt of an over≈øeer and twenty men, mu≈øt be engaged, and ≈øent without delay to Fort Stanwix. Captain Marqui≈øie, the Engineer, who is at Schenectady, will take charge of them.

Fort George will probably be navigable by the fir≈øt week in April. About that time therefore the working cattle, de≈øigned for Ticonderoga and the Carrying-place, ≈øhould be at Fort George, to be tran≈øported without delay.
All the working cattle for the communication between this and Fort George and Fort Ann ≈øhould al≈øo be there about the fir≈øt of April.
Nails, pitch or tar, and oakum for the batteaus building at Saratoga, mu≈øt be ≈øent on immediately.

Three ploughs, and as many harrows, with the nece≈ø≈øary apparel, mu≈øt be ≈øent to Ticonderoga, under the care of a tru≈øty per≈øon, who under≈øtands farming and gardening, in order to prepare the earth for rai≈øing turnips and other vegetables for the u≈øe of the army. You will give orders to ≈øupply them with working cattle and men, and direct your a≈ø≈øi≈øtants to procure a piece of land for the purpo≈øe. As ≈øoon as the ice has left Wood Creek, you are to cau≈øe it to be cleared from the old timber which ob≈øtructs its navigation.
The ≈øaw-mills at Wyng's and Che≈øhire's, Skeen≈øborough and Ticonderoga, mu≈øt be immediately ≈øet to work.
Thirty of the batteaus building at Saratoga mu≈øt be ≈øent to Wood Creek, to be employed between Fort Ann and Skeen≈øborough.
Do not forget the ferry ≈øcows I formerly ordered to be con≈øtructed, nor the repairs to the roads.

At Half-Moon, Stillwater, M'Larin's, Fort Miller, Fort Edward and Che≈øhire's, turning cranes ≈øhould be erected, to load and unload the batteaus with. They are a tri≈øting expence, and will greatly pre≈øerve the batteaus, which ≈øu≈øtain more damage by loading and unloading than by any other means whatever.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Captain Marqui≈øie, A≈ø≈øi≈øtant Engineer, dated Head-Quarters, Albany, March 18, 1777.
div.p: YOU will call on the A≈ø≈øi≈øtant Deputy Quarter Ma≈øter General at Schenectady, and ≈øupply your≈øelf with what intrenching tools and other nece≈ø≈øaries you will need for altering and ≈øtrengthening Fort Schuyler. He will al≈øo furni≈øh you with a company of carpenters, and provide batteaus to carry you, them, and ≈øuch articles as you may want, to that fortre≈øs. On your arrival there, you will apply to the commanding officer for ≈øuch a≈ø≈øi≈øtance as you may need, who will have my orders to afford you all in his power. You will make the alterations agreeable to the plan you have laid before me, and to guard as much as po≈ø≈øible again≈øt any misfortunes that might be occa≈øioned by an attack before the alterations are compleat, you will leave as much of the pre≈øent work ≈øtanding, whil≈øt the other is going on, as po≈ø≈øible, that the garri≈øon may be covered. Perhaps it will be be≈øt to begin with one ba≈øtion and the adjacent curtains, and to compleat as much of them as po≈ø≈øible before another is begun.
Whatever articles you may from time to time nece≈ø≈øarily require, you will apply to Henry Glen‚ñ™ A≈ø≈øi≈øtant Deputy Quarter Ma≈øter General at Schenectady, for.

Fortifications are at all times expen≈øive; they become more ≈øo, when the artificers are ≈øuffered to while away their time. Your carpenters mu≈øt therefore begin to work at day-light, and work until ≈øun-≈øet, allowing an hour for breakfa≈øt, and an hour and a half for dinner. No ≈øitting down to ≈ømoak and drink at eleven o'clock, or at any other time, except that at meals. In very hot weather, two hours may be allowed at dinner.

Appoint ≈øome tru≈øty non-commi≈ø≈øioned officer as ma≈øter of the checque, and in≈øtruct him particularly in his duty. Soldiers or women mu≈øt be got, to cook for the carpenters, and allowed moderate wages.
Inform me repeatedly how your work advances, and of what difficulties, if any, you meet with, that I may take mea≈øures to obviate them.
I have the fulle≈øt confidence that you will make u≈øe of every exertion to forward the work, and promote the ≈øervice.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Commodore Wynkeep, dated Albany, March 24, 1777.
div.p: YOU will repair to Fort George without delay, and there, in conjunction with Captain Douw, A≈ø≈øi≈øtant Deputy Quarter Ma≈øter General, employ the carpenters in con≈øtructing two ≈øtrong ≈øchooners, of ≈øixty feet keel and twenty feet beam. They ≈øhould be ≈øo con≈øtructed as not to draw above ≈øix feet water, when they have all their cannon and ≈øtores on board; and as I conceive that they will be more ≈øerviceable in proportion as their guns lay near the water, I would have you give them the lea≈øt height po≈ø≈øible. Be≈øides, three other ve≈ø≈øels are to be built without decks. The≈øe ≈øhould be ≈øo contrived, as to row fa≈øt, and to carry a cannon of twelve pound ≈øhot in the bow, and as many on each ≈øide as po≈ø≈øible. Whatever articles you may want, and that are not to be had at Fort George, you will make timely application for to Colonel Lewis, Deputy Quarter Ma≈øter General, that no time may be lo≈øt in procuring what may be wanted. You will examine the ≈øtores at that place, and ≈øee what is there, and write to Ticonderoga to know what rigging and anchors can be ≈øpared from thence, and cau≈øe them to be brought to Fort George as ≈øoon as the Lake opens.

div.head: Extract of Orders to Colonel Van Schuick, dated Albany, March 25, 1777.
div.p: I PROPOSE early to-morrow to ≈øet out on a journey to Philadelphia. You, as elde≈øt officer, will con≈øequently command until my return, or the arrival of an officer of elder or ≈øuperior rank. It is impo≈ø≈øible to particularize the variety of affairs that will claim your attention. I ≈øhall therefore only mention ≈øuch as occur to me at pre≈øent.

Colonel Wayne, and Lieutenant Colonel Van Dyck, are informed that the command devolves on you, and they have my orders to addre≈øs you on whatever ≈øubject they may have occa≈øion to write. It is impo≈ø≈øible to fore≈øee what demands they may make, as they mu≈øt ari≈øe from exigencies that may happen. No in≈øtructions can therefore be given on that head, other than the general one, to do in every ca≈øe what you ≈øhall judge mo≈øt conducive to promote the ≈øervice.

As the late ho≈øtilities committed by the enemy and their ≈øavages has already greatly alarmed the country, and prevents people from giving that a≈ø≈øi≈øtance with their carriages which the public ≈øtands ≈øo much in need of, I have ordered reinforcements to Saratoga, Fort Edward and Fort George, that all carriages may have convoys, and the workmen at Fort George be covered by ≈øtrong parties, and the magazines at tho≈øe places pro ‚Ä¢ ected and ≈øecured. You will therefore give your orders accordingly. The reinforcements are of the troops from the Ea≈øtern States; and the di≈øpo≈øition of your regiment and tho≈øe troops I wi≈øh to be as follows: One hundred rank and file, and a ≈øufficient number of officers, at Saratoga, who are to mount, be≈øides the guards at the barracks, a ≈øerjeant's guard at my hou≈øe, with centinels at the mills and ≈øtore-hou≈øe, both of which contain great quantities of valuable public ≈øtores; fifty, with like officers, at Fort Edward, and one hundred at this place; tho≈øe at Fort Edward will be joined by two companies of the troops from the ea≈øtward; the remainder of your regiment at Fort George, to which I have al≈øo ordered three companies of the Ea≈øtern corps.

You will order Living≈øton's to march to John's-Town and Fort Dayton, and Gan≈øevoort's to Fort Schuyler, to relieve tho≈øe garri≈øons, the pre≈øent commanding officers whereof are to deliver copies of their in≈øtructions to the officers commanding the re≈øpective reliefs. You will particularly charge the officers to be very attentive and vigilant. Tho≈øe at Fort Edward and Saratoga to keep ≈ømall ≈øcouting parties con≈øtantly out to the we≈øtward. Colonel Wayne, and Lieutenant Colonel Van Dyck, have my orders on this head with re≈øpect to their commands.

A quantity of powder is arrived at King≈øton, and is daily expected here, one ton whereof is to be left here, and the remainder to be forwarded to Fort George, where it is to remain until occa≈øion ≈øhall require it to be ≈øent on to Ticonderoga. A ≈øtrong e≈øcort mu≈øt attend this powder in all its route. The cannon that are ≈øtill here are to be forwarded to Ticonderoga, except tho≈øe carrying ≈øix pound ball and under, which are to be left at Fort George.
Every other kind of ≈øtore that may be here, or may arrive, is to be ≈øent on, except ≈øuch cloathing as may be nece≈ø≈øary for the troops coming in here.
You will plea≈øe to give orders for furni≈øhing Mr. Douw with ≈øuch articles out of the public ≈øtores, as he may apply to you for, for the u≈øe of the Indians.

You will order a court to apprai≈øe all the uninvoiced articles in the Commi≈ø≈øary of Cloathing's ≈øtore; a copy of ≈øuch apprai≈øement, ≈øigned by the Pre≈øident, to be kept by you, and another to be delivered to the Commi≈ø≈øary.
Such of Colonel Ha ‚Ä¢ on's regiment as may be in this department are to be ≈øent down to General Wa≈øhington, as ≈øoon as relieved from the po≈øts they now garri≈øon.
The Court adjourn till to-morrow, nine o'clock.

div.head: OCTOBER 2d.
div.p: THE Court met according to adjournment.
Major General Schuyler proceeds in his Defence, as follows:

‚ÄîSUCH were the preparations for this campaign, made by me prior to the 26th day of March, 1777, when I left Albany, ≈øoon after which General Gates took the command, and I tru≈øt they were ≈øuch as, at lea≈øt, exclude any imputation of want of vigilance or care. The Court will be plea≈øed to ob≈øerve, that in my ≈øeveral orders I de≈øcended to minutiae, in a manner not u≈øual for general officers, and which nothing but the mo≈øt ardent zeal for the ≈øervice could have prompted.
The third period extends from the time I re≈øumed the command to the evacuation of Ticonderoga.

On the fourth day of June, 1777, I again re≈øumed the command of the department, and I offer the following letters and orders as evidence of the manner in which I continued to provide for the exigencies of the en≈øuing campaign, and for the general defence of the whole department.
I arrived at Albany on the third day of June, and the next day wrote the following letter to Major General Gates.

body.p: INCLOSE you copy of a re≈øolution of the Honourable Continental Congre≈øs, by which they have again conferred on me the honour of commanding the army in the Northern Department.

You will plea≈øe to furni≈øh me with copies of ≈øuch orders and in≈øtructions as you may have given to the commanding officers at Ticonderoga, and the other po≈øts in the department, and ≈øuch others as you may think it nece≈ø≈øary I ≈øhould be advi≈øed of.
Plea≈øe al≈øo to furni≈øh me with copies of your la≈øt return of the troops in this department.

I wi≈øh to ≈øee you at an early hour, to profit by the intelligence you have received, by the ob≈øervations you may have made, and to con≈øult with you on the mo≈øt eligible mode of carrying into execution the intention, of our ≈øuperiors. I am, &c.

div.p: To this letter I received no written an≈øwer. General Gates waited on me to conver≈øe with me, and delivered me a letter he had received from General Poor, and a return of the troops then at Ticonderoga, and ≈øome other papers.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Colonel Lewis, D. Q. M. G. dated Albany, June 5, 1777.
div.p:
YOU will, without delay, ≈øend to all your A≈ø≈øi≈øtants, at the re≈øpective forts, po≈øts and places, in the Northern Department, to make immediate and exact returns of every article under charge, belonging to your
department. You will particularly charge them to note the number and condition of the batteaus, and the implements belonging to them.

You will give the mo≈øt pointed orders, that no delay be made in making the≈øe returns; and, to avoid confu≈øion, you will furni≈øh each of your A≈ø≈øi≈øtants with a blank form of a return, with directions to fill it up.

You will furni≈øh each of your A≈ø≈øi≈øtants with a hor≈øe, and allow forage therefor. If any are ≈øtationed at a po≈øt where there is no magazine, they mu≈øt find it, and you will pay for it. Two good hor≈øes, with ≈øaddles and bridles, mu≈øt be kept here, two at Saratoga, and two at Fort George, for the purpo≈øe of carrying di≈øpatches.

The commanding officers at the≈øe po≈øts, when they have occa≈øion to ≈øend di≈øpatches, to make written applications to you, or your a≈ø≈øi≈øtants, for the hor≈øes. You will give directions that none of the hor≈øes be turned to gra≈øs, and that they be well fed.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Eli≈øha Avery, E≈øq D. C. G. dated Albany, June 4, 1777.
div.p: YOU will plea≈øe immediately to make me a return of the provi≈øions in this department, ≈øpecifying the ≈øeveral ≈øorts, po≈øts, places and magazines, in which it is ≈øtored, the quantity in and at each, and di≈øtingui≈øhing the ≈øalted meat from the fre≈øh, and noting what has been forwarded to Skeen≈øborough, Fort George, and the intermediate po≈øts, ≈øince the 26th day of March la≈øt.

div.head: Copy of a letter to General St. Clair, dated June 5, 1777.
div.p: YOU will plea≈øe to repair to Ticonderoga with all convenient ≈øpeed, and take the command of the troops at that place.

As the whole of our force in the Northern Department, if collected at Ticonderoga, would not be capable of properly meaning the exten≈øive works on both ≈øides of the Lake, and as Mount Independence is by much the mo≈øt defen≈øible, and may be made a po≈øt capable of ≈øu≈øtaining a long and vigorous ≈øiege, it is my intention that your fir≈øt care ≈øhould be to be≈øtow the utmo≈øt attention to fortifying the Mount. You will therefore plea≈øe, immediately on your arrival, to give directions for erecting the nece≈ø≈øary fortifications, and employ all the troops that can be ≈øpared from other duty and nece≈ø≈øary works in that bu≈øine≈øs. If the ob≈øtruction between the French redoubt and Mount Independence is not compleated, that work will al≈øo claim your immediate attention, and I wi≈øh that ≈øtrong piles ≈øhould be drove in the intervals between every ca≈ø≈øoon, and others in the front of each ca≈ø≈øoon, and if po≈ø≈øible a line of pickets drove acro≈øs the channel, ≈øo far below Mount Independence, as that the cannon from thence may render it impo≈ø≈øible for the enemy's ve≈ø≈øels to lay there, or be employed in removing the ob≈øtructions. This ≈øeems to be work in the execution of which no time ≈øhould be lo≈øt, as it may, by preventing the enemy's ≈øhips from pa≈ø≈øing, enable us to keep up the communication with our ve≈ø≈øels, if the Mount ≈øhould be inve≈øted.
I wi≈øh you to keep ≈øcouting parties con≈øtantly out on both ≈øides of the Lake. That on the we≈øt ≈øhould go as far as the road by which the Tories la≈øt fall marched to Crown-Point.

Be ≈øo good as to order returns to be made immediately by the Chief Engineer, Commanding Officer of Artillery, Commi≈ø≈øary of Provi≈øions, and Clothier, of every article in their re≈øpective departments, and of what is wanting in each, that the deficiency may be procured without delay.
Inclo≈øe you a credit on the military che≈øt for Ten Thou≈øand Dollars, to pay any contingent expences that may ari≈øe, and not payable by any of the civil departments.

I am confident that no officer is more deeply impre≈ø≈øed with the nece≈ø≈øity of pre≈øerving the health of the men than you, and I doubt not but you will be≈øtow much of your attention on ≈øo capital a matter. Tents are arrived here, and orders are given to ≈øend up five hundred. If more are wanted, you will plea≈øe to ≈øignify it to me.
You will plea≈øe to ≈øend me a return of the troops at Ticonderoga, as ≈øoon after your arrival as you po≈ø≈øibly can.

You will lay in a magazine of fire wood on Mount Independence, to be pre≈øerved in ca≈øe of a ≈øiege, and to be as ≈øparing of the ≈øalt meat as you po≈ø≈øibly can, con≈øi≈øtent with the health of the men.

As an arrangement of the troops into brigades cannot ≈øo properly be made here as at Ticonderoga, and it being probable that I ≈øhall not be able to repair to that place until towards the end of the month, you will plea≈øe, con≈øulting with the other general officers, to brigade them, putting the militia into one by them≈øelves.
You will give directions that no con≈øiderable quantity of provi≈øion, or other military ≈øtores, are at any time left on the carrying place at the north end of Lake George.

As the health of the troops is very much injured by an improper mode of dre≈ø≈øing their victuals, I wi≈øh you to order an officer of every company daily to ≈øuperintend that bu≈øine≈øs; and as I conceive it would be for the benefit of the troops to be furni≈øhed with kettles ≈øufficiently large to cook for a whole company, I have ordered the Deputy Quarter Ma≈øter General to ≈øend twenty to Ticonderoga for that purpo≈øe.
Plea≈øe to cau≈øe a ≈øurvey to be made of the ≈øalted meat. I apprehend much of it will require to be repacked and well brined.
I ≈øhall be extremely happy frequently to be favoured with a line from you.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Colonel Lewis, D. Q. M. G. dated Head-Quarters, Albany, June 6, 1777.
div.p: BY the Deputy Commi≈ø≈øary General's return, I find there is a con≈øiderable quantity of flour, 213 barrels of pork, 582 barrels of beef, and near 600 bu≈øhels of pea≈øe, at Fort George. You will immediately cau≈øe the ≈øame to be conveyed to Ticonderoga, except 100 barrels of flour, 50 barrels of pork, 50 barrels of beef, and 50 bu≈øhels of pea≈øe. You will ≈øend 32 of the ≈ømall batteaus into Lake George, 30 of which to be conveyed into Lake Champlain, from thence into Wood Creek. The large batteaus now in Wood Creek to be carried below the Falls, and well ≈øecured. The quantity of provi≈øion at Fort Schuyler is very inadequate. You will therefore take mea≈øures, without delay, to convey to that garri≈øon whatever ≈øupply the Deputy Commi≈ø≈øary General can furni≈øh, and you will call upon him to know what that is.

If you have not already you will immediately procure four fi≈øhing nets, one to be ≈øent to Fort George, and three to Ticonderoga. Five hundred of the tents which arrived ye≈øterday to be immediately ≈øent to Ticonderoga. You will al≈øo purcha≈øe twenty pot-a≈øh kettles, to be ≈øent to Ticonderoga. A number of bricks will be wanted at Ticonderoga, Fort George and Saratoga; you will therefore take mea≈øures, the ≈øoone≈øt po≈ø≈øible, to get them made. Fort Edward may be ≈øupplied with this article from Fort George in returning carriages. Skeen≈øborough and Fort Ann may be ≈øupplied in returning batteaus from Ticonderoga.
You will al≈øo give directions for burning lime at Ticonderoga, Fort George and Saratoga, for the u≈øe of the works there, and the places mentioned in the preceding paragraph.
If no bricks are to be purcha≈øed in this place, you will al≈øo cau≈øe fifty thou≈øand to be made here, and lay in a quantity of lime, which may be procured in the vicinity of Poukeep ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e.

div.head: Extracts of a letter to Congre≈øs, dated Albany, June 8, 1777.
div.p: I DO my≈øelf the honour to advi≈øe you that I arrived here on Tue≈øday, the third in≈øtant, and found an account, which I received on my way up, that the enemy were approaching Ticonderoga, to be without foundation.

Inclo≈øe you, Sir, a return of the troops at Ticonderoga and this place. As ≈øoon as I procure tho≈øe from the other po≈øts I ≈øhall make out a general return, and do my≈øelf the honour to tran≈ømit copies to you and his Excellency General Wa≈øhington.

You will perceive by the return of the Commi≈ø≈øary of Provi≈øions, which I al≈øo inclo≈øe, that only 337 barrels of the meat kind have been forwarded to Ticonderoga ≈øince the 26th of March, and no fre≈øh beef, ≈øo that the ≈øtock of ≈øalted provi≈øions ≈øince that time is con≈øiderably dimini≈øhed, nor is there any con≈øiderable quantity provided in the country. I have therefore directed the Commi≈ø≈øary to forward an immediate ≈øupply of fre≈øh beef, that as much of the ≈øalted beef and pork may be ≈øaved as po≈ø≈øible, in order to have a ≈øtock on hand, in ca≈øe the enemy ≈øhould be able ≈øo to interrupt the communication as to prevent cattle being ≈øent on.

Inclo≈øe you copy of the in≈øtructions I have given General St. Clair. I have directed that Mount Independence ≈øhould be the primary object of attention. 1st. Becau≈øe, if even the lines on the we≈øt ≈øide ≈øhould be perfectly compleated, it will not be in our power to man them properly with the whole force de≈øtined for this department, if it could be all collected at Ticonderoga, which it cannot, for the ≈øeveral po≈øts on the Mohawk river, and tho≈øe on the communication between this and Ticonderoga, will take at lea≈øt two thou≈øand men. I have in view the drawing part of the army to this ≈øide of the Lake.

2dly. Becau≈øe I think it rather imprudent that the greater part of our army ≈øhould occupy a po≈øt, which if the enemy ≈øhould be able ≈øo to inve≈øt as to cut off the communication with the country on this ≈øide, we might po≈ø≈øibly experience a di≈øa≈øter ≈øimilar to that at Fort Wa≈øhington.
3dly. Becau≈øe I am fully convinced that between two and three thou≈øand men can effectually maintain Mount Independence, and ≈øecure the pa≈øs.
4thly. If the whole army was at Mount Independence, it is po≈ø≈øible that a want of provi≈øion might oblige us to abandon that important po≈øt.

5thly. If the enemy ≈øhould attempt to draw their boats over land into Lake George, from beyond the Three Mile Point, our naval ≈øtrength on Lake George will prevent their progre≈øs; and if it did not, we ≈øhould have a body of troops to oppo≈øe them with.
6thly. Becau≈øe, if Mount Independence ≈øhould be inve≈øted, the militia will readily march when they have an army to join, and the ≈øiege may be rai≈øed.

7thly. Becau≈øe, if they ≈øhould attempt to march a body of troops from Crown Point, leaving Ticonderoga on their left (by the road la≈øt year cut by the tories who joined General Carleton) to interrupt the communication, there will be a force to meet them, and to prevent the evil con≈øequences of ≈øuch a manoeuvre of theirs.

8thly. Becau≈øe, if a ≈øudden irruption ≈øhould be made on the Mohawk river, or from New-York, by Hud≈øon's river, a force will be at hand to face them. Be≈øides the≈øe con≈øiderations, there are oeconomical ones
al≈øo to induce to this di≈øpo≈øition of the army, if it can be done without danger, which I am fully of opinion it may, and will certainly be ≈øo, if General Carleton ≈øent part of his troops from Canada to New-York or el≈øewhere.

I have mentioned the matter to General St. Clair, and although I did not adduce to him all the rea≈øons given above, yet he is in ≈øentiment with me on the ≈øubject. May I be permitted to entreat the direction of Congre≈øs?

Some tru≈øty Indians, with two of the French officers, accompanied by an approved Canadian, who leaves a wi≈øe and numerous family here, are going into Canada, to try to gain ≈øome intelligence of the enemy's ≈øtrength and intentions.

div.head: Extract of a letter to his Excellency General Wa≈øhington, dated Albany, June 9, 1777.

I wi≈øh him particularly to ob≈øerve to the Canada Indians, that a treaty will be held with the Six Nations on the 15th of July next at Albany, and that I invite them al≈øo to come to it, or as many of them as can. div.head: Extracts of a letter to Congre≈øs, dated Saratoga, June 14, 1777.
div.p:
LAST evening I arrived here, on my way to Ticonderoga, and at ≈øix this morning I received a letter from the Committee of Albany, inclo≈øing one from Colonel Harper of the militia, copies whereof, No. 1 and 2, I do my≈øelf the honour to tran≈ømit you.
Copy of a letter from the Committee of Albany to Major General Schuyler.
Albany Committee-Chamber,
June 12, 1777.
SIR,
THE inclo≈øed ju≈øt came to hand, which we ≈øubmit to your con≈øideration. We would ≈øugge≈øt to you the propriety of ≈øending a di≈øcreet per≈øon to Unadilla, in order to be properly informed of the particulars of this affair, as perhaps the accounts of that quarter may be exaggerated. I am, Sir,
Your mo≈øt obedient humble Servant, JOHN BARCLAY, Chairman.
Copy of a letter from the Committee of Albany to General Schuyler, dated June 13, 1777.
SIR,
THE inclo≈øed ju≈øt came to hand. As it contains a fuller repre≈øentation of the affair at Unadilla than you have had, we have taken the liberty to ≈øend it by expre≈øs. We are afraid Brandt will give us much trouble. I am, Sir,
Your mo≈øt humble Servant, JOHN BARCLAY, Chairman.
Copy of a letter from Colonel Harper to the Committee of Sch ‚Ä¢ bary, dated Harpersfield, June 12, 1777.
Gentlemen,
I SENT you an account of the ≈øituation of the people at Unadilla the 10th of this in≈øtant, and have now an opportunity fully to acquaint you of the matter, as Mr. John≈øon of Unadilla has given me a full detail of it, which is as follows: That Jo≈øeph Brandt came to Oui ‚Ä¢ quago, hoi≈øted the Briti≈øh flag, and then proceeded to Unadilla with his party, which con≈øi≈øted of more than one hundred men. Before he made his appearance in Unadilla him≈øelf, he ≈øent one William John≈øon, half brother to Sir John John≈øon, with ≈øeveral other Indians, to acquaint the people that he was coming with his party, and that they ≈øhould not be afraid, as he ≈øaid he would be peaceable as vet. When Brandt arrived with his men, he marched to one McGinnis, who is a noted „Äà‚óä„Äâ , and ≈øent for Mr. John≈øon, the Mini≈øter, and Captain John≈øon, his ≈øon, who went immediately to him. He a≈øked the old gentleman ≈øeveral que≈øtions concerning u≈øing his friends ill, as they were a free people, who an≈øwered that his friends had been u≈øed with all the civility of „Äà‚óä„Äâ people. Brandt replied that he and his party were for the King, and that he did not think proper to fall out for every „Äà‚óä„Äâ ; but as he had a large party, and wanted provi≈øion for them, if the people would let him have it, he would pay for it, letting them know at the ≈øame time that he would have it at any rate; and after getting cattle, ≈øheep and ≈øwine, and other provi≈øions, he told the people that Butler would be along ≈øoon, and pay for what he had taken from them; that he then appeared there in a warlike manner, and intended to bring off his people in ≈øpite of every oppo≈øition; and further ≈øaid, there would be great trouble there ≈øoon. When Brandt and his party were about returning to Onioquago, be de≈øired McGinnis to let the boards he had furni≈øhed them with for c ‚Ä¢ mps remain as they were until he returned, which would be in a few days, in order to bring his friends from the Mohawk river. It is uncertain when he will return, but he is expected every hour. The tories, who have joined him, ≈øay they are not afraid of the American troops now. They have made a road from the Su ‚Ä¢ quehanna to the Delaware, in order, as we ≈øuppo≈øe, that the tories from Katt≈økill and el≈øewhere may join them. Thus, Gentlemen of the Committee, and Commanders of the militia, I „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢ aid the matter before you, and a≈ø≈øure my≈øelf you will do every „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ the de ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nce of the frontiers. When you have peru≈øed this letter, forward it to the Commander in Chief at „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , that ≈øuch mea≈øures may be taken for the ≈øecurity of the poor inhabitants in th ‚Ä¢ ≈øe parts, as may be judged „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ to the public „Äà‚óä„Äâ .
N. B.
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ of Brandt ‚Ä¢ s appearance at Unadilla was the ≈øecond of June, when ‚Ä¢ ll the families that were earne≈øt in the country's „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , to ≈øave their lives and effects, which were apparently in the greate≈øt danger.
JOHN HARPER, Colonel.
Having had ≈øome intimation before I left Albany, that Jo≈øeph Brandt had drove off ≈øome cattle from the we≈øtern frontiers of this State, and threatened the inhabitants, I di≈øpatched a me≈ø≈øage to the ‚Ä¢ neidas on that ≈øubject. I have this day ≈øent them a ≈øecond me≈ø≈øage, couched in ≈øuch firm, but, I hope, prudent terms, that I expect it will have the de≈øired effect, and that we ≈øhall have no farther trouble from that fellow and his a≈ø≈øociates. Le≈øt, however, I ≈øhould be mi≈øtaken in my conjectures, I have ordered Colonel Van Schaick into that quarter with 150 men, to protect the inhabitants, and have directed him in the line of conduct he is to hold, which is to be ≈øuch as not to give umbrage to our Indian allies.

At twelve I received an expre≈øs from General St. Clair, copies of his letters No. 3 and 4, with copy of the letter to General Sullivan No. 5, and of the pa≈øs to Am≈øbury No. 6, I herewith tran≈ømit.

Con≈øidering the exten≈øivene≈øs of our works at Ticonderoga, the ≈ømallne≈øs of the garri≈øon is alarming; but I hope that, by confining our whole attention to Mount Independence, we ≈øhall be able to hold that pa≈øs again≈øt any effort of the enemy.

Though chagrined, I am not di≈øcouraged by the variety of difficulties that pre≈øent them≈øelves; becau≈øe I am confident that by ≈øteady exertions and per≈øeverance we ≈øhall ≈øurmount them, and hope that the enemy will find that we ≈øhall be able to prevent them from penetrating the country, ≈øhould they attempt it, which I believe they will not do, even if they ≈øhould (contrary to my expectations) be able to po≈ø≈øe≈øs them≈øelves of Ticonderoga, unle≈øs General Howe ≈øhould penetrate up Hud≈øon's river. I have already di≈øpatched an expre≈øs to the States of Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts, and New-Hamp≈øhire, to ha≈øten on the remainder of their troops, and have given the mo≈øt pointed orders to the Deputy Commi≈ø≈øary and Quarter Ma≈øter General to furni≈øh what is nece≈ø≈øary in their re≈øpective departments, and as ≈øoon as I have brought matters in ≈øome train at Ticonderoga, and the communication above this, I ≈øhall ha≈øten back to pu≈øh on the nece≈ø≈øaries, and regulate affairs on the We≈øtern Communication, where al≈øo much di≈øorder prevails.

I take the liberty to enclo≈øe this under flying ≈øeal to his Excellency the Commander in Chief, as I cannot find time to do my≈øelf the honour to give Congre≈øs and him a ≈øeparate detail of what I have written.

div.head: Copy of a letter to his Excellency General Wa≈øhington, dated Saratoga, June 14, 1777.
div.p: I DO my≈øelf the honour to inclo≈øe your Excellency a letter to Congre≈øs under flying ≈øeal. Let me entreat you, Sir, to ≈øpare no exertions to ha≈øten on the troops from your State. Such as can conveniently come by the way of Albany to do it. div.head: Extracts of a letter to John Barclay, E≈øq Chairman of the Albany Committee, dated Saratoga, June 14, 1777.

Before I left Albany I di≈øpatched a ≈øpeech to the Oneidas, on the ≈øubject of Brandt's threatnings, and the depredations he has already committed. By this conveyance another on the ≈øame ≈øubject is ≈øent.

div.head: Extract of a letter to the Honourable Philip Living≈øton, James Duane, and William Duer, E≈øquires, dated Saratoga, June 14, 1777.
div.p: I BELIEVE the ab≈øurdity, as well as impo≈ø≈øibility, of attempting to maintain the exten≈øive lines at Ticonderoga, will appear in a ≈øtriking point of view (if attention is paid to General St. Clair's letter) as well as the propriety of drawing ≈øo much of our force to this ≈øide of the Lake, as to leave only a ≈øufficient garri≈øon for Mount Independence. If Sir John John≈øon attempts to fall on the Mohawk river, and takes his route from Crown-Point, and we have troops on this ≈øide of the lake, I propo≈øe to let him pa≈øs, and fall in his rear, while he is oppo≈øed in front by what force we may be able to collect on the Mohawk River, and by thus getting him between two ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ res we ≈øhall probably give a good account of him.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Colonel Van Schaick, dated Saratoga, June 14, 1777.
div.p: I HAVE ordered a detachment of about one hundred men, under the command of Captain Wiley, now at Stillwater, immediately to march to Albany, there to obey ≈øuch orders as you ≈øhall give. On your arrival at Albany, you will apply to Colonel Tupper for ≈øuch a detachment of his and Colonel We≈ø≈øon's regiment as to make up one hundred and fifty, exclu≈øive of commi≈ø≈øioned officers. Major Badlam to be one of the officers.

With the≈øe, taking twenty days provi≈øions, and a ≈øufficiency of ammunition, you will immediately march „Äà‚óä„Äâ Cherry Valley, de≈øiring the Committee of Tryon county to meet you on the way to that place, of whom you will enquire what place will be mo≈øt eligible to po≈øt the troops in, ≈øo as be≈øt to defend the inhabitants from any in≈øults which may be offered by Jo≈øeph Brandt and his party, or any others. You will give ≈øtrict orders that no in≈øult is offered to any Indian whatever, unle≈øs the troops are ab≈øolutely attacked, in which ca≈øe force is to be repelled by force; nor are any of the troops to go beyond the line of patented lands, unle≈øs it be in pur≈øuit of Brandt and his party, ≈øhould he kill or captivate any of the inhabitants. Whatever Indians come to any of your po≈øts are to be treated kindly, and ≈øome provi≈øions given them.
You will apply to the Commi≈ø≈øary for a barrel of rum, that you may be enabled to treat the Indians occa≈øionally.

I have ≈øent one me≈ø≈øage to Oneida, and inclo≈øe another, which you will ≈øend from Albany by expre≈øs. Should you not meet any of the Ochquagues on your way to Cherry Valley, I wi≈øh you to ≈øend off a tru≈øty per≈øon, inviting ≈øome of their Chiefs to an interview. When they arrive, urge the nece≈ø≈øity of pre≈øerving the covenant they have made with us. Conjure them not to ≈øuffer Brandt, or any other, to di≈øturb the path of peace. Inform them that you have orders not to cro≈øs the line, unle≈øs it be in pur≈øuit of Brandt, or others that may kill or captivate our people. Remark, that I have ≈øent two me≈ø≈øages to them by the way of Fort Schuyler; that all the Six Nations are to meet the Commi≈ø≈øioners on the 15th of next month; that I hope we ≈øhall meet, as at every former meeting, in love and friend≈øhip, and that we ≈øhall part perfectly ≈øatisfied with each other. Dwell on the little pro≈øpect there is of the Engli≈øh maintaining ≈øo much as one foot of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion on the continent of America; that we are daily gaining ≈øtrength, they weakening; and whatever el≈øe your prudence, on which I greatly rely, may ≈øugge≈øt. Events will ari≈øe, which, as they are unfore≈øeen, no orders can be given about, and in which you mu≈øt exerci≈øe your own judgment.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Eli≈øha Avery, E≈øq D. C. G. dated Saratoga, June 14, 1777.
div.p: BY letters this moment received from General St. Clair, I am advi≈øed that there is only ≈øeven weeks provi≈øions at Ticonderoga. I am al≈øo informed that there is no more at Fort George, than what is barely nece≈ø≈øary for the daily con≈øumption of the garri≈øon. If the orders I gave you early la≈øt winter had been complied with, we ≈øhould not have laboured under the pre≈øent di≈øtre≈øs. If my memory ≈øerves me (for I have not my books with me) I directed you to lay in provi≈øions at Ticonderoga, to ≈øupport a garri≈øon of three thou≈øand men to the fir≈øt of April, be≈øides eight months provi≈øions for five thou≈øand men at Fort George, Fort Ann and Skeen≈øborough, and a like quantity at Albany.

I charge you in the mo≈øt po≈øitive manner to ha≈øten what ≈øalted beef and pork you may have to Albany, or to any of the po≈øts on Hud≈øon's river, between Albany and Fort Edward, and to procure as many fat cattle as po≈ø≈øible, and to cau≈øe them to be drove to Ticonderoga without delay. If we are obliged to abandon Ticonderoga for want of provi≈øions, I leave you to judge of the con≈øequences to your≈øelf. I am, &c.

div.head: Extracts of a letter to his Excellency General Wa≈øhington, dated Fort Edward, June 16, 1777.
div.p: I DID my≈øelf the honour to addre≈øs you from Saratoga on the 14th in≈øtant. On the next day Am≈øbury and Adams (mentioned in General St. Clair's letter, copy whereof I tran≈ømitted Congre≈øs by letter under cover to your Excellency) arrived at Saratoga. What pa≈ø≈øed between us, and what information he gave, is noted in the paper, No. 1. No. 2 is the letter which was inclo≈øed between the two bottoms of the canteen.

If the information which Am≈øbury gives is to be relied upon, as I think it is, we ≈øhall ≈øoon be attacked at Ticonderoga; and, although I think the forces now there may be ≈øufficient to hold that important po≈øt, I have no troops to oppo≈øe either Sir John John≈øon, if he ≈øhould penetrate to the Mohawk river, or any to prevent the communication between this and Fort George from being cut off, nor have I force, if the≈øe ≈øhould not be attempted by the enemy, to march to the relief of Ticonderoga. In this ≈øituation, I am under the nece≈ø≈øity of applying to your Excellency for a reinforcement.
Permit me to beg that your Excellency will communicate the contents of this di≈øpatch to Congre≈øs, as I cannot find time to do my≈øelf the honour to write them.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Colonel Lewis, D. Q. M. G. dated Saratoga, June 16, 1777.
div.p: ALL the batteaus in Hud≈øon's river you are immediately to ≈øend to Fort George, except ≈øixty-five, which are to be divided between the different ≈øtations between Albany and Fort Edward; and, that this may be done in the mo≈øt expeditious manner, the batteaumen at Stillwater to go to Albany, and they, together with the batteaumen which are at Albany, to bring as many as they can navigate to Stillwater, and to go back from thence with the remainder to Half Moon, where they will be brought by the troops from Albany, leaving twenty batteaus at Albany.

When the remainder are got to Stillwater, the batteaumen to proceed with them to Fort Miller, leaving twenty at Stillwater, and five between M'Larin's and Fort Miller. When the whole are got to Fort Miller, the batteaumen to proceed to Fort Edward, leaving twenty at Fort Miller. The batteaumen now employed between Fort Edward and Fort Miller, after having carried all the batteaus which are at the former place to the latter, to go down to Stillwater, and bring batteaus from thence to Fort Edward. A compleat ≈øett of oars, poles and paddles, to be brought on with each batteau, leaving a ≈øufficient number of oars, poles and paddles, at the different po≈øts for the batteaus to be employed from tho≈øe po≈øts. Fifty waggons, at lea≈øt, to be immediately ≈øent to Fort Edward, to carry the batteaus into Lake George. All the tar that can be procured to be ≈øent on without the lea≈øt delay. Each of the batteaus, as they come up, to take what ≈øtores there may be at any of the po≈øts from Albany to Fort Miller, both included. One hundred of the be≈øt working cattle to be immediately drove down to Ticonderoga.

div.head: Copy of Memorandum given to Colonel Lewis, D. Q. M. G. the 17th day of June, 1777 , at Fort George.
div.p: ALL the beef and pork to be ha≈øtened up to Fort George. As many oxen and waggons to be ≈øent up to Fort Edward and Lake George as can be procured.

Leave orders at every ferry, in the General's name, not to ≈øuffer any waggons to pa≈øs downwards, unle≈øs they have written orders from the commanding officers at Fort George, Fort Edward, or from an A≈ø≈øi≈øtant Quarter Ma≈øter. The≈øe orders to be left in writing at each ferry. Send on the batteaus with all po≈ø≈øible di≈øpatch. Send on pitch or tar, and oakum or junk. Get a li≈øt from Commodore Wynkoop, of every article wanted in the naval department. Write an order to Yates for a company of batteaumen. Ha≈øten on carpenters coming from New-England to Fort George. Let the black≈ømiths continue to make intrenching tools, whenever they can be ≈øpared from labour indi≈øpen≈øibly nece≈ø≈øary.

Inform Mr. Avery the General expects that the pork that is at Bennington, and other places on the communication, be forwarded immediately to Hud≈øon's river. Examine every po≈øt, ≈øee what is wanting, and whatever ought to be forwarded ≈øhould be done immediately. Only 260 tents arrived at Fort George. Make particular enquiries where they are, and let them be in≈øtantly forwarded.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Mr. James Yancey, A. D. C. dated Head-Quarters, June 21, 1777.
div.p:
INFORMATION having been given me that there is a number of horned cattle, ≈øufficiently in fle≈øh to be killed for the u≈øe of the army, in that part of the country which lies on the ea≈øt ≈øide of Hud≈øon's River, and to the northward of the manor of ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øeluerwick, and that many of the owners of ≈øuch cattle refu≈øe to ≈øell the „Äà‚óä„Äâ . And whereas the army „Äà‚óä„Äâ de≈øtitute of fre≈øh provi≈øions, an article e≈ø≈øentially nece≈ø≈øary to the pre≈øervation of the health of the troops, you are therefore hereby ordered immediately to repair to that part of the country, and apply to the owners of all ≈øuch cattle as my be fit for the purpo≈øe afore≈øaid to ≈øell the ≈øame to you; and if they refu≈øe to di≈øpo≈øe of them, you are to cau≈øe the ≈øame to be apprai≈øed by two apprai≈øers, under oath, giving the owner the appointment of one of them, if he chu≈øes, and tender payment therefor
accordingly; and if, neverthele≈øs, the owners refu≈øe to part with ≈øuch cattle, you are then to take them away, keeping an account of and giving a certificate for the ≈øame, ≈øpecifying the number and apprai≈øed value. And that you may not be ob≈øtructed in the execution of this order, an officer and a party of men will attend you, to aid you in the ≈øame; in doing of which, you are to pay ≈øtrict attention that no unnece≈ø≈øary violence or in≈øult be offered to any per≈øon whatever, and cautiou≈øly avoid all partiality.

div.head: Extracts of a letter to General St. Clair, dated Fort George, June 24, 1777.
div.p: I ARRIVED here ye≈øterday afternoon, and am now bu≈øied in arranging matters a little, that ≈øtores may be forwarded with more regularity than heretofore.
In a day or two you will receive all the pork and ≈øalted beef now at this po≈øt, fifty barrels only excepted. Eighteen barrels are only come from Albany ≈øince March la≈øt.
When the pork and other articles are ≈øent on, the flour will come in the large ≈øchooner only, until you can have more time and ≈øpare cattle to tran≈øport it from the landing to the ≈øaw-mills.

Seven barrels of tar go over to-day, and two tons of iron, with all the tents that are arrived here, together with four boxes of axes, and about three hundred bu≈øhels of pea≈øe, and about twenty new batteaus. The≈øe ≈øhould be carried acro≈øs the ≈øoone≈øt po≈ø≈øible, and not ≈øuffered to be u≈øed. The remainder will come on from day to day.
Pray oblige me with your commands for whatever you may need for a public or private u≈øe.

div.head: Extract of a letter to Congre≈øs, dated Saratoga, June 25, 1777.
div.p: ON the 17th in≈øtant I arrived at Ticonderoga, where I found General St. Clair, and the other General Officers, a≈ø≈øidno ‚Ä¢ ≈øly employed in the nece≈ø≈øary works. I ≈øoon found that much was to be done, and, after having informed my≈øelf of the ≈øtate of the fortifications, ≈øtores, &c. I thought it nece≈ø≈øary to convene a Council of the General Officers, and laid before them the propo≈øitions contained in the paper No. 1, which being taken into their con≈øideration, we came to the re≈øolutions noted in the ≈øame paper.

I was in hopes to have found the po≈øt in a better ≈øtate of defence than it is, and the works for ob≈øtructing the pa≈ø≈øage to prevent the enemy's naval force from getting into the rear of our fortifications compleated, or, at the very lea≈øt, con≈øiderably more advanced than it unhappily is. That matters have not been carried on with more di≈øpatch is in a great mea≈øure to be imputed to the late arrival of any troops, who could be brought to work with ≈øpirit, that the artificers did not come by the time they were ordered, and to a want of working cattle. The latter I have already ≈øupplied, and I have ≈øent on an additional number of carpenters, ≈øo that the bu≈øine≈øs will now go on in better train, and I hope with much more ≈øpirit, and tru≈øt we ≈øhall ≈øtill be able to put every thing in ≈øuch order as to give the enemy a good reception, and, I hope, a repul≈øe, ≈øhould they attempt a real attack, which I conjecture will not be ≈øoon, if at all, although I expect they will approach with their fleet, to keep us in alarm, and to draw our attention from other quarters where they may meditate a real attack.

I left Ticonderoga on Sunday evening, and arrived at Fort George on Monday afternoon; and having, previous to my cro≈ø≈øing the lake, taken mea≈øures to bring on a ≈øupply of provi≈øions, I had the happine≈øs to ≈øend on from Fort George between three and four hundred barrels of beef and pork, ≈øo that we have now near ≈øixty days provi≈øions of the meat kind at Ticonderoga, and flour for near double that time, al≈øo at lea≈øt fifteen hundred barrels now at Fort Edward and Fort George, which will all be at the latter place by the end of this month. A ≈ømall quantity of beef and pork is be≈øides on the way up; but, le≈øt this ≈øhould ≈øtill be an in≈øufficient quantity in ca≈øe of a ≈øiege, and that the ≈øalted meat may be hu≈øbanded as much as po≈ø≈øible, I have ≈øent Commi≈ø≈øary Yancey with a ≈ømall party into the interior part of the country to bring up fat cattle; of which, I am informed, there is a con≈øiderable number, chiefly in the hands of per≈øons who have purcha≈øed them to get our paper currency out of their hands. The orders I have given to procure them (copy whereof, No. 2, I do my≈øelf the honour to tran≈ømit) will, if carried into execution, certainly infringe on the civil rights of the inhabitants; but, con≈øidering the nece≈ø≈øity of the ca≈øe, and what kind of people will be mo≈øt affected by them, I hope I ≈øhall ≈øtand excu≈øed for this ≈øtretch of power. I expect the ≈øupply will be ≈øpeedy; if ≈øo, it will eradicate every anxiety on the ≈øcore of provi≈øions, at lea≈øt until our numbers con≈øiderably encrea≈øe.

I was very di≈øagreeably di≈øappointed to find the troops of Ticonderoga ≈øo mi≈øerably clad and armed, and nothing in ≈øtore for them. Many are literally barefooted, and mo≈øt of them ragged. It is not po≈ø≈øible to procure ≈øome cloathing, arms and blankets? Many are al≈øo de≈øtitute of the latter.
The tents I ≈øent from Philadelphia came in good time, as there was hardly ≈øhelter for what troops we have, and that very indifferent.

I have ordered all ≈øuch ≈øick as are not likely to recover ≈øoon to be conveyed to Fort George in covered boats, which are made for the purpo≈øe. If it had been equally proper to have ≈øuffered them to remain, and that they could have been as well provided with vegetables, yet nece≈ø≈øity would have ju≈øtified it, as not one ≈øingle room in the ho≈øpital is yet fini≈øhed, nor will it ≈øoon be in a condition to receive a con≈øiderable number of ≈øick.

The corps of artillery not affording even one man to a gun, I have drafted two hundred from the different regiments, but was under the nece≈ø≈øity to promi≈øe ≈øuch additional pay as to make it equal to that of the artillery corps, which I hope will meet the approbation of Congre≈øs.

One of the ≈øchooners at Lake George is launched: She is to carry fourteen guns. Another will be in the lake by the fir≈øt of next month, and the timber for the gallies is hauled to the ≈øpot where they are to be built. But the rigging which I ordered up in the winter is not all arrived, nor have we a ≈øufficient number of guns for the≈øe ve≈ø≈øels. I tru≈øt, however, I ≈øhall ≈øtill be able to procure both in time.
The paper, No. 3, is copy of Francis Montly's information, who is lately arrived from Canada.

div.head: Extract of a letter to his Excellency General Wa≈øhington, dated Saratoga, June 25, 1777.
div.p:
I HAD the honour to receive your Excellency's favour of the 16th in≈øtant, at Ticonderoga, on Sunday the 24th. It gives me infinite plea≈øure to learn that your force is becoming ≈øo re≈øpectable, as to afford you a
pro≈øpect of making an impre≈ø≈øion on the enemy's lines. I wi≈øh I could ≈øay that ours was ≈øuch, as to create a rea≈øonable hope that we ≈øhould be able to maintain both ≈øides of the lake at Ticonderoga, in ca≈øe of a ≈øerious attack.

The inclo≈øed letter and papers to Congre≈øs will advi≈øe your Excellency of the ≈øtate of affairs in this department. Since writing my letter to Congre≈øs, I have received one from General St. Clair, copy whereof I do my≈øelf the honour to enclo≈øe. If the enemy's object is not to attack Ticonderoga, I ≈øu≈øpect their movement is intended to cover an attempt on New-Hamp≈øhire, the Mohawk river, or to cut off the communication between Fort George and Fort Edward, or perhaps all three, the more to di≈øtract us and divide our force, by drawing our attention to ≈øo many different quarters. I wi≈øh the reinforcement the General Officers at Ticonderoga advi≈øed me to apply to your Excellency for may be ≈øent the ≈øoone≈øt po≈ø≈øible. The garri≈øon, of Fort George is much too weak, and I have not a man to ≈øend there, or to make any oppo≈øition in Tryon county.

div.head: Copy of a letter to Major General St. Clair, dated Saratoga, Thur≈øday morning, June 26, 1777.
div.p: YOUR favour of the 24th was delivered me la≈øt evening. If the enemy ≈øhould not mean a ≈øerious attack on your po≈øt, their movement is probably calculated to cover an attempt on New Hamp≈øhire, the Mohawk river, or to cut off the communication between Fort George and Fort Edward, or perhaps all three. I wi≈øh you therefore to keep a ≈ømall ≈øcout on the ea≈øt ≈øide of the lake, near the road leading from St. John's to New Hamp≈øhire, and others as far we≈øt as the road leading to the north branch of Hud≈øon's river.

I have di≈øpatched an expre≈øs to Congre≈øs and General Wa≈øhington, and have entreated the latter to afford as a reinforcement. Pray let nothing be left at the landing, and the batteaus be brought over as ≈øoon as po≈ø≈øible, that your retreat may not be cut off, ≈øhould you be unable to maintain your po≈øt. I cannot learn that any troops are arrived at Albany. I ≈øhall ha≈øten to that place to forward on whatever I can, and to be in the way to bring up the militia, if nece≈ø≈øary. God ble≈øs you, and believe me, &c.

div.head: Extracts of a letter to his Excellency General Wa≈øhington, dated Albany, June 28, 1777, eleven o'clock A. M.
div.p: YOUR Excellency's favour of the 20th in≈øtant I had the honour to receive, at Saratoga, in the evening of the 26th.

I am this moment favoured with a letter of the 25th in≈øtant from General St. Clair, copy whereof I herewith tran≈ømit. Should an accident happen to the garri≈øon of Ticonderoga, and General Burgoyne make a pu≈øh to gain the ≈øouth part of the lake, I know of no ob≈øtacle to prevent him, as, comparatively ≈øpeaking, I have not a man to oppo≈øe him. The whole number at the different po≈øts at and on this ≈øide of the lake, including the garri≈øon of Fort George and Skeen≈øborough, not exceeding ≈øeven hundred men, and the≈øe I cannot draw away from their ≈øeveral ≈øtations, in every one of which they are already much too weak. It is therefore highly nece≈ø≈øary that a ≈øtrong reinforcement ≈øhould without delay be ≈øent me. If the ≈øloops are not yet ≈øent to bring the troops your Excellency has ordered to be kept in readine≈øs at Peeks-kill, I ≈øhall pu≈øh them off without delay.
As it is not probable that we ≈øhall in time be ≈øupplied with field pieces from the ea≈øtward, I mu≈øt entreat that the reinforcement may bring ≈øome up with them.

I have this moment al≈øo received a letter from Mr. Deane, the Indian Interpreter, extract whereof I inclo≈øe you.Copy of a letter from James Deane, Interpreter, to Major General Schuyler, dated Albany, June 25, 1777. As the information tallies exactly with what I had before, it leads me to conclude that an irruption will be made from the we≈øtward.
I ≈øhall apply for the aid of the militia of this and the neighbouring States, but I fear it will not be very powerful, as many mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily be left at home.

Since writing the above, I have received another letter from General St. Clair, copy whereof is inclo≈øed. I am in pain about Fort George, but have no troops to throw in, and ≈øome time will nece≈ø≈øarily elap≈øe before the militia can be got to march.

body.head: Copy of a letter from James Deane, Interpreter, to Major General Schuyler, dated Albany, June 25, 1777.
body.p:
YOUR favours of the 12th and 14th in≈øtant found me at Fort Schuyler the 17th, bu≈øy in ≈øitting out Thomas and his party to Kaghnawaga. On the morning of the 18th he ≈øat out, with a party of five others, and expected to return in thirty days. He will come in at Fort Schuyler, as he thinks it rather un≈øafe to come directly to Ticonderoga from Canada, le≈øt our ≈øcouts ≈øhould mi≈øtake him for a party of the enemy. I thought it be≈øt that Thomas ≈øhould take five or ≈øix in company, that, ≈øhould be make any important di≈øcovery upon his way to Kaghnawaga, he might immediately detach one or two of his party to give your Honour the ≈øpeed ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øt intelligence. Directly after having di≈øpatched Thomas and his party, I repaired to Oneida, called a meeting, and delivered your ≈øpeeches as directed. The Oneidas were of opinion that it would be to no purpo≈øe for them to ≈øend a me≈ø≈øage to Brandt, as he has long ≈øince publicly declared that ‚Ä¢ e would never regard any thing they ≈øhould ≈øay to him. They have, however, in con≈øequence of your Honour's me≈ø≈øage, di≈øpatched a party to Omoquago, to prevent their people at that place from joining Brandt's party. Al≈øo at the ≈øame time ≈øent an expre≈øs to the Onondagoes, Cayugas and Senecas, conjuring them in the ≈øtronge≈øt terms immediately to recal their people from Oni ‚Ä¢ quago. Mr. Spencer, with a guard of the One ‚Ä¢
das, is gone forward through the Six Nations. I apprehend they will not be able to meet the Commi≈ø≈øioners by the time appointed, by rea≈øon of a Congre≈øs they are ≈øoon to hold among them≈øelves at Onondago, where they expect a deputation of ten men from the Cherokee Nations. I have ventured to direct the Onondagoes to invite them down to the treaty of this place. By an Indian, ≈øome time ≈øince from Canada, it is reported that ju≈øt before he left that country the warriors of Aghg ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øane, who took a party of our people at Sabbath Day Point, fell in with a con≈øiderable number of Scots in the woods, on their way to Canada, whom they attacked and entirely cut off, ≈øuppo≈øing them to have been a party from the American Army; that Sir John John≈øon threatened to be revenged upon them, but that the Indians „Äà‚óä„Äâ him to do his utmo≈øt: that Montreal is full of regular troops, &c. And by two others very lately from Canada, it is reported that Sir John John≈øon would be at O≈øwego with a large body of Indians ‚Ä¢ y the fir≈øt of July, where he would be joined by Butler and his party from Niagara, from whence they were to attack Fort Schuyler; and that the regular troops were at the ≈øame time to make an attack upon Ticonderoga.

closer.signed: I am, Sir, with great re≈øpect, &c. JAMES DEANE.

div.head: Copy of a letter to the Committee of Safety of the State of New-York, dated Albany, June 28, 1777.
div.p: BY the inclo≈øed, which I left under flying ≈øeal for the peru≈øal of the Council of Safety, you will perceive that the enemy are arrived at Crown Point. Whether their intentions are only to make a feint to draw our attention, or a real attack, is ≈øtill doubtful; but as General St. Clair wi≈øhes to have the militia up, I ≈øhall apply to General Ten Broeck for half of the militia under his command. They may be in≈øufficient, even with what may come from the neighbouring States, to make effectual oppo≈øition, if a di≈øa≈øter ≈øhould befal us at Ticonderoga. I wi≈øh therefore, if po≈ø≈øible, to have ≈øome from the northern parts of Dutche≈øs and Ul≈øter counties, and de≈øire General Herkimer to keep that of Tryon county in readine≈øs to march at a moment's warning.

I wi≈øh you to expedite the letter to General Putnam by expre≈øs, with a copy of General St. Clair's letter to me, and if there are any ≈øtoops in the vicinity of King≈øton to order them down to Peek's-Kill.

div.head: Copy of a letter to Major General Putnam, dated Albany, June 28, 1777, 11 o'clock A. M.
div.p: I HAVE this moment received a letter from General St. Clair, copies whereof I have tran≈ømitted to his Excellency General Wa≈øhington and to the Council of Safety of this State; the latter I have reque≈øted to forward a copy to you.

You will perceive our ≈øituation to the northward. I am very apprehen≈øive that I ≈øhall not be able to obtain a body of militia, ≈øufficient to make effectual oppo≈øition; and as his Excellency General Wa≈øhington has advi≈øed me, in a letter of the 20th in≈øtant, that he had ordered you to hold four Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts regiments in readine≈øs at Peek's-Kill to reinforce me, you will plea≈øe to ha≈øten them on with all po≈ø≈øible di≈øpatch. I ≈øhall ≈øend ≈øloops from here, but if any craft can be procured near you, I wi≈øh you by no means to wait the arrival of ve≈ø≈øels from hence.

div.head: Extracts of a letter to Major General St. Clair, dated Albany, June 28, 1777, 11 o'clock A. M.
div.p: YOUR favour of the 25th in≈øtant is this moment delivered me. It ≈øeems as if the enemy mean a real attack on your po≈øt. I ≈øhall move the militia of this State as ≈øoon as I can collect them, and di≈øpatch me≈ø≈øengers to the Ea≈øtern States for as many as they can ≈øend. div.head: Copy of Orders to Eli≈øha Avery, E≈øq D. C. G. dated Albany, June 29, 1777.
div.p:
I HAVE received your letter, in an≈øwer to mine of ye≈øterday. I believe the difficulty of procuring cattle at pre≈øent, is very great, but a ≈øufficient ≈øtock of provi≈øions might have been laid in, if the orders I gave on

div.head: Copy of a letter to the Pre≈øident of the State of Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts-Bay, dated Albany, July 3, 1777.
div.p: THE nece≈ø≈øity of inducing the Six Nations to abide by the neutrality they have promi≈øed to ob≈øerve is a matter of capital moment. div.head: Copy of a letter to Major General Heath, dated Albany, July 3, 1777.

div.head: Copy of a letter to Major General St. Clair, dated Albany, July 4, 1777.
div.p: YOUR favour of the 30th ult. continued to the fir≈øt in≈øtant, I received about two o'clock ye≈øterday morning, and that of the ≈øecond at about one this morning.
If the enemy intend a ≈øerious attack, that manoeuvre of retrenching them≈øelves, and throwing a boom acro≈øs the lake, ≈øeems very odd. I wi≈øh we could certainly know their numbers.

The militia are moving up in great numbers, both from this and the New-England States. I ≈øhall ≈øet out to-morrow with the reinforcements from Peek's-Kills, which are very con≈øiderable. 2dly. Had I received the lea≈øt intimation that it was the de≈øire of Congre≈øs that I ≈øhould take the command of Ticonderoga, I ≈øhould, without the lea≈øt he≈øitation, have done it, but ≈øuch intimation was never given me.
