It will be unnece≈ø≈øary here to mention the frequent applications made to me for ≈øuccour from the we≈øtern country, I mean from Cherry Valley, Umadilla, Schohary, Canajoharie, German Flatts, and Fort Schuyler, which was afterwards relieved by a detachment I ≈øent under General Arnold for that purpo≈øe, ≈øome of which places were in danger, others had ≈øuffered, and all in the greate≈øt con ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ernation, as will appear by ≈øundry papers which I ≈øhall have the honour to lay before the Court.

The fate of ≈øort Schuyler, as well as Ticonderoga, was precarious. In ca≈øe of the reduction of either, mea≈øures were to be taken for oppo≈øing the victorious army, and the ≈øy≈øtem of that oppo≈øition was to depend on events and circum≈øtances, then only to be conjectured.

Pacific, as well as ho≈øtile mea≈øures, to avoid the depredations of the ≈øavages, were then in agitation, a treaty was to be held, me≈ø≈øages were to be ≈øent and received, agents to be employed and in≈øtructed, ≈øpeeches to be made and an≈øwered, pre≈øents to be collected and di≈øtributed. Add to this, that there was not a general officer in the department, who had a competent knowledge of that exten≈øive country, immediately to direct the military operations in it. With what propriety could I throw my≈øelf into Ticonderoga, and, as it were, abandon tho≈øe numerous and e≈ø≈øential objects?

Had I remained with the garri≈øon of Ticonderoga, the valuable ≈øtores at Fort George would have been lo≈øt, a competent ≈øupply of provi≈øions for Fort Schuyler would not have been afforded, for although I had given or ‚Ä¢ ers for it immediately on my re≈øuming the command, it was not done till after the 20th of July, as appears by Colonel Gan≈øevoort's letter of that date, and then by my expre≈øs orders. The militia of this State would not have been ≈øo ≈øoon collected or the cattle and carriages in the reach of the enemy removed. The ob≈øtructions in the navigation of Wood Creek, and of the roads into the country (which was done before General St. Clair and the garri≈øon came up) whereby the progre≈øs of the enemy was greatly retarded, might not have been effected, nor would the country ≈øo ≈øpe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ have been put into a po≈øture of defence.

The papers which I have la≈øt quoted, I tru≈øt, wil ‚Ä¢ evince ≈øuch a con≈øtant attention to the duties of my office, and ≈øuch a degree of anxiety for the public weal, as could only flow from a heart deeply impre≈ø≈øed with the love of its country; and may I be permitted to ob≈øerve, that, notwith≈øtanding the Committee appointed
by the re≈øolution of Congre≈øs of the 29th of July, 1777, were charged to make the mo≈øt critical enquiry, in order to inve≈øtigate the cau≈øes of the misfortunes in the Northern Department, and that in obedience to the orders of Congre≈øs, and in conformity to their duty, they publi≈øhed the re≈øolutions in the newspapers, and in the ≈øame public manner called upon every per≈øon capable of giving information to do ≈øo, wrote to the ≈øeveral officers in the Northern Department, and to the ≈øeveral Executive Powers of this and the Ea≈øtern States, to afford their aid in procuring information, and as the charge of my not being at Ticonderoga is founded on a fact which was notorious, which Congre≈øs were fully informed of, previous to that re≈øolution, it affords ≈øtrong pre≈øumptive proof that the Committee received no information on which they could ground any charge, and authorizes the conclu≈øion, that if I erred in judgment, in not being at Ticonderoga during the ≈øiege, it was by no means an intentional neglect of duty. Indeed, I have every rea≈øon to believe, from the confidence which Congre≈øs have been plea≈øed to place in me after I was la≈øt ≈øuperceded in the command of the Northern Department, in≈øtances of which I ≈øhall beg leave to produce, that that Honourable Body does not con≈øider me either as a criminal, or even unworthy ≈øervant of the public. I hope al≈øo to evince to the Court, that, although extremely wounded in my feelings to be deprived of the command in the moment when there was a pro≈øpect of acquiring great reputation, I continued in that line of conduct which I conceived it to be the duty of every good man to hold to his country, however highly that country may have injured him; and for that purpo≈øe I ≈øhall beg leave to read ≈øome letters and papers, for the information of the Court, after having laid before them ≈øundry applications that were made me from different quarters
The Papers read were:
1. A letter of July 2, from the Committee of Tryon county, repre≈øenting the danger of withdrawing the continental troops from Cherry Valley, and that unle≈øs a ≈øufficient guard is kept there, the inhabitants from Cherry Valley to the German Flats will be obliged either to abandon their habitations, or ≈øubmit to the terms of the friends of Great-Britain.
2. A letter of July 2, from General Herkimer, informing of a temporary agreement he had made with J. Brandt and his warriors, at the ≈øame time communicating the intelligence he had received of the enemy's intention to in
‚Ä¢ ade the frontiers, which he repre≈øents to be in ≈øo weak and defencele≈øs a ≈øtate, that, in≈øtead of ≈øparing militia to guard Fort Schuyler, they want a≈ø≈øi≈øtance for their own immediate ≈øafety.
3. A letter of July 3, from Colonel Gan≈øevoort, at Fort Schuyler, repre≈øenting the ≈ømallne≈øs of his force, the want of provi≈øions, ammunition, &c.
4. A letter of July 4, from the ≈øame, informing of the mea≈øures he is taking for ≈øtrengthening the po≈øt, and the impo≈ø≈øibility of executing the orders he has received without further a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, and pre≈ø≈øing for a reinforcement and a ≈øpeedy ≈øupply of provi≈øions and ammunition.
5. A letter of July 6, from the ≈øame, accompanied with intelligence from Mr. Spencer, at the Oneida Ca≈øtle, and notifying the arrival of the enemy at O≈øwego, and urging the nece≈ø≈øity of a ≈øpeedy reinforcement and ≈øupply of ammunition and provi≈øions.
6. A letter of July 26, from the ≈øame, informing that the orders for reinforcing the garri≈øon with 200 militia had not been complied with, and that he is ≈øtill in want of provi≈øions; and confirming the account of Colonel Butler's arrival at O≈øwego with a number of Indians and Canadians; and that Sir John John≈øon was on an i≈øland near O≈øwego, with a number of tories.
7. A letter from Mr. Spencer, dated Oneida, July 6, 1777, informing that the Indians have received an invitation from the enemy, and have re≈øolved to attend a treaty at O≈øwego, after which they promi≈øe to go to Albany.
8. A letter of July 7, from the Committee of Schohary to Brigadier General Ten Broeck, informing him of the ho≈øtile intentions of the Indians and tories in that quarter, and de≈øiring that the militia from that di≈øtrict may be ≈øent home for their immediate defence.
9. A letter of July 7, from the Committee of Tryon county, expre≈ø≈øing their apprehen≈øion of an inva≈øion on the northerly parts of their county, and earne≈øtly ≈øoliciting a ≈øpeedy reinforcement of the garri≈øons of Forts Schuyler, Dayton and John≈øon, which are at pre≈øent weak, and on the ≈øupport of which the ≈øafety of that county wholly depends.
10. A letter of July 7, from General Herkimer, repre≈øenting the weak ≈øtate of the garri≈øons of Forts Schuyler and Dayton, and informing that Indian ≈øcouts have been di≈øcovered near tho≈øe places; that a Negroe conver≈øed with one of the ≈øcouts.
11. A letter of July 9, from the Committee of Schenectady to Brigadier General Ten Broeck, repre≈øenting that the inhabitants of that di≈øtrict had made application to them, reque≈øting their militia might be kept at home; and that the Committee, ≈øen≈øible of the danger that threatened that quarter, had ≈øo far complied with their reque≈øt as to ≈øtop the march of the militia that were ordered to join him, until they could receive his an≈øwer.
12. A letter of July 9, from General Ten Broeck, inclo≈øing a copy of the foregoing letter, and of that of the 7th from the Committee of Schohary, and informing that in his an≈øwer he has acquainted them that he cannot comply with their reque≈øt, on the contrary has urged them to ≈øend on their militia to join him.
13. A letter of July 9, from Mr. V. P. Douw, informing that an Ogwaga Indian has been ≈øent by the Chiefs from that village, to inform the Commi≈ø≈øioners that Sir John John≈øon is arrived at O≈øwego, where he intends to hold a treaty with the Six Nations; that two other Indians ≈øay Sir John has about one thou≈øand regulars with him, and that his intention is to take Fort Schuyler, and when he has effected that, to come down the Mohawk river.
14. A letter of July 11, from Colonel Robin≈øon, at Bennington, forwarding a reque≈øt for more troops to a≈ø≈øi≈øt in defending the Northern Frontiers, as Colonel Warner has with him only an hundred, and the confu≈øion the inhabitants are in at pre≈øent in moving their families and effects renders it impo≈ø≈øible for them to a≈ø≈øi≈øt, and ≈øoliciting a ≈øupply of arms and ammunition.
15. A letter of July 12, from the Committee of Tryon county to General Herkimer, repre≈ø ‚Ä¢ nting in ≈øtrong terms the critical ≈øituation of Cherry Valley and other parts of the county, and earne≈øtly ≈øoliciting that their militia may not be ≈øent to Fort Schuyler.
16. A letter of July 15, from General Herkimer, informing that the two hundred militia which he had ordered from Tryon county to the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Fort Schuyler had been ≈øtopped by the Committee of the county; that with much difficulty, and by renewing his orders, he had prevailed on them to proceed, under a promi≈øe that they ≈øhould not be kept longer than three weeks from home; repre≈øenting withal the in≈øolence of the di≈øaffected, and the de≈øpondency of the well affected, and praying that mea≈øures may be taken to r ‚Ä¢ u≈øe and animate the ≈øpirits of the latter.
17. A letter of July 22, from the Committee at Albany, repre≈øenting the di≈øtre≈øs of the country at and near Schohary; that near one half of the people there, heretofore well affected, have laid down their arms, and propo≈øe to ≈øide with the enemy, and expre≈ø≈øing an apprehen≈øion that the lo≈øs of Ticonderoga will be followed by a revolt of more than the half of the northern parts of that county, and informing that a con≈øiderable party of tories are lying in the woods in the neighbourhood. Schohary, waiting orders from Sir John John≈øon.
18. A letter of Augu≈øt 5, from the Committee at Schenectady, repre≈øenting the people of that di≈øtrict to be much in the ≈øame ≈øituation and temper as is mentioned in the foregoing letter. .

div.head: Copy of a letter to Mr. Spencer, a Re≈øident at Oneida, dated Albany, July 6, 1777.
div.p: YOUR a≈ø≈øiduity in di≈øcharge of the bu≈øine≈øs committed to you merits my thanks, and I beg you to accept of them. Be a≈ø≈øured that I ≈øhall not forget your ≈øervices. When the Indians come down, I wi≈øh you to accompany them, and to let me know as ≈øoon as the fir≈øt party arrives at Oneida. Mr. Douw has written to ≈øeveral per≈øons on the Mohawk River to furni≈øh the Indians with provi≈øions on their way down.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Colonel Lewis, dated Head-Quarters, Fort Edward, July 8, 1777.
div.p: THE carpenters, who have been employed at Ticonderoga and Skeen≈øborough, are totally de≈øtitute of tools, having lo≈øt them all in their retreat. Some of them are on their way down, and will apply to you to be furni≈øhed with what tools you can procure. The General de≈øires you will take the mo≈øt effectual mea≈øures to procure them a ≈øupply. Inclo≈øed you have a li≈øt of nece≈ø≈øaries wanted at Fort Schuyler. Such as have not been ≈øent by Mr. Ren≈ø≈øclaer, and in your power to furni≈øh, you will plea≈øe to ≈øend on with all the expedition po≈ø≈øible to Col. Gan≈øevoort, except mu≈øket ball, which mu≈øt be delayed till we have a ≈øupply here. I am, &c.

closer.signed: By Order of General Schuyler, J. LANSING, jun. Secretary.

postscript.p: P. S. Three hundred carriages are wanted at this place, which it will be nece≈ø≈øary to detain only a few days Your be≈øt exertions will be required to ≈øend up that number. Let none be neglected. Apply to the Committee of Albany and General Ten Broeck, and reque≈øt their aid to induce the people from every quarter to come up with waggons. Let the militia bring with them as many as they think proper, and a≈ø≈øure them that their detention will be only for a few days. We are in great di≈øtre≈øs for want of lead, an article ≈øo e≈ø≈øentially requi≈øite, that we cannot even hope to do any thing here to prevent the enemy's advancing without it. The citizens of Albany only can ≈øupply our pre≈øent exigencies immediately. Recour≈øe mu≈øt therefore be had to the Committee, begging their interpo≈øition to collect ≈øuch lead as is in the city. The lead from windows and weights may perhaps afford a ≈øupply for the pre≈øent. As ≈øoon as it can be collected, Mr. Ren≈ø≈øelaer will have it made into ball, and ≈øend it up without a moment's delay.
Should a waggon be ≈øent only with one box, as ≈øoon as it is ready, it mu≈øt be pu≈øhed up; al≈øo all the buck ≈øhot.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Major Yates, dated Fort Edward, July 8, 1777.
div.p: BY the return of the fir≈øt carriages you will plea≈øe to ≈øend the remainder of the powder, keeping a quantity ≈øufficient for the garri≈øon and ≈øchooner.

You will al≈øo ≈øend what intrenching tools can be ≈øpared, and all the cannon, except tho≈øe in the ≈øort and on board the ≈øchooner, and the ≈øalt. Should there be a greater number of carriages than what are wanted for the above articles, you will cau≈øe them to be loaded with flour, as we ≈øhall ≈øoon be in want here.

As ≈øoon as General St. Clair arrives, I ≈øhall reinforce your garri≈øon; but ≈øhould you certainly di≈øcover that the enemy's army are near you, and ≈øo ≈øtrong as that you will not be able to keep your po≈øt, you are then to quit it, bringing off what you can, and effectually de≈øtroying the re≈øt, together with all the buildings. If you are obliged to come away, try by all means to bring off the cannon and tents. Keep the contents a profound ≈øecret, for fear of di≈øpiriting the troops. If you have any mu≈øket ball, ≈øend it over in the very fir≈øt waggon, with what bullet-moulds you may have.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Philip Van Ren≈ø≈øelaer, E≈øq Store-keeper, &c. dated Fort Edward, July 8, 1777.
div.p: SUCH is the urgent nece≈ø≈øity of a ≈øpeedy ≈øupply of mu≈øket ball, that no exertion ≈øhould be ≈øpared to have it immediately furni≈øhed. Every man therefore that can be got mu≈øt be employed in that nece≈ø≈øary work, and pu≈øh it up as ≈øoon as any is ready. The cartridge paper is doubtle≈øs on its way. I am, &c.

closer.signed: By Order of General Schuyler, J. LANSING, jun. Secretary.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Major Yates, dated Fort Edward, July 9, 1777.
div.p: YOUR letter of this day is ju≈øt delivered me. The large waggons which now go up are capable of carrying the eighteen pounders; you will therefore ≈øend them on without delay. Send over the carpenters tools, and likewi≈øe the black≈ømiths tools and bellows, &c. We ≈øtand much in need of both. Send eight barrels more of the powder.

When the≈øe things are forwarded, ≈øend all the rum that belongs to the ≈øuttlers, for we ≈øhall need it much, it is to be left in their own po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; and then the other articles mentioned in my la≈øt. General St. Clair is expected here to-morrow. If he arrives, I ≈øhall not be in ha≈øte to evacuate Fort George. The ≈øtores, however, mu≈øt be removed. Should you be obliged to retreat, bring off all the hor≈øes, horned cattle and carriages belonging to the inhabitants, except their milch cows. Such carriages as you cannot bring away you mu≈øt de≈øtroy. Keep this a ≈øecret, le≈øt they ≈øhould put it out of your power to comply with this order.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Philip Van Ren≈ø≈øelaer, E≈øquire, dated Fort Edward, July 9, 1777.
div.p: I AM extremely ≈øorry to hear that the ammunition waggon did not leave Albany until ye≈øterday morning. Nothing can equal the di≈øtre≈øs we are in for want of it. Let me entreat you, in the name of God, to ha≈øten on the ball and cartridge paper, and let a tru≈øty hand attend the waggons in which they come.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Colonel Lewis, dated Fort Edward, July 10, 1777.
div.p: YOUR's of the 8th in≈øtant is before me. I am happy at the mea≈øures you have taken. Ha≈øten up every thing which the army may ≈øtand in need of, which has hardly any thing. Carriages are ≈øo much wanted, that we may be utterly ruined for the want of them. They mu≈øt be ≈øent me.

The ammunition waggon that was loaded on Sunday la≈øt is not yet arrived. Whenever any ammunition is ≈øent up, apply to the Commanding Officer for an officer to e≈øcort it, and let me know the very hour which it leaves Albany. Let the ≈ømiths make axes. The batteaumen are, I think, acquitted; if not, I pardon them. Plea≈øe to ≈øignify this to Colonel We≈ø≈øon, for I have not time to write him. If the enemy gives us a little time, and that I am joined by General St. Clair, they will not ≈øee Albany this campaign.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Colonel Gan≈øevoort, dated Fort Edward, July 10, 1777.
div.p: YOUR letter of the 6th in≈øtant I received la≈øt night. I have reque≈øted General Herkimer to ≈øend you a reinforcement, which I hope is on the way up to you. I do not apprehend that any con≈øiderable body is coming again≈øt you. If you ≈øhould receive intelligence of the approach of the enemy, you will apply to Major Badlam, who commands the continental troops I ≈øent up under Colonel Van Schaick to reinforce you. My orders for that purpo≈øe go to him by this conveyance. I have ordered on a ≈øupply of provi≈øions and ammunition, and will give you all the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance in my power to afford.
Send Captain Marqui≈øie down, and let Major Hubble ≈øuperintend the work. Our affairs begin to put on a better face in this quarter, and I tru≈øt all will go well.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Captain Hodg≈øden of the Artillery, dated Fort Edward, July 10, 1777.
div.p: I HAVE this day wrote to Colonel Ma≈øon, reque≈øting him to forward without delay the ≈øtores mentioned in a li≈øt which I inclo≈øed him. You will proceed with all po≈ø≈øible di≈øpatch to Springfield, to a≈ø≈øi≈øt in bringing tho≈øe ≈øtores on, and any other that may be wanted or ordered this way. Lieutenant Inger≈øole is to accompany you, to a≈ø≈øi≈øt in executing this bu≈øine≈øs. All officers in the ≈øervice of the United States are required, and all civil officers entreated, to give you the mo≈øt effectual aid, to convey the ≈øtores you are ≈øent for in the mo≈øt expeditious manner to the army.

div.head: Extract of Orders to Jacob Cuyler, E≈øq D. C. G. P. dated Fort Edward, July 12, 1777.
div.p: If the enemy give me a little time, and I believe nece≈ø≈øity will oblige them to do that, we ≈øhall, I tru≈øt, put our≈øelves into ≈øuch a po≈øture as will prevent them from going down the country. Notwith≈øtanding the variety of cares that engro≈øs my attention, I a≈ø≈øure you that I am in high ≈øpirits, and, thank God, in full health, hoping for the be≈øt, and not doubting but that our affairs will ≈øoon wear a better face, and take a more favourable turn, and in the fulle≈øt confidence that America cannot be conquered by Britain. Why ≈øhould we de≈øpond? Do you, my dear Sir, and let every Gentleman in≈øpirit the people, and all will be well.
Axes are greatly wanted, and, although it is not of your department, yet your a≈ø≈øi≈øtance will be of much ≈øervice. I greatly depend upon it.

div.head: Extract of Orders to Colonel Living≈øton, dated Head-Quarters, Fort Edward, July 13, 1777.
div.p: AS we have good rea≈øon to believe the enemy mean to penetrate by the Mohawk river, they will probably attempt to ≈øurpri≈øe John's-town. The General therefore de≈øires you will be extremely vigilant, and con≈øtantly keep out ≈øcouts to watch the motions of the enemy, as directed by former orders. Any material intelligence you may receive you will plea≈øe to tran≈ømit by expre≈øs to the General.

closer.signed: H. B. LIVINGSTON, A. D. C.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Captain McCrackin, of Van Schaick's, dated Head-Quarters, Fort Edward, July 13, 1777.
div.p: YOU are immediately to proceed, with your company and the detachment under your command, to White Creek, and there, with the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of ≈øuch of the militia as can be prevailed upon to defend their country, po≈øt your≈øelf in ≈øuch a ≈øituation as be≈øt to prevent the incur≈øions of the enemy.

You will not leave any cattle, or any carriages of any kind, between you and the enemy, that you can po≈ø≈øibly drive or bring off, nor will you ≈øuffer any to be left in your rear, in ≈øuch a ≈øituation as that, if you ≈øhould be obliged to give way, they may fall into the enemy's hands, before you can be ≈øupported by a reinforcement. Such per≈øons as the Committee ≈øhall point out to you as unfriendly to the United American States, you will immediately apprehend and ≈øend down pri≈øoners to Fort Miller. You will advi≈øe me from time to time of your ≈øituation, and that of the enemy, and be extremely careful that you may not experience either the misfortune or di≈øgrace of a ≈øurpri≈øe.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Jacob Cuyler, D. C. G. P. dated Head Quarters, Fort Edward, July 14, 1777.
div.p: THE army at this po≈øt have not a mouthful of provi≈øions of the meat kind on this ground. The General directed me to acquaint you of this circum≈øtance, and to beg you to ≈øend up a ≈øupply in≈øtantly, as we ≈øhall otherwi≈øe be in danger of ≈øtarving. I am, &c.

closer.signed: J. LANSING, jun. Secretary.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Mr. Farrant, A. C. P. dated Head-Quarters, Fort Edward, July 14, 1777.
div.p:
YOU will go from hence to Bennington with all expedition, by way of Cambridge. Upon your arrival at the latter place, as well as on your way to it, and between that and Bennington, you will give directions that all the fat cattle in that part of the country, whoever may have them in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, be in≈øtantaneou≈øly
brought to this place. You will urge the per≈øons employed in conveying them not to make a moment's delay, as the army have not a mouthful of fre≈øh provi≈øions.

closer.signed: By Order of General Schuyler, J. LANSING, jun. Secretary.

div.head: Copy of a letter to His Excellency General Wa≈øhington, dated Stillwater, Monday, July 7, 1777.
div.p: I HAVE this moment received a letter from General Learned, copy whereof I do my≈øelf the honour to inclo≈øe.

I am extremely apprehen≈øive that the greate≈øt part of the garri≈øons of Ticonderoga and Mount Independence are in the enemy's power, and if they make a pu≈øh they may do what they plea≈øe, as I have not above 700 continental troops to oppo≈øe them with, and I fear not above twice that number of militia. I cannot doubt but that we have lo≈øt every piece of cannon we had there, ≈øo that I am now left with a few ≈ømall pieces, not a ≈øufficient number even for the two ≈ømall ≈øchooners on Lake George. I evidently fore≈øee that all this part of the country will ≈øoon be in their power, unle≈øs we are ≈øpeedily and largely reinforced.
I am in the utmo≈øt di≈øtre≈øs for want of provi≈øions of the meat kind, much of the beef now forwarding being ≈øpoiled.
I ≈øhall do every thing that is left in my power to do, and the be≈øt.

div.head: Copy of Orders directed to General St. Clair, or officer commanding the troops from Ticonderoga, dated Albany, July 7, five A. M.
div.p: I AM this moment informed, by an expre≈øs from Fort Ann, that Ticonderoga and Mount Independence are evacuated, and that our troops are landing at Skeen≈øborough. If ≈øo, you will plea≈øe to ≈øend out ≈øtrong parties, to bring away the inhabitants to the north and north-ea≈øt of Skeen≈øborough. Should that be impracticable, you are to give the mo≈øt po≈øitive orders to bring away all their cattle, of what kind ≈øoever they may be, and al≈øo all ≈øuch wheel carriages as cannot be brought away to be de≈øtroyed.

div.head: Copy of a letter to Brigadier General Ten Broeck, dated Stillwater, July 7, 1777.
div.p: BOTH Ticonderoga and Mount Independence are in the enemy's po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. Part of our troops are at Skeen≈øborough, to which place the enemy have pur≈øued. It is therefore now become nece≈ø≈øary that every man of the militia ≈øhould turn out, and that without a moment's delay. You will therefore i≈ø≈øue your orders accordingly, and I hope to ≈øee you with them. Such a variety of affairs will engro≈øs my attention, that I ≈øhall not have time to attend to the applications of the militia, and the ≈øervice will con≈øequently ≈øuffer, unle≈øs you are pre≈øent.

div.head: Copy of a letter to the Committee of Berk≈øhire, dated Stillwater, July 7, 1777.
div.p: I HAVE this moment received a letter, of which the inclo≈øed is a copy. An event ≈øo alarming has not yet happened ≈øince the conte≈øt began, and yet, by ≈øtrennous exertions, we may ≈øtill prevent the enemy from penetrating, but not unle≈øs every man of the militia turns out. I therefore entreat that you will take mea≈øures, without delay, for marching the whole force of your county, and that of the neighbouring counties in your State, and that of Connecticut, directly to Albany. Time is too pre≈ø≈øing to apply to the Pre≈øident of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts and Governor of Connecticut.
You will plea≈øe to forward to each this intelligence. I am, &c.

div.head: Copy of a letter to Major General St. Clair, dated Fort Edward, July 8, 1777.
div.p: I WROTE you la≈øt night from Saratoga, wi≈øhing you to direct your march with the utmo≈øt expedition to Fort Ann or this place. I now mo≈øt earne≈øtly renew the reque≈øt. I had forgot to give directions about the ≈øecurity of the people on the Grants. I think it will be right to leave Colonel Warner, with his regiment and the militia belonging to the Grants. If you are of the ≈øame opinion, you will give the orders accordingly. I wi≈øh Colonel Warner to drive the cattle in that part of the country into his rear, and to ≈øend off every carriage that may be ≈øerviceable to the enemy, and ≈øuch as cannot be ≈øent off to be de≈øtroyed. Whatever cattle are ≈øufficiently in fle≈øh to be killed for the troops, he mu≈øt ≈øend on here by a ≈øafe route.
Some of the enemy are harra≈ø≈øing us above Fort Ann; I wi≈øh you may fall in with them.
The reinforcement from below is marching up, and ≈øo are the militia, and I think, when you join us, we ≈øhall not have occa≈øion to fear that the enemy will make any further progre≈øs.

div.head: Copy of a letter to Brigadier Herkimer, dated Fort Edward, July 8, 1777.
div.p: THE road leading from Fort Dayton to Fort Schuyler is ≈øo much incumbered with wood, by the falling of trees acro≈øs it, that it is rendered impa≈ø≈øable for men or carriages. You will therefore plea≈øe to order two hundred of your militia to be employed in clearing it away, with all the di≈øpatch the nature of the ≈øervice will admit of, each man bringing an are with him.

Colonel Gan≈øevoort, who commands at Fort Schuyler, is very pre≈ø≈øing for a reinforcement, to carry on the nece≈ø≈øary works at that garri≈øon; and as I have it not in my power to ≈øend up continental troops for that purpo≈øe, I mu≈øt beg you will order two hundred men of your brigade to his ≈øupport and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance. I am, &c.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Brigadier General Fellows, dated Fort Edward, July 9, 1777.
div.p:
YOU will march with the detachment ordered to parade by the orders of this morning as far as Fort Ann. You are to take with you as many ≈øelling axes as can be found in ≈øtore. On your arrival at Fort Ann, you will ≈øend off ≈ømall parties to the different farm hou≈øes, to drive off all the cattle to this place, and to bring
away whatever carriages may be found. Provided neverthele≈øs, that if any of the inhabitants chu≈øe to come away, that parties are to a≈ø≈øi≈øt them in loading their goods upon their carriages, and e≈øcort them to this po≈øt. The≈øe parties being ≈øent out, you will begin, as near Fort Ann as po≈ø≈øible, to fell trees acro≈øs the road; and when you come where the roads divide, one half of your force is to be employed on the road which leads to Huffnagel's, and the other half on that to Jones's. You will make the ob≈øtructions as effectual as po≈ø≈øible. Take up every bridge, and burn the covering and timber. Let me know from time to time how you proceed. It will be nece≈ø≈øary that you keep two or three ≈øcouts con≈øtantly out towards the enemy.

div.head: Copy of a letter to his Excellency General Wa≈øhington, dated Fort Edward, July 10, 1777.
div.p: I AM this moment favoured with your Excellency's letter of the 6th in≈øtant. You will before this have received my ≈øeveral letters, advi≈øing your Excellency of the evacuation of Ticonderoga, and the di≈øtre≈ø≈øed ≈øituation we are in. We are by no means now in a better, rather wor≈øe, as de≈øertion is frequent. General Nixon's brigade is not yet come up, nor do I get a reinforcement of the militia. General St. Clair, from whom I have heard for the fir≈øt time about ten this morning (copy of his letter I inclo≈øe) is about fifty miles ea≈øt of me. If he ≈øhould go to Bennington, as I fear he will be obliged to do, he will be ≈øtill farther off, and the more he gets into the inhabited part of the country, the greater will the de≈øertion from the army be, which is already much, very much dimini≈øhed, by numbers going off. I am very apprehen≈øive General St. Clair will not join me with more than one thou≈øand men. General Nixon's corps, I am informed, is under that. Thus, with le≈øs than three thou≈øand continental and not quite one thou≈øand militia, I am to face a powerful enemy from the north, flu≈øhed with ≈øucce≈øs, and pre≈ø≈øed at the ≈øame time from the we≈øt by a body, which, from repeated information (copies whereof I have not time to ≈øend), is re≈øpectable, and already at O≈øwego.

We have ≈øtill ≈øtores of ≈øuch importance left at Fort George, that I am very anxious to bring them off before I order that po≈øt to be abandoned, which I mu≈øt do, or ≈øuffer the garri≈øon to fall into the enemy's hands, which it inevitably will, if the enemy, who are approaching by Wood Creek, throw them≈øelves between this and Lake George.
I have brought away about twenty pieces of artillery from Lake George, together with nearly all the powder, amounting to about thirteen tons.

General Fellows, with a ≈ømall body of militia, but all I could get, are breaking up the road between this and Fort Ann, and felling trees into it. I will throw every ob≈øtacle in their route I po≈ø≈øibly can, and retard their progre≈øs as much as po≈ø≈øible. For this purpo≈øe, I ≈øhall di≈øengage my≈øelf of every thing cumber≈øome, the artillery e≈øpecially, as I can make no u≈øe of it.
Permit me to a≈ø≈øure your Excellency, that I ≈øhall make every re≈øi≈øtance I po≈ø≈øibly can, and that nothing ≈øhall be left undone to prevent the enemy from penetrating farther in the country.

div.head: Copy of a letter to Brigadier General Ten Broeck, dated Fort Edward, June 10, 1777.
div.p: I WISH you to write the Committee of Schohary not to be under ≈øuch groundle≈øs apprehen≈øion. If there are any tories ≈øixteen miles ≈øouth-ea≈øt, let the inhabitants go and take them, for at pre≈øent I cannot ≈øpare any men from here. A few days after General St. Clair arrives, I hope to di≈øcharge part of the militia that were up fir≈øt.

The enemy are retired from Fort Ann, and I am making all the ob≈øtruction in my power, and if they give me three or four days time after General St. Clair joins. I believe they will not ≈øee Albany this campaign.

I have ≈øaved about forty pieces of cannon, and fifteen tons of powder. The cannon I ≈øhall ≈øend to Saratoga, to get carriages made for them at that place. I am greatly di≈øtre≈ø≈øed for waggons. Pray afford your a≈ø≈øi≈øtance in procuring them. The troops are recovering their ≈øpirits, and begin to look up: Mine were never better. Adieu.

div.head: Copy of a letter to Brigadier General Herkimer, dated Fort Edward, July 10, 1777.
div.p: YOUR letter of the 7th in≈øtant is before me. I doubt not but that you will have parties of Indians about you. Tho≈øe you mention ≈øeem to have been very quiet ones, for they not only ≈øhewed them≈øelves, but ≈øtood and talked with a Negroe. You mu≈øt expect that ≈øome mi≈øchief will be done, but that ought not to di≈øcourage the people. If only a ≈ømall portion of your militia turn out, you will drive them off. The garri≈øon of Fort Schuyler will be ≈øufficiently ≈øtrong when your detachment arrives, but as ≈øoon as I can afford troops to go into that quarter, I ≈øhall ≈øend them. We mu≈øt oppo≈øe the enemy where they ≈øhew them≈øelves, that is here, at pre≈øent; and although Ticonderoga is abandoned, I am neverthele≈øs not afraid that they will be able to get much lower into the country. Keep up the ≈øpirits of the people, and all will be well.

div.head: Copy of a letter to the Committee of Tryon County, dated Fort Edward, July 10, 1777.
div.p: I AM ≈øorry, very ≈øorry, that you ≈øhould be calling upon me for a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of continental troops, when I have already ≈øpared you all I could, when no army has yet made its appearance, when the militia of every county in the State, except yours, is altogether called out. For God's ≈øake, do not forget that you are an over-match for any force the enemy can bring again≈øt you, if you can act with ≈øpirit. I have a large army to oppo≈øe, and tru≈øt I ≈øhall do it effectually, and prevent their penetrating to any di≈øtance into the country.
Keep up your ≈øpirits, ≈øhew no ≈øigns of fear, act with vigour, and you will not only ≈øecure your country, but gain immortal honour.

div.head: Copy of a letter to Brigadier General Nixon, dated Head-Quarters, Fort Edward, July 12, 1777.
div.p:
YOU will immediately march your brigade to Fort Ann. On your arrival there, you will di≈øpatch two ≈øcouts, one on the we≈øt and the other on the ea≈øt ≈øide of Wood Creek, to di≈øcover if the enemy are approaching
either by land or water. You will direct the officers commanding the≈øe ≈øcouts to be as exact as po≈ø≈øible in a≈øcertaining the numbers of any of the enemy they may ≈øee, and to give you the earlie≈øt intelligence of it, that I may be advi≈øed thereof by you as ≈øoon as po≈ø≈øible. Having di≈øpatched the ≈øcouts, you will proceed to burn the ≈øaw-mills which are near Fort Ann, and then fall the trees growing on the banks of Wood Creek into the ≈øame; and if ≈øuch a ≈øuperior body of the enemy ≈øhould move towards you, that it is „Äà‚óä„Äâ probable that you can keep your ground, you are then to retire, advi≈øing me thereof, that your retreat may be covered. In retreating, you are to break up all the bridges in your rear, that the enemy may be as much ob≈øtructed in their march as po≈ø≈øible. Let me frequently hear from you, for much depends upon receiving early intelligence.

Axes will be delivered by Captain Wendell, A≈ø≈øi≈øtant Deputy Quarter Ma≈øter General, to your Quarter Ma≈øter. If you ≈øhould be obliged to retreat, be ≈øure to bring the axes off with you, for we have none be≈øides what will be delivered to you. Plea≈øe therefore to impre≈øs your officers and men with the great nece≈ø≈øity there is to be extremely careful of the axes.
You will find Brigadier General Fellows, with a body of troops, on your march. You are to take him and the troops under his command with you.

div.head: Copy of a letter to Mr. Edmund Willis, Chairman of the Committee of Cambridge, and Colonel Van Woert, dated Fort Edward, July 12, 1777.
div.p: YOUR letter of the 10th in≈øtant I have received. The information that four or five hundred Indians were on their way to New-Perth is totally groundle≈øs. There are not even any ≈øo high up Wood Creek as Fort Ann, where we have a large body of troops. If it was nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øend troops to White Creek, I would mo≈øt readily do it. My care ≈øhall be extended to every quarter, and if my countrymen will ≈øupport me with vigour and activity, we ≈øhall be able to prevent the enemy from penetrating much farther into the country; but if they ≈øuffer their ≈øpirits to ≈øink, and meanly de≈øpond, the word of con≈øequences are to be apprehended.

I am informed that ≈øeveral people, forgetting the duty they owe their country, di≈øcourage the good inhabitants, and are ready to take protection from the enemy. Any that have made ≈øuch declarations, I would advi≈øe to have immediately ≈øecured and ≈øent pri≈øoners to Albany.

The enemy's view, in offering protection, is only to prevent the inhabitants from acting ≈øpiritedly; to get into the country, and, when once there, to plunder indi≈øcriminately, as well tho≈øe that may have relied on their promi≈øes, as tho≈øe that have gloriou≈øly ≈øtepped forth for the defence of their country, and tho≈øe ble≈ø≈øings which they can only enjoy by having that country free. Let every one therefore exert him≈øelf, and all will go well.

div.head: Copy of a letter to Col. Robin≈øon, Lieut. Col. Bru≈øh, and John Fay, E≈øq dated Fort Edward, July 13, 1777.
div.p: YOUR letter of the 11th in≈øtant I received la≈øt night. I ≈øhould be extremely happy if I had it in my power to afford you the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance you reque≈øt, but in fact I have not that number of militia in this quarter. From every intelligence I can procure, the enemy mean to bend their force this way, and it would therefore be highly imprudent to weaken the army in this quarter.

I would, by all means, advi≈øe that the cattle of every kind, and carriages, ≈øhould be moved from every town≈øhip expo≈øed to the incur≈øions of the enemy's parties, and which cannot be covered by the troops or militia, to ≈øome more interior places of ≈øafety.

I have already ordered a con≈øiderable quantity of powder and ball to be ≈øent on to Colonel Warner. If more of the former ≈øhould be wanted, it will be ≈øent on application. As to fire-arms, I have not one, and many of the troops are without, con≈øequently cannot give any.
Inclo≈øe you an order for one thou≈øand weight of powder, which you mu≈øt ≈øend for. Lead or balls there are none arrived as yet.

div.head: Extracts of a letter to his Excellency General Wa≈øhington, dated Fort Edward, July 14, 1777.
div.p: COLONEL Warner, with the remains of his regiment, I have ordered to remain on what are commonly called the New-Hamp≈øhire Grants, together with the militia from that part of this State. He has directions to drive off all the cattle and carriages; but whether he will be able to effect it is a doubt, as I am informed a very great proportion of the inhabitants are taking protections from General Burgoyne, as mo≈øt of tho≈øe in this quarter are al≈øo willing to do.

De≈øertion prevails and di≈øca≈øe gains ground, nor is it to be wondered at, for we have neither tents, hou≈øes, barns, boards, or any ≈øhelter except a little bru≈øh. Every rain that falls, and we have it in great abundance almo≈øt every day, wets the men to the ≈økin. We are be≈øides in great want of every kind of nece≈ø≈øary, provi≈øion excepted. Camp kettles we have ≈øo few, that we cannot afford one to twenty men.

Inclo≈øe your Excellency copy of the proceedings of a Council of General Officers, held at Ticonderoga, copy of which I beg you will tran≈ømit to Congre≈øs, and be ≈øo good as to mention that I have not time to do my≈øelf the honour to write them.

div.head: Copy of a letter to the Inhabitants of Cherry Valley, dated Head-Quarters, Fort Edward, July 14, 1777.
div.p: GENERAL SCHUYLER has directed me to acknowledge the receipt of your petition, and to inform you that Major Bradlam, who commands the detachment which was ≈øent up under the command of Colonel Van Schaick, has orders to advi≈øe with the Committee of your county re≈øpecting the di≈øpo≈øition of the troops under his command. To them therefore he refers you, as he doubts not, ≈øhould they be convinced of the expediency of that body's marching to Cherry Valley, but that they will advi≈øe that mea≈øure for your protection. I am, &c.

closer.signed: J. LANSING, junior.

div.head: Extracts of a letter to the Council of Safety of the State of New-York, dated Fort Edward, July 14, 1777.
div.p: I AM honoured with your favour of the 11th in≈øtant. The contents give me great ≈øatisfaction. However painful it is to labour under a load of calumny, I have, thank God, fortitude enough not to ≈øink under it, nor ≈øhall it di≈øtre≈øs my ≈øpirits, or make me for one moment relax tho≈øe exertions which are become ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary to prevent the enemy from penetrating much farther into the country, which, by God's ble≈ø≈øing, I hope ≈øtill to do. Perhaps, Sir, it may be as well, if even the evacuation of Ticonderoga was an unwi≈øe mea≈øure, not to deprecate it too much, le≈øt it ≈øhould encrea≈øe our difficulties, and God knows I have a choice of them, and yet I am ≈øupported by a pre≈øentiment that we ≈øhall ≈øtill have a merry Chri≈øtmas.

div.head: Copy of a letter to the Committee of Schohary, dated Head-Quarters, Fort Edward, July 15, 1777.
div.p: YOUR letter of the 11th in≈øtant General Schuyler has received, and directed me to inform you that, tho' he cannot ≈øend back Major Becker's detachment, he con≈øents that you keep the re≈øt of your militia at home.

closer.signed: I am, &c. J. LANSING, junior.

div.head: Copy of a letter to Colonel Simmonds, of the Militia of Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts-Bay, dated Fort Edward, July 15, 1777.
div.p: I WISH to extend my care and attention to every part of the country, and afford a≈ø≈øi≈øtance wherever it is wanted; but I am very weak here, and the enemy, as I am informed, are gone to Ticonderoga, to come through Lake George. However, a≈ø≈øi≈øtance is wanted on the Grants, and you will march four or five hundred men to aid Colonel Warner, the remainder of the militia to come this way.

div.head: Copy of a letter to Major General Heath, dated Fort Edward, July 15, 1777.
div.p: WE are collecting our army; its ≈øpirits are recovering. Pray ≈øend us whatever you can think of for an army that has nothing, except provi≈øion. Our whole train of artillery con≈øi≈øts of two iron field pieces. The whole of our lead le≈øs than three tons, only about fifteen reams of cartridge paper. In great want of blankets, camp kettles, arms, cloathing of every kind, rum, coffee, chocolate, ≈øugar; axes we have very few, and none to be had in the country.

Many of our troops have de≈øerted. I wi≈øh you to apply to the Legi≈ølature of the State, and reque≈øt them to adopt ≈øuch mea≈øures as will bring them back. The enemy are at Skeen≈øborough. Our advanced po≈øts are at Fort George and Fort Ann. We propo≈øe to remain here, and at a po≈øt about four miles below this.

Our whole ≈øtrength does not exceed four thou≈øand four hundred men, including General Nixon's brigade, which con≈øi≈øts of no more than five hundred and ≈øeventy-five effectives, rank and file, and eleven ≈øick. I am, &c.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Colonel Warner, dated Fort Edward, July 15, 1777.
div.p: I AM favoured with your's of ye≈øterday. Inclo≈øe you an order for what cloathing can be procured at Albany, which mu≈øt be ≈øent for. I have made a temporary appointment of Mr. Lyons to be your Pay Ma≈øter, and have given him four thou≈øand dollars, which is all I can at pre≈øent ≈øpare. Colonel Simmonds, with four or five hundred of his regiment, will join your's; but let the others come this way. We are informed the enemy are gone to Ticonderoga, to come by the way of Fort George, becau≈øe they find it rather difficult to penetrate by the way of Skeen≈øborough. Secure all the cattle and carriages you can. Much depends upon preventing them from getting ≈øupplies of that kind. Advance as near to the enemy as you po≈ø≈øibly can. Secure all tories, and ≈øend them to the interior part of the country. Be vigilant; a ≈øurpri≈øe is inexcu≈øable. Thank the troops, in my name, for behaving ≈øo well as you ≈øay they did at Hubbarton. A≈ø≈øure them that I will get whatever I can to make them comfortable. All of your regiment that were here are already on the way to join you. If we act vigorou≈øly, we ≈øave the country. Why ≈øhould we de≈øpond? Greater misfortunes have happened, and have been retrieved. Cheer up the ≈øpirits of the people in your quarter.

div.head: Copy of Orders to General Nixon, dated Fort Edward, July 16, 1777.
div.p: BOTH your letters of this day have been delivered me.

I am quite in opinion with you and General Fellows, that de≈øtroying the cau≈øeway will be a very material ob≈øtruction to the enemy's march. I beg therefore that you will do it in the mo≈øt effectual manner, as I hope that of ≈øelling trees acro≈øs the road is done; but unle≈øs both roads are compleatly ≈øtopped, it will be of little avail. You will therefore plea≈øe, as ≈øoon as that which leads by Jones's is done, to go upon that which leads pa≈øt Huffnagel's, and ≈øtop that al≈øo.

You will ob≈øerve by my orders to General Fellows, that he was directed to ≈øend parties to the different farm hou≈øes, to drive off all the cattle. This you will plea≈øe to do without exception, leaving only the milch cows with ≈øuch families as cannot move off.
You will al≈øo bring away the ≈øcows, and all the iron work from Jones's and Huffnagel's mills, or ≈øee they do it them≈øelves, that the enemy may not have the advantage of tho≈øe mills.

Pray keep out ≈øcouts continually, and order them to go as far beyond Fort Ann as po≈ø≈øible. When you have compleatly carried into execution what is hereby directed, you will advi≈øe me thereof, that I may give directions or your future de≈øtination.

div.head: Copy of a letter to Mr. Ira Allan, dated Fort Edward, July 16, 1777.
div.p: IT gives me great pain that I am not in a capacity directly to an≈øwer your letter of the 15th in≈øtant. As an officer of the Honourable the Congre≈øs, who repre≈øent the Thirteen United States of America. I cannot with propriety take notice of a Fourteenth State, unknown in their Confederacy. In order that the public ≈øervice may not ≈øuffer, I ≈øhall however an≈øwer your letter, which, for the rea≈øons already a≈ø≈øigned, I am under the nece≈ø≈øity of doing in your private capacity.

That the enemy ≈øhould fortify at Ca≈øtle-Town is to me exceeding unaccountable. It is certain that a con≈øiderable body of their troops with General Burgoyne are at Skeen≈øborough; that, from corroborated information, a body of them are gone to Ticonderoga, to come by the way of Lake George.

It is, doubtle≈øs, extremely difficult to move the inhabitants that lie neare≈øt the enemy, but I ≈øhould hope that Colonel Warner, ≈øupported by the militia under Colonel Simmonds, which I have ordered to join him, and with that of the State of New-Hamp≈øhire, and ≈øuch as can be collected from the more ≈øouthern parts of what are commonly called the Grants, would be able to effect this bu≈øine≈øs in a very great mea≈øure.
The enemy, by the be≈øt accounts, are not above ≈øix thou≈øand; and, if it be true that they are di≈øpo≈øed of as I have mentioned, the body at Ca≈øtle-Town cannot be con≈øiderable.

I have ordered ≈øuch per≈øons as are going to the enemy for protections to be ≈øeized, and ≈øent pri≈øoners to me. Three have been delivered to me, and I have ≈øent them to goal in Albany. I think it would be right to adopt a ≈øimilar conduct, e≈øpecially to tho≈øe who are not yet ≈øo much in their power as to be obliged to accept protection from them.
I have delivered Captain Fitch a proclamation, of which I wi≈øh you to make copies, and di≈øtribute them in the country neare≈øt the enemy.

div.head: Copy of Orders to Colonel Warner, dated Fort Edward, July 16, 1777.
div.p: I AM this moment informed by Captain Fitch, that the New-Hamp≈øhire militia are marching to join me. It is not my intention, much as I am in want of troops, that they ≈øhould come hither, as it would expo≈øe the country in that quarter to the depredations of the enemy. I therefore inclo≈øe you an order for them to join you. If none are arrived, you will ≈øend expre≈øs for them. I hope when they come you will be able, if not to attack the enemy, at lea≈øt to advance ≈øo near as to bring off the well affected and ≈øecure the malignants. Let me hear from you often.

div.head: Extract of a letter to his Excellency General Wa≈øhington, dated Fort Edward, July 17, 1777.
div.p:
INCLOSE your Excellency copy of a proclamation of General Burgoyne, with copy of one of mine.
By PHILIP SCHUYLER, E≈øq Major General in the Army of the United States of America, and Commander in Chief of the Northern Department.
To the Inhabitants of Ca≈øtle-Town, of Hubbarton, Rutland, Tinmouth, Paulett, Wells, Grenville, with the neighbouring Di≈øtricts, al≈øo the Di≈øtricts bordering on White Creek, Cambden, Cambridge, &c. &c.
WHEREAS Lieutenant General John Burgoyne, commanding an army of the Briti≈øh troops, did, by a written paper by him ≈øub≈øcribed, bearing date at Skeen≈øborough Hou≈øe on the 10th day of July in≈øtant, require you to ≈øend from your ≈øeveral town≈øhips deputations, con≈øi≈øting of ten per≈øons or more from each town≈øhip, to meet Col. Skeene at Ca≈øtle-town, on Wedne≈øday, July 15th, at ten in the morning, for ≈øundry purpo≈øes in ≈øaid paper mentioned, and that you were not to fail in paying obedience thereto, under pain of military execution.
Whatever, my countrymen, may be the ob≈øten≈øible rea≈øons for ≈øuch meeting, it is evidently intended by the enemy then to prevail on you, by threats and promi≈øes, to for≈øake the cau≈øe of your injured country, to a≈ø≈øi≈øt them in forcing ≈ølavery on the United States of America, and, under the ≈øpecious pretext of affording you protection, to bring on you that mi≈øery, which their promi≈øes of protection drew on ≈øuch of the deluded inhabitants of New-Jer≈øey who were weak enough to confide in them, but who ≈øoon experienced their fallacy, by being treated, indi≈øcriminately with tho≈øe virtuous citizens who came forth in defence of their country, with the mo≈øt wanted barbarity, and ≈øuch as hitherto hath not even di≈øgraced barbarians They cruel ‚Ä¢ y butchered, without di≈øtinction to age or ≈øex‚Äî ravi≈øhed children from ten to women of eighty years of age‚Äîthey burnt, pillaged and de≈øtroyed whatever came into their power, nor did tho≈øe edifices, dedicated to the wor≈øhip of Almighty God, e≈øcape their ≈øacrilegious fury. Such were the deeds, ≈øuch they were inconte≈øtibly proved to be, which have marked the Briti≈øh arms with the mo≈øt indelible ≈øtains. You will plea≈øe to repair thither with all convenient ≈øpeed, and take upon you the command of all the continental troops, and ≈øuch of the militia as you can prevail upon to join your troops. Fort Schuyler being be≈øieged, you will ha≈øten to its relief, and I hope that the continental troops now in the county of Tryon, if joined by ≈øome of the militia, will be adequate to the bu≈øine≈øs. Lieutenant Colonel Van Dyck is very well acquainted, not only with the country, but with many of the Indians, and will be capable of doing you good ≈øervice. Permit me therefore to recommend him to your attention.

Henry Glen, E≈øq is A≈ø≈øi≈øtant Deputy Quarter Ma≈øter General at Schenectady, to whom you will apply for a≈ø≈øi≈øtance in waggons and batteaus. If you could procure ≈øuch a number of waggons as to convey the mens packs, it would greatly expedite your march. Orders are given to ≈øend on a ≈øupply of provi≈øions. You will, however, not be retarded on that account, as the country is capable of affording a ≈øufficiency for your troops.

Colonel Van Dyck will inform you of the names of the Colonels of militia in Tryon county, and although I have already written to General Herkimer and the General Committee of the county to draw forth their militia, yet it will be proper for you, as ≈øoon as you join the troops marched under the command of General Learned, to expedite expre≈ø≈øes, entreating that the militia may be collected at the German Flats by the time you may arrive there.

A ≈ømall regiment, commanded by Colonel Living≈øton, is at John's-Town. The inhabitants of Caghnawaga have offered to hold that po≈øt, if Colonel Living≈øton ≈øhould be ordered up. You will be better enabled to judge of the propriety of moving him when you arrive there, and will do what you judge be≈øt.

Although the Mohawk Indians are far from being friendly to us, yet it would greatly prejudice our cau≈øe if they were in≈øulted. You will therefore take every precaution to prevent it. The Oneidas have friendly ≈øentiments towards us, and mu≈øt be cheri≈øhed. They may perhaps be induced to take an active part in our ≈øavour. Inclo≈øe you a warrant for one thou≈øand dollars in ≈øpecie, which you will plea≈øe to make u≈øe of in order to conciliate the Oneidas, and to induce them to a≈ø≈øi≈øt you. Be plea≈øed to a≈ø≈øure them that I wi≈øh to ≈øee them as ≈øoon as they can come down, and that I have provided a genteel pre≈øent for them.

The inhabitants of Tryon county are cheifly Germans, e≈øpecially tho≈øe at the German Flats. I think it would ≈øerve a good purpo≈øe to extol the action under General Herkimer, to prai≈øe their bravery, and give a≈ø≈øurances that you wi≈øh to be joined by men, who have ≈øo bravely defended them≈øelves. Compliment General Herkimer, and plea≈øe to make mine to him.

It is not only impo≈ø≈øible, but needle≈øs, to be more particular. I ≈øhall therefore only add that if Fort Schuyler ≈øhould unhappily have fallen into the enemy's hands, that you will then ≈øo di≈øpo≈øe of the troops as be≈øt to cover the country.

I have ordered on a quantity of ammunition from Albany. If it is not yet gone, pray take it with you. I very much que≈øtion whether more lead can be ≈øpared, as none of that from Peek's Kill which was de≈øigned for this department is come up. If you ≈øhould think the quantity of powder I have ordered to be in≈øufficient, you can take more. It is be≈øt you ≈øhould carry it on with you.

On the 19th of Augu≈øt, in the evening, General Gates arrived, and re ‚Ä¢ a≈ø≈øumed the command of the Northern Department. Here I could indulge my≈øelf in the fir≈øt of rational plea≈øures, that of paying the tribute of gratitude to the Gentlemen I had the honour to command; but my peculiar ≈øituation, and a delicacy which I cannot ≈øurmount in the pre≈øence of ≈øome of the≈øe Gentlemen, prevents me.

The Court will have ob≈øerved that I made frequent applications to his Excellency the Commander in Chief for reinforcements, in addition to tho≈øe that were ≈øent. I ≈øhould charge my≈øelf with a want of candour to that re≈øpectable character, if I did not acknowledge that I believe, nay that I know, that he afforded me every aid it was in his power to give. I could dwell with ≈øatisfaction on the many marks of attention which I have experienced from his hands, but in this place it would be improper. I therefore proceed to lay before the Court ≈øome papers, which will exhibit my conduct after I was ≈øuperceded, together with ≈øome from Congre≈øs, evincive of the confidence they ≈øtill repo≈øed in me.

As it is of importance to ≈øecure as many of the Indians to the intere≈øt of the American cau≈øe as po≈ø≈øible, e≈øpecially ≈øuch as re≈øide in Canada, you will therefore plea≈øe to take mea≈øures to remove the abovementioned Indians to ≈øome part of Connecticut river, as near the inhabitants as po≈ø≈øible; and, to induce them more readily to come, you will afford them ≈øome a≈ø≈øi≈øtance in provi≈øion and ammunition, for which purpo≈øe we furni≈øh you with eight hundred dollars. div.p: ON the 14th in≈øtant about three hundred Indians (including men, women and children) of the Oneidas, Tu≈øcaroras, and a few Onondagos and Mohawks, arrived here. The 15th was ≈øpent in the u≈øual ceremony of congratulation, during which we took occa≈øion to found their inclinations, and finding them inclinable to engage in the war, we prepared a ≈øpeech, and on the next day offered them the war belt, which was immediately accepted by warriors of each nation. On the 17th the war fea≈øt was prepared, at which the belt was ≈øolemnly accepted by the whole. The 18th and 19th pa≈ø≈øed in equipping them, and being informed about ten at night of the 19th that our army was engaged, and having then three of the chief warriors to ≈øup with me, Mr. Edwards and my≈øelf reque≈øted them to march without delay, which they and many others did with great alacrity, and with ≈øuch di≈øpatch as to reach General Gates before noon next day, and by night the remainder arrived at the camp, making in all near one hundred and fifty. They have already taken about thirty pri≈øoners, and intercepted ≈øome di≈øpatches from General Burgoyne to General Powel, commanding at Ticonderoga. The≈øe Indians have reque≈øted that the ≈øouthern ones ≈øhould be advi≈øed by us that they have taken the hatchet, and a bolt will al≈øo be ≈øent by them. We have taken mea≈øures to induce the whole confederacy to join us, and have rea≈øon to believe that they will do it. If ≈øo, we ≈øhall ≈øoon be informed of it, and I think in that ca≈øe it would be prudent to call them into action the ≈øoone≈øt po≈ø≈øible, into whatever quarter their ≈øervices may be mo≈øt wanted.

div.head: Copy of a letter to Congre≈øs, dated Saratoga, November 4, 1777.
div.p: YOUR favour of the 12th ult. I had the honour to receive on the ≈øecond in≈øtant. I feel my≈øelf much affected by your friendly wi≈øhes for my happine≈øs. The ≈øentiments I have been happy enough to entertain of your humanity and ≈øen≈øibility have encrea≈øed with my misfortunes, nor ≈øhall ought ever be able to efface them.

On the ≈øecond in≈øtant, two Briti≈øh officers, on their return to Canada, took ≈øhelter in a violent ≈øtorm of rain in my little hut, the only remains of all my buildings in this quarter. In the cour≈øe of conver≈øation, I found that the one was attached to General Carleton, the other to General Burgoyne. Carleton was faulted by the one for keeping more troops in Canada than what were nece≈ø≈øary. An alternation en≈øued, and, from what pa≈ø≈øed, I had every rea≈øon to conclude that the number now in Canada, including the garri≈øon of Ticonderoga, does not exceed two thou≈øand. I ≈øpeak of tho≈øe in Canada proper, exclu≈øive of the garri≈øon of O≈øwegatchie, Niagara, and the upper po≈øts, which, from the conver≈øation of the≈øe officers, I concluded to be between 1500 and 2000.

Whether it was po≈ø≈øible to have ≈øent a body of troops immediately after the Convention of this place to Ticonderoga I will not venture n ‚Ä¢ w to ≈øay, but if they had been ≈øent I believe that we ≈øhould have regained that po≈øt; for I learn from a tolerable intelligent countryman ju≈øt arrived from thence, that the hurry which prevails in embarking their ≈øtores in ≈øuch, that it ≈øtrongly indicates they are apprehen≈øive of a vi≈øit, and will probably abandon it. If ≈øo, it argues that they are too weak in Canada to ≈øupport that garri≈øon in ca≈øe of an attack.

Impelled, Sir, by that affection for my country, which not all the injuries I have ≈øu≈øtained have been able to ≈øhake, I venture to ≈øugge≈øt to Congre≈øs, that I can conceive an irruption into Canada in the en≈øuing winter would be attended with a variety of happy con≈øequences, which will readily occur to Congre≈øs, provided that the force employed be ≈øo re≈øpectable as to create ≈øuch a confidence in the Canadians, as would induce them to join our arms for the pre≈øervation of the country after we ≈øhould have entered it. Perhaps five thou≈øand men would be ≈øufficient.

I am well aware that a winter's expedition is attended with more difficulties than will offer to a ≈øuperficial ob≈øerver; but I am very far from thinking them in≈øurmountable, provided that mea≈øures are pur≈øued without delay, and the proper officers exert them≈øelves in the execution of the orders they receive. Congre≈øs may, perhaps, determine on ≈øuch an expedition. I ≈øhall therefore take the liberty to ≈øay, if they do, that the men who go on this ≈øervice ≈øhould, be≈øides their ordinary under-cloaths, be provided each with a good woollen cap, a ≈øhort, but good, blanket coat, with a cape to turn over the cap, to prevent the ≈ønow falling on the neck, each two chequered woollen ≈øhirts, a woollen pair of breeches, two pair of good woollen ≈øtockings, a pair of Indian legings, ≈øo long as to come up to the crotch, a pair of good Indian ≈øhoes, and a pair of Engli≈øh ≈øhoes, with a pair of good warm ≈øocks, and a pair of ≈øtout mittens, and not to be ≈øuffered to carry any other cloathing. Each man ≈øhould al≈øo have a pair of creepers, a tinder-box or horn, ≈øteel, ‚Ä¢ lints, and a bundle of matches to every ten men. One thou≈øand pair of ≈ønow ≈øhoes ≈øhould al≈øo be provided, 100 pair of ≈økates, 100 hand machines for firing ve≈ø≈øels or buildings, 2000 mu≈øket wooden cartridges, canes with ≈øpikes, to be filled with a combu≈øtible compo≈øition, to be ≈øhot into ve≈ø≈øels or buildings. Each man to be al≈øo furni≈øhed with a powder horn and bullet pouch. Two thou≈øand ≈øpare ≈øtand of arms ≈øhould al≈øo be carried on, to furni≈øh ≈øuch Canadians as might be willing to engage with us. All the≈øe articles ≈øhould be collected at Albany, to be delivered to the troops immediately before they are to march. One thou≈øand men ≈øhould al≈øo be ≈øent without delay to Skeen≈øborough, by the way of Fort Ann, from whence they ≈øhould take down in rafts the boards that remain at the ≈øaw-mill near that place, none of which have been de≈øtroyed by the enemy, and 16000 are left there, a number ≈øufficient not only to cover the men comfortably, but al≈øo the provi≈øions, of which a quantity, ≈øufficient for 5000 men for three months, ≈øhould be carried to Skeen≈øborough in the cour≈øe of the winter, and bi≈øcuit ≈øent in≈øtead of flour. Before the march of the troops from thence, the Commi≈ø≈øary ≈øhould pick of the be≈øt pork ≈øufficient for the army for fifteen days, and have it well boiled, then laid out to freeze, and packed up again, that the men may not be under the nece≈ø≈øity of cooking on their march.

As it will require 1500 carriages to move ≈øuch a body of troops, and two of the three months provi≈øions, with all the other ≈øtores, a great quantity of hay ≈øhould be purcha≈øed, packed, and di≈øpo≈øed of in ≈øuch place ‚Ä¢ , as that it might be conveniently taken up by the ≈øleds, whether they come from the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts or thi ‚Ä¢ State. Corn, oats and pea≈øe ≈øhould be collected in like manner, and directions given to each driver to bring with him three or four bags. But as I apprehend that a ≈øufficient number of hired ≈øleds could not be conveniently procured, I would advi≈øe that 500 common co ‚Ä¢ r≈øe ≈øleds, of which a carpenter will ea≈øily compleat one in two days, ≈øhould be made, and 1000 ≈øtall fed oxen with yokes be purcha≈øed, to draw the≈øe ≈øleds, and the oxen killed as ≈øoon as the army has penetrated Canada, that the ≈øalt provi≈øion may be ≈øaved as much as po≈ø≈øible, that none may be taken from the Canadians, as I ≈øuppo≈øe no ≈øpecie can be procured to pay them. As it is in vain to attempt to carry on ≈øuch an enterprize in a ≈øecret manner, application ≈øhould be made to the Legi≈ølature of Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts and this State to aid in procuring the ≈øleds, that every farmer who is to furni≈øh one may prepare him≈øelf in time, and the Committee of each di≈øtrict ≈øhould be obliged to deliver the ≈øleds they are to furni≈øh at ≈øuch rendezvous as the officer commanding the expedition ≈øhould direct.

The whole ≈øhould be in readine≈øs to move as ≈øoon as the Lakes have taken, which will probably be by the middle of February; and if Ticonderoga ≈øhould be abandoned, the army might move that way, if not, by the way of Ca≈øtle-Town and Otter-Creek, ≈øo as to fall in with the Lake between Crown-Point and the Mouth of Otter-Creek, or, if the Lakes ≈øhould not be ≈øtrong enough from thence, then not to approach the Lake until the army reaches Onion River.

If it ≈øhould be a≈øked what military operations I have in idea to carry on, I would an≈øwer, whether Ticonderoga is or will be abandoned or not, I would advi≈øe in the fir≈øt place to ≈øecure I≈øle-aux-Noix, and the army to halt there for three or four days, and all the ≈øleds employed to bring timber on it for erecting a fortification; and before the army left it, five or ≈øix rows of ≈øtrong and heavy pickets ≈øhould be drove in the ≈øhip channel, which is there very narrow, and not deep, to prevent the enemy's ≈øhipping from getting into the Lake. If St. John's ≈øhould not be reduced before the ≈øpring of the year, as I ≈øu≈øpect it would not, at I≈øle-aux-Noix three hundred men, under the command of a judicious officer, ≈øhould be left, with directions to fortify him≈øelf in the be≈øt manner he could. The re≈øt of the army ≈øhould then proceed towards St. John's, which I ≈øuppo≈øe the enemy would not abandon; and if it was found impracticable to form the ≈øiege, becau≈øe of the fro≈øt and ≈ønow, one thou≈øand men ≈øhould be left to blockade it. The remainder of the army ≈øhould then proceed to reduce Chamble, which would be the work of a day or two, and then go on to Montreal, and ≈øecure what ≈øtores might be left there by the enemy, and take all the merchandize that would be u≈øeful for the army, and ≈øend it to Albany, paying the French merchants a generous price by bills on France, if Congre≈øs has a fund there to draw on, as I have been informed they have, nothing to ≈øuch of the Engli≈øh as have been our enemies, when we were in Canada in 1775 and 1776. When at Montreal, the Commanding Officer will be able to judge with certainty what force the enemy can gather in Canada to oppo≈øe him, and, if he finds that he can ≈øpare a detachment, he ≈øhould lend it to O≈øwegatchie, to ≈øecure or de≈øtroy the enemy's ≈øhipping, which are always laid up at that place. This bu≈øine≈øs appears to me of the fir≈øt importance, as it would not only be a great ≈øtep towards the reduction of Niagara, if Congre≈øs ≈øhould attempt in the next campaign to get po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of that very important pa≈øs, and which, if in our hands, would have a variety of ≈øuch obvious good con≈øequences that I need not mention them; but it would al≈øo be nece≈ø≈øary, in order to ≈øecure a retreat that way, which, if a retreat is nece≈ø≈øary, I would rather wi≈øh than by the way of Champlain, if St. John's ≈øhould hold out ≈øo long as that the enemy might ≈øend forces into Canada from New-York or el≈øewhere. It may be a≈øked, why I ≈øhould with a retreat by Ontario, and how it could be effected? To the fir≈øt I an≈øwer, becau≈øe mea≈øures may be taken to reinforce the army at their arrival at O≈øwego by troops from Albany, thence to proceed to the reduction of Niagara, if Congre≈øs thought proper; if not, they might return by the way of Fort Schuyler. To the ≈øecond, that all the batteaus in the St. Lawrence, in the vicinity of Montreal, might be collected, and tho≈øe would probably be ≈øufficient to convey all the troops, if not, an additional number might ≈øoon be con≈øtructed; and for that and other bu≈øine≈øs one hundred carpenters ≈øhould be ≈øent with the army into Canada. Nor ≈øhould the Commanding Officer neglect, when at Montreal, to take ho≈øtages from the Cagnawaga and Cana≈øwago Indians, who will be in his power, for their peaceable behaviour, and tho≈øe ≈øhould be ≈øent to the≈øe parts without delay. If St. John's
≈øhould be reduced, I think it is pretty certain that a body of troops appearing before Ticonderoga the garri≈øon would ≈øurrender, ≈øhould they not abandon it this fall, or on ≈øeeing our preparations for going into Canada. It would therefore be nece≈ø≈øary to collect a body of troops, not only for that purpo≈øe, if nece≈ø≈øary, but, if Ticonderoga ≈øhould be abandoned, to be ≈øent into Canada, to reinforce the army there in ≈øuch a manner as that the country might be kept, and, if po≈ø≈øible, the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ge of Quebec undertaken. For the conveyance of the≈øe troops, batteaus ≈øhould be built at Fort George, and begun upon as ≈øoon as advice is received that the army is got into Canada. But if the army ≈øhould be obliged to retreat, this expence may be thought needle≈øs. Not at all; for, if they retreat by Champlain, they may want boats; if by Ontario, the boats may be ea≈øily conveyed into Hud≈øon's river, and from thence into the Mohawk river, to carry on provi≈øions for the troops to go to Niagara, ≈øhould an expedition be determined on; but whether it is or not, it would be imprudent not to prepare in ≈øuch a manner as that troops might be ≈øent to Canada, if it ≈øhould be found nece≈ø≈øary.

Congre≈øs will perceive that great exertions are nece≈ø≈øary for ≈øuch an enterprize, and that the officer who commands it, let him be who he will, will require a≈ø≈øi≈øtance. div.head: Copy of a letter to Congre≈øs, dated Albany, February 8, 1778.
div.p: ON the 12th of January la≈øt we did our≈øelves the honour to inform Congre≈øs of the re≈øult of our deliberations re≈øpecting Indian affairs in this department. They will be plea≈øed to ob≈øerve, from the inclo≈øed copy of a letter from Mr. Deane, the Interpreter, that our opinion of the temper of the Senecas and Cayugas was but too well founded. Tho≈øe haughty nations cannot brook the di≈øgrace which they ≈øu≈øtained from the militia of Tryon county, under the late brave and worthy General Herkimer, near the German Flats, and from the Garri≈øon of Fort Schuyler, under the command of the gallant Colonel Gan≈øevoort. Their re≈øentment has undoubtedly been highly irritated by the infidious arts and bribes of our enemies, who, at a treaty held at Niagara, and which is ju≈øt concluded, have had an opportunity to give an edge to their animo≈øity. The Onondagoes we are apprehen≈øive will al≈øo be drawn in to manife≈øt the ≈øame ho≈øtile ≈øpirit. From the≈øe unfavourable circum≈øtances, there is too much rea≈øon to believe that an expedition will be formed again≈øt the we≈øtern frontiers of this State, Virginia and Penn≈øylvania, in concert with the Briti≈øh troops, Ottowas, Chippewas, Wio ‚Ä¢ dots, Mingoes and other tribes. It is therefore, with the utmo≈øt anxiety, that we wait for the direction of Congre≈øs in an≈øwer to our la≈øt di≈øpatches, without which we ≈øhall be at an utter lo≈øs how to proceed. It is our opinion that vigorous preparations ought to be made, not only to defend the frontiers, but to cha≈øti≈øe tho≈øe nations, by carrying the war, if po≈ø≈øible, into their country. Till they feel the power and the ju≈øt re≈øentment of the United States, there can be no ≈øafety for the defencele≈øs inhabitants. The militia, who lo≈øt their leaders and many of their brave≈øt men at the German Flats, ≈øuffered the additional misfortune of being deprived of their crops. If they ≈øhould again be called upon in planting or harve≈øt time, their families mu≈øt be deprived of all ≈øub≈øi≈øtence. Indeed, they are very ≈øore from what they have already ≈øuffered, and want time to repair their pa≈øt calamities. Little therefore can be expected from their exertions, willing as they may be to give their aid. The Oneidas and Tu≈øcaroras are ≈øtill very friendly; but, ≈øo far from being capable of an active part, are under well grounded apprehen≈øions of falling victims to the rage of their ≈øavage neighbours. They call upon the United States, in who≈øe cau≈øe they took up the hatchet, and are in danger, to protect them, and it is become indi≈øpen≈øably nece≈ø≈øary to erect ≈øome fortre≈øs, and ≈øtation a ≈ømall garri≈øon in their country, for the ≈øecurity of their women and children. We flatter our≈øelves that the Commanding Officer of this department will have in≈øtructions to receive our information, and to make immediate preparations for the defence of the frontiers and protection of our allies. div.head: Extract of a letter to Congre≈øs, dated Albany, March 15, 1778.
div.p: I DO my≈øelf the honour to inclo≈øe the proceedings of the Commi≈ø≈øioners of Indian affairs at the la≈øt treaty, held at John's-Town. The Board of Commi≈ø≈øioners intended to have addre≈ø≈øed the Honourable Congre≈øs in an official letter, which was prevented by the departure of Mr. Duane and Mr. Edwards, who were obliged by a ≈øudden thaw to ha≈øten from John's-Town before the bu≈øine≈øs of the Indians was compleated, left the ≈øwelling of the rivers ≈øhould have prevented them from reaching their families.

Mr. Duane, the gentlemen mentioned in the minutes, as well as the Commi≈ø≈øioners, were unanimou≈øly of opinion that it was ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary to threaten the ≈øavages with cha≈øti≈øement, as the only means left, ≈øhort of actual cha≈øti≈øement, to induce them to ob≈øerve a ≈øtrict neutrality.

Whether it will have the wi≈øhed for effect, the re≈øult of the Council to be held at Onondago, of which we expect to be informed in about forty days, mu≈øt determine. But, from the accounts received of their hitherto inimical di≈øpo≈øition and revengeful re≈øolutions, the gentlemen, I think, unanimou≈øly believed that ≈øuch of the Mohawks as have fled from their country, a majority of the Onondagoes, and the Cayugas and Senecas in general, will commence ho≈øtilities again≈øt us as ≈øoon as they conveniently can, and that it would therefore be prudent early to take mea≈øures to carry the war into their country, as it would not require a greater body of troops to de≈øtroy their towns than what would be nece≈ø≈øary to protect the frontier inhabitants, who already labour under the greate≈øt apprehen≈øions that they will ≈øoon experience the ravages and cruelty of tho≈øe barbarians. Since my return to this place, I have been honoured with a letter from the Legi≈ølature of this State, covering petitions from the inhabitants of Schohary, Cherry-Valley, Charlotte River, Delaware and Harper's Field, praying the Legi≈ølature for a≈ø≈øi≈øtance. As it is not in the power of the Commi≈ø≈øioners to afford any aid to the≈øe expo≈øed ≈øettlements, I have communicated the contents of the letter and petitions to the Marquis de la Fayette, that he may take mea≈øures to enable the inhabitants to remain on their plantations.

Before I left John's-Town, an account which we had received that the enemy meant to take po≈øt at O≈øwego was confirmed by the information of a tru≈øty Indian, whom I had rea≈øon to believe had good authority for what he a≈ø≈øerted. Should this really be the ca≈øe, there will be little hope left that the Indians will remain neuter. I cannot avoid ≈øugge≈øting, that I ≈øu≈øpect the enemy intend to pro≈øecute the plan which the French began in 1753, and to approach our frontiers with a line of ≈øorts, from whence the Indians may be ≈øupplied with every nece≈ø≈øary, ≈øent out to harra≈øs us, and to which they may retire after an excur≈øion on our frontiers. As ≈øuch a man ‚Ä¢ euvre would not only prove extremely di≈øtre≈ø≈øing to us, but al≈øo oblige us to keep a large body of troops on the interior frontiers, Congre≈øs will pardon me if I expre≈øs a wi≈øh that early and mo≈øt vigorous mea≈øures may be taken to counteract it. Perhaps the mo≈øt, if not the only, effectual means to defeat ≈øuch an intention of the enemy would be, by ≈øending a re≈øpectable army, not only to regain po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of O≈øwego, but to attempt the reduction of Niagara. The honourable Hou≈øe is too well aware of the various advantages that would re≈øult to the States from having that pa≈øs in our hands, for me to pre≈øume to point out even a ≈øingle one. I confe≈øs that ≈øuch an expedition would be attended with many difficulties, that many requi≈øites are to be procured, but if men and ≈øalted provi≈øions can be procured, I ≈øhould imagine every thing el≈øe might be got in r ‚Ä¢ adine≈øs by the la≈øt of May, provided that orders are given immediately. The enemy's ≈øhipping on Ontario might indeed prove trouble≈øome, but not ≈øo as to prevent the troops from cro≈ø≈øing. It is certain they were not able to do it in 1758, when Colonel Brad≈øtreet took Fort Fron ‚Ä¢ tenac. If Congre≈øs ≈øhould enter on ≈øuch a mea≈øure, perhaps it might be well to cover the real de≈øign by building the boats on Hud≈øon's River, and give out that they are intended for the more ≈øpeedy conveyance of troops up and down that river.

Reflecting that Congre≈øs might perhaps have in contemplation the reduction of Niagara, or an expedition into Canada through Ontario, I have engaged Louis (commonly called Colonel Lewis, a friendly Caghnawaga, and a man of enterprize, who is going into Canada by the way of O≈øwegatchie, with three or four tru≈øty Oneidas) to burn, if po≈ø≈øible, the enemy's ve≈ø≈øels on Ontario; if not, to attempt the de≈øtruction of tho≈øe at St. John's; and have promi≈øed a thou≈øand dollars in ≈øpecie as a reward, if the one or the other is accompli≈øhed. I hope for the approbation of Congre≈øs.

Louis, who expects to return in le≈øs than forty days, is al≈øo charged to bring me the mo≈øt exact account he can procure of the enemy's force in Canada, the po≈øts occupied by them, and the numbers at each po≈øt; to inform him≈øelf, if po≈ø≈øible, what military operations the enemy mean to pro≈øecute from Canada in the en≈øuing campaign, and to engage ≈øome of our Caghnawaga friends to give the earlie≈øt intelligence of the movements of the enemy, and of what provi≈øions and military ≈øtores may be ≈øent either to St. John's or up the St. Lawrence.

Court of Ver≈øailles as may be thought prudent, or as Congre≈øs may be at liberty to publi≈øh. I will with the utmo≈øt chearfulne≈øs charge my≈øelf with getting them properly conveyed.

I think one thou≈øand men, with half the garri≈øon of Fort Schuyler, ≈øuch militia as may be procured in Tryon county, and ≈øome of the Oneidas and Tu≈øcaroras, would be quite ≈øufficient to burn the Cayuga Town and ≈øome of the Seneca Villages.
