div.head: Copy of a letter to the Board of War, dated Albany, June 27, 1778.
div.p: YOUR letter of the 16th in≈øtant, covering re≈øolutions of Congre≈øs of the 11th, I had the honour to receive on the 25th at night. I was determined to have commenced my journey to York-Town on this day, but conceive it my duty to delay my departure until the bu≈øine≈øs directed to the attention of the Commi≈ø≈øioners of Indian affairs is adju≈øted.

Congre≈øs will be plea≈øed to pardon me, if I pre≈øume to ob≈øerve that the object of the expedition, being confined to the cha≈øti≈øement of the Senecas only, does not ≈øeem to be broad enough, as the Cayugas are equally in≈øo ‚Ä¢ ent and ho≈øtile, and that ≈øome of the Onondagoes are al≈øo proper objects of puni≈øhment. Both of the≈øe lie directly in the route to the Seneca country.

I have taken the liberty to inclo≈øe General Gates copy of a letter la≈øt night received from Mr. Deane (copy of which I have al≈øo the honour herewith to tran≈ømit to Congre≈øs) and ob≈øerved that, from the information it contained, the pro≈øecuting of the expedition with all po≈ø≈øible di≈øpatch ≈øeems to have become now more indi≈øpen≈øibly nece≈ø≈øary.
I have al≈øo hinted that the real object of the enterprize ought to be carefully concealed. I do not adduce the rea≈øons, as they will occur, or probably have already occurred.

I do not know if General Gates will con≈øider him≈øelf at liberty to order Colonel Gan≈øevoort's regiment as part of the troops for this ≈øervice. As it is numerous, and I believe well appointed, may I be permitted to wi≈øh that they were employed on this occa≈øion, and that orders be given for the purpo≈øe. There can be no danger of Fort Schuyler, whil≈øt the troops for the expedition are in that part of the country, and I humbly apprehend it might be ≈øafely tru≈øted to a corps of militia, e≈øpecially if two or three of Colonel Gan≈øevoort's officers were left, with about twenty-five of his privates.

As the batteaus which were ordered to be built in this quarter are not all fini≈øhed, I have taken the liberty to advi≈øe the Quarter Ma≈øter to con≈øtruct the remainder in ≈øuch manner as to adapt them to the navigation of the Mohawk river, where they will be wanted to convey the provi≈øions, &c. to Fort Schuyler, which appears to me without compari≈øon to be the be≈øt, if not the only proper place to rendezvous the troops, both on account of its vicinity to the road leading to the Seneca country, and as it offers a fine opportunity effectually to conceal the object of the expedition until the troops are in march.

If the Senecas, who went from hence to Head-Quarters, are not yet adverti≈øed of the death of the Chief they are in ≈øearch of, I wi≈øh them to be detained as long as po≈ø≈øible. Perhaps a pretence of ≈øending an expre≈øs to Fort Pitt to enquire for the Indian may an≈øwer the end.
Major General Schuyler reque≈øts that Major General St. Clair may be ≈øworn.
Major General St. Clair being ≈øworn,
Q. by General Schuyler. During the time I had the honour of having you under my command, did you ever ob≈øerve any neglect of duty in my conduct?
A. None. As far as it fell within my ob≈øervation, I have ≈øeen the direct contrary.
General Schuyler's que≈øtion. If I had been in Ticonderoga during the ≈øiege, what would have been the probable con≈øequences?

A. The immediate con≈øequences, it appears to me, mu≈øt have been, that the re≈øt of the department mu≈øt have been neglected; becau≈øe your post ought to have been at or near Albany, to have collected the nece≈ø≈øaries, and to have urged on the militia for the aid of the whole. Ticonderoga was at a corner of the department, in an uninhabited part of the country, and the communication to it from any part of the country (except New-England) acro≈øs a Lake.
General Schuyler's que≈øtion. Upon any alarm, did I turn out my≈øelf and the troops with any degree of alacrity?
A. Whenever there was an alarm, and I was pre≈øent, I have always ≈øeen you do it with great alacrity, and you were always pre≈øent your≈øelf.
Q. Court. What did you under≈øtand the intention of the order of Congre≈øs was, in appointing you to the command of Ticonderoga?

A. I under≈øtood it was that I ≈øhould take the command of that po≈øt, ≈øubject to the orders of General Schuyler, or the Commanding Officer in the Northern Department; but I did not expect that he, or the Commanding Officer, was per≈øonally to have taken the command of that po≈øt from me.
General Schuyler's que≈øtion to Major Lan≈øing. Were you at Fort Edward with me immediately after the evacuation of Ticonderoga?
A. I was.
General Schuyler's que≈øtion. Did you at that time, or at any time before or ≈øince, ob≈øerve any negligence in my conduct with re≈øpect to public matters?
A. I did not; but at that time, and at every other time before and ≈øince, I ob≈øerved in you the greate≈øt attention to public matters, as far as came within my ob≈øervation.

General Schuyler's que≈øtion. Did I not, immediately after I returned from Ticonderoga, on being informed of the approach of the enemy, make application to the State of New-York, and to the other States, to endeavour to get out the militia?
A. You did to the State of New-York and to the Ea≈øtern States, except Rhode-I≈øland, immediately on your return to Saratoga, on being informed of the enemy's approach.
After the examination of the above witne≈ø≈øes, the General clo≈øes his Defence as follows:

It is incumbent on me to remark that the ob≈øervation made by the Judge Advocate, that I went to Ticonderoga in con≈øequence of General St. Clair's letters of the 13th or 18th June, is founded in error, which will appear by a retro≈øpect of my letter to Congre≈øs of the 14th from Saratoga, in which I expre≈øly informed them that I arrived at that place on the evening of the 13th, on my way to Ticonderoga, and that at twelve I received an expre≈øs from General St. Clair, with his letters of the 13th.

Permit me, Mr. Pre≈øident, and Gentlemen of the Court Martial, briefly to ob≈øerve, that from the beginning of November, 1776, to the latter end of March following, which was a month after I was ≈øuperceded, my exertions to prepare for the campaign of 1777 were without intermi≈ø≈øion. That immediately on my reappointment I returned to Albany, and adopted every po≈ø≈øible mea≈øure to provide the nece≈ø≈øaries for the campaign, to procure intelligence of the enemy's intentions, and to conciliate the affections, or guard again≈øt the ho≈øtile intentions, of the Indians; that within eight days after my arrival at Albany I went to vi≈øit Ticonderoga and the northern communication, that I might be per≈øonally informed of what was nece≈ø≈øary to be provided or done; that I was on the point of doing the like to Fort Schuyler and the we≈øtern communication, when General St. Clair's letter arrived, advi≈øing me of the approach of the enemy; that I lo≈øt not a moment's time in applying for reinforcements both of continental troops and militia; that I was on the way to put my≈øelf at the head of the ≈ømall body of militia which had moved, when I received the account of the evacuation of Ticonderoga; that after that my exertions to prevent or retard the enemy's progre≈øs were without intermi≈ø≈øion, and not without ≈øucce≈øs, until I was, unhappily for me, no longer permitted to direct the military operations in the Northern Department; that from that time until this day I have never cea≈øed affording every aid in my power to give ≈øucce≈øs to the glorious cau≈øe America is engaged in.

Here, Gentlemen, I ≈øhall re≈øt my defence. It has indeed been prolix, but important. Facts and plain narrative, not declamation, have made it ≈øo. My whole conduct has been, with the utmo≈øt candour, ≈øubmitted to your examination, and I hope the re≈øult of this enquiry will re≈øtore me to that full confidence, which, at lea≈øt, the rectitude of my intentions gives me rea≈øon to expect. I forbear dwelling on the cau≈øes to which its diminution is to be a≈øcribed, le≈øt I ≈øhould be ≈øu≈øpected of a de≈øign rather to reproach than explain. Whatever may be time event, permit me to a≈ø≈øure you that my affection for my country will continue unimpaired,
and that among the late≈øt actions of my life will be found the mo≈øt ≈øincere endeavours to promote her pro≈øperity.

I cannot di≈ømi≈øs this ≈øubject, without acknowledging my obligations for the candour and patience with which I have been heard, or without expre≈ø≈øing the high ≈øen≈øe I entertain of the attention of his Excellency the Commander in Chief, in in≈øtituting ≈øo re≈øpectable a Court on my trial.

THE Court, having con≈øidered the charge again≈øt Major General Schuyler, the evidence, and his defence, are unanimou≈øly of opinion that he is NOT GUILTY of any Neglect of Duty in not being at Ticonderoga, as charged, and the Court therefore do acquit him with the highe≈øt honour.
